message: Republican leaders are promising to repeal the Affordable Care Act as quickly as possible during the 115th Congress, which begins tomorrow. It is now more important than ever that I hear directly from you about the benefits of this important law. When you have a minute, please submit your story about how the health reform law impacted you and your family.

Moments ago, I was sworn into the 115th Congress by House Speaker Paul Ryan. I am forever grateful to my constituents for their continued trust and support. Serving the people of Western New York has been the honor of my life and I’m ready to work harder than ever on their behalf. We must create a fairer economy that finally benefits American families. I will continue fighting to pay women equal pay for equal work, because when a woman is paid less, it cheats her entire family. I will also keep working to make college more affordable and preserve the effectiveness of antibiotics. I’m proud of what we’re accomplished together and look forward to getting to work in the 115th Congress to address the challenges facing all of my constituents.

The Republican rules package enacted yesterday is deeply troubling and is a direct retaliation against Democrats who, after exhausting all other options this June, took to the House Floor to push for a vote on sensible legislation to prevent those on the terrorist watch list from buying a gun. This was a necessary protest, and Democrats were doing what the Constitution allows—expressing free speech and peacefully assembling. Democratic members  represent roughly half of the population of this country. We have ideas and deserve to be heard. I will not be deterred from fighting for action on the gun violence epidemic!

After many months of work, I received an exciting call from the Secretary of Energy this week. The Rochester Institute of Technology has been named winner of a hard-fought, nationwide competition by the U.S. Department of Energy to headquarter a new clean energy manufacturing institute. This center will be instrumental in growing our economy and ensuring that Monroe County remains a global leader in manufacturing innovation. Rochester is the only city in the country to secure two of these federal awards and this is a testimony to the world-class laboratories, industry leaders, and research happening right here in our community! Our efforts are paying off and you can count on me to remain a relentless fighter for our region.

Women’s healthcare will be under siege during the Trump administration and Republican-led Congress. That’s why I’m holding a press conference today with Leader Pelosi, Congresswoman DeGette and other pro-choice leaders to sound the alarm. Men in blue suits and red ties have no place telling women what they can and should do when it comes to their own health. If the president-elect and Republican leaders in Congress try to ratchet up the war on women, then we are prepared to fight tooth and nail against them. The government shouldn’t be in the business of taking away women’s health care rights! You can watch this event live here.

I am proud to have brought the Affordable Care Act to the House Floor in 2009 as Chairwoman of the Rules Committee. This law finally prevented insurance companies from treating being a woman as a preexisting condition. Before this law was enacted, eight states and the District of Columbia treated domestic violence as a pre-existing condition. Now, survivors of abuse are able to get the health care they need. Republicans in Washington won’t acknowledge it, but there is no doubt the Affordable Care Act has made insurance for women in America better, cheaper, and more available. I’m proud to have stood up today against the push to repeal this law, including the effort to defund Planned Parenthood. I hope women and men all across the country stand up and join this fight!

After years of political witch hunts like the Benghazi and Planned Parenthood panels,  which uncovered absolutely no wrongdoing but cost taxpayers millions of dollars, Republican leaders passed new rules giving them even more power to go on political fishing expeditions. The new rules give their Republican staffers the remarkable power to compel private citizens to testify in unilateral, partisan, closed door depositions. Freely handing the power to compel any American to appear, sit in a room, and answer staff’s invasive questions on the record is truly unprecedented, unwarranted, and offensive. Republicans in Congress have shattered decades of the careful use of bipartisan, Member-led deposition authority. Republican staffers were not elected to Congress, and we should not be delegating powerful investigative authorities to them that belong solely in the hands of Members.

From protecting benefits for disabled officers to securing emergency preparedness funding for Rochester, I have always been a proud advocate for our law enforcement agencies. That’s why today my Washington office “went blue” in celebration of National Law Enforcement Appreciation day, to honor the brave men and women who put themselves in harm’s way for us every single day. Thank you to those who serve, I am sincerely grateful for the work that you do!

Republicans don’t want to talk about them, but there are many important provisions under the Affordable Care Act that are benefiting Americans every single day. A particularly important provision has finally eliminated annual and lifetime caps on healthcare coverage that often used to limit coverage just when people needed it the most. Before the this law, many plans set a dollar amount on what they would spend on covered benefits while enrolled in a plan. Thanks to the Affordable Care Act, that cap on healthcare benefits has been lifted. This is one of the many reasons I’m going to fight to preserve and strengthen this law despite vows from President-elect Trump and Republicans in Congress to repeal it as quickly as possible, without any plan to replace it.

Like so many of you, I am deeply troubled by the findings from the 17 U.S. intelligence agencies that have documented proof of foreign interference in last year’s elections. There have been a lot of questions raised about what leaders in Congress are planning to do about it. I have now co-sponsored legislation with over 170 of my colleagues calling for an independent, bipartisan commission to investigate exactly what happened and suggest ways to prevent it from ever happening again. This legislation would create a 12-member, bipartisan, independent commission empowered to interview witnesses, obtain documents, issue subpoenas, and receive public testimony to examine how actions supported by the Russian government interfered with, and undermined trust in in the November election. This kind of behavior by foreign actors undermines trust in our democratic process, and we simply cannot let it become the new normal!

I wrote the STOCK Act, one of the most important ethics bills in a generation, to ban insider trading by federal officials after reports surfaced that individuals in congressional offices had abused the public trust. It is because of the disclosure requirements in this law that questionable stock trades by President-elect Trump’s nominee to head the Department of Health and Human Services, Congressman Tom Price, have recently come to light. Reports have indicated that Congressman Price made hundreds of stock trades since the STOCK Act was enacted, including stocks of 40 different companies in the health care sector. This is especially concerning since Congressman Price was privy to information not available to the public in his role as chairman of House Budget Committee and a member of the House Ways & Means Subcommittee on Health. Today, I am asking the Securities and Exchange Commission to launch an investigation and resolve this matter as quickly as possible. I don’t take this step lightly, especially since this involves a fellow member of the House of Representatives. But we must ensure that all federal officials uphold our sacred trust with the people we represent.

Senator Sessions’ confirmation hearing today to be President-elect Trump’s Attorney General only strengthened the doubts I have about his nomination. As our nation’s top law enforcement officer, Mr. Sessions would be responsible for protecting the rights of all Americans, including women and minorities. If past is prologue, his voting record suggests he would not live up to this responsibility. Not only has Senator Sessions consistently opposed women’s reproductive rights, he also voted  against the Violence Against Women Act three times. I’m proud to be an original author of this landmark legislation, which has reduced the rate of domestic violence by 67% since 1994. It is unconscionable to me that any member of Congress would vote against protecting sexual assault survivors once, let alone three times. I’m also especially disappointed that in the hearing today, Senator Sessions refused to say whether he would hire a special prosecutor if the President-elect or his family violates insider trading laws like the STOCK Act, a law I also wrote to hold federal officials accountable. As a member of the House of Representatives, I don’t vote on cabinet nominations but I feel strongly that we should #StopSessions!

Upholding ethics laws is no laughing matter. I have asked the Securities and Exchange Committee to launch an investigation into Congressman Tom Price, the president-elect’s nominee for Secretary of Health and Human Services, because federal officials have a responsibility to uphold the sacred trust of the people they represent. The disclosure requirements in the law that I wrote, the STOCK Act, uncovered questionable trades, and we need an investigation to figure out if any wrongdoing has occurred. The incoming administration may take this lightly, but I do not!

Another important provision of the Affordable Care Act focuses on providing preventative care services at no out-of-pocket expense. Under the ACA, health plans must cover critical services like flu shots, cancer screenings, and immunizations at no extra cost to insurance-holders. In New York State alone, this provision has benefited more than 8.6 million people! This is just one of the many reasons that I’m going to keep fighting tooth and nail to protect this law so Americans can continue receiving the affordable, quality care they deserve.

The president-elect’s press conference yesterday regarding his tangled web of business conflicts sadly wasn’t worth the wait. Simply handing over his businesses to his sons and associates does nothing to prevent him from using his presidency as a means of enriching himself and his family. The only solution is to completely divest himself from his businesses and put his assets in a blind trust like every other president in modern history. Even the nonpartisan Office of Government Ethics called the president-elect’s proposal “meaningless.” During his campaign, Mr. Trump assured us that he would be president for all Americans and yet he continues to put personal profit over the interests of the country. I’m going to continue to push the incoming administration to resolve its conflicts of interest so we can give the American people the transparent and accountable government they deserve!

After midnight this morning, the Senate put the wheels in motion to repeal the Affordable Care Act despite having no replacement for the millions of people who depend on this law. It is completely outrageous that Republicans in Congress have voted to pull the rug out from tens of millions of people and eliminate this life-saving coverage, which could throw our health insurance market into chaos. Many of you have asked how you could get involved in the fight to protect this law. I want you to join me in Rochester this Sunday in support of the Affordable Care Act and against the dangerous agenda of repeal. You will hear first-hand from your neighbors and local healthcare professionals on how the ACA protects our community. Please invite your friends and family and make sure all of our voices are heard!
NA

The President-elect is simply not doing enough to remedy his conflicts of interest at home and around the globe. That’s why I'm standing with my colleagues in demanding that Speaker Ryan do more in helping disentangle Mr. Trump’s complicated web of business interests, specifically those involving Russian investors and development partners. Although the President-elect has denied having any business projects in Russia, he has not addressed investments and partnerships with Russians in other projects around the world. I’m urging President-elect Trump to release all the financial documents necessary to ensure that his business deals are in compliance with the Constitution he will soon swear to uphold. In one week, Mr. Trump will be our President and it is now past time that he put his country before his businesses.

The past week I’ve heard from many of you who are concerned by the President-elect and Republican leaders’ misguided plan to repeal the Affordable Care Act. Many of you have asked how you can get involved and what you can do to help protect and strengthen this important law. I want you to know that I hear, and share, your concerns. That’s why I will be hosting an ACA press conference at 1:00 PM this Sunday, January 15 at Workers United in Rochester. I will be joined by healthcare experts and constituents who will share personal stories about how the Affordable Care Act has changed their lives for the better. I hope you will join me in making sure that your voice is heard in this important debate!   Let me now if you’re planning to attend, RSVP here today:

The past few weeks, I’ve heard from many of you about the life-changing benefits of the Affordable Care Act. Just recently I heard from Linda, a mother of two young women who need monthly shots to help control and monitor their severe asthma. Before the ACA, Linda struggled to find healthcare coverage for her daughters, who were denied care because of their pre-existing condition. Without the Affordable Care Act, Linda would have to pay $5,000 out-of-pocket for her daughters’ medication. Under the ACA, however, Linda only pays $40 a month! Thanks to the Affordable Care Act, 30 million young adults between the ages of 18 and 34 with pre-existing conditions can no longer be charged higher premiums and denied coverage altogether. This is just one of the many reasons I’m going to continue fighting relentlessly to protect and strengthen this important law!    For more information on how the Affordable Care Act has changed the lives for millions with pre-existing conditions, please visit here:

Constituents from across the country are asking what their leaders in Congress are planning to do about the President-elect and Republican leaders’ plan to repeal the Affordable Care Act. I hear your concerns and I want you to join me tomorrow, Sunday, January 15th at Workers United in Rochester to rally together and support this landmark law. I will be joined by healthcare providers and constituents who will talk about how the ACA has helped to change their lives and their families lives for the better. Come and make sure your voice is heard in this important debate!   Let me know if you’re planning to attend, RSVP here:

Today I will be joined by healthcare providers and constituents from across Rochester in support of the Affordable Care Act, which President-elect Trump and Republican leaders in Congress  have vowed to repeal with no replacement plan in sight. Every voice counts in this fight, and I want you to join me this afternoon at Workers United in Rochester at 1:00 PM to help push back against the incoming administration’s promise to eliminate healthcare coverage for tens of millions of Americans. Please invite friends and family as we work together to protect the ACA!   Let me know if you’re planning to attend, RSVP here:

Today I stood with doctors, nurses, my constituents Jonathan and Claire, and hundreds of others from our region in support of the Affordable Care Act. Jonathan is a new business owner who credits the ACA for giving him the entrepreneurial courage to step out on his own. Claire is the mother of Chris, a bright 24-year-old pursuing a PhD whose life-threatening condition has been made manageable by remaining under his mother’s plan. Jonathan and Claire’s stories are two of thousands that speak to the life-changing benefits that the Affordable Care Act offers. Mr. Trump’s campaign was centered around change, but repealing the ACA with no alternative in place will cause chaos in insurance markets and deny all Americans protections under the ACA. People asked for change but what they’re getting is a step back in time to when insurance companies’ profits came first and delivering healthcare to those who need it was an afterthought. People want help improving their lives, they don’t want their healthcare taken away with absolutely no plan to replace it. Instead of moving our nation forward, Republican leaders and the President-elect are taking us back in the wrong direction. You can count on me to continue fighting relentlessly against efforts to repeal this law that you have come to depend on!

Today, as we celebrate the life and legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., I am reminded of his words, "the time is always right to do what is right." Let the Rochester community and communities all across the country recommit ourselves to do what is right and just as we face challenges and work together to build a stronger tomorrow!

In case you missed it, last week I was so proud to announce nearly $150,000 in funding for the Rochester Institute of Technology to continue their award-winning counter-terrorism project, “It’s Time: ExOut Extremism.” By harnessing the power of social media, this team has been able to fight against online extremism and global terrorism.  This award is a testament not only to the importance of this project but also to the world-class research happening right here in our community. I often say that Rochester is home to some of the brightest minds in the country, and this team is no exception!

Many of you have been asking whether or not I plan to attend Friday’s inauguration for President-elect Trump. I take the privilege of serving as a member of Congress seriously, so this was not an easy decision. Congressman John Lewis and I came to Congress at the same time, and he has become like a brother to me. He came to Rochester late last year and visited the convent where nuns from Rochester saved his life on the Edmund Pettus Bridge. For all that he’s stood for all these years, I’m happy to stand with him. As tough as this decision is, I was sent to Washington to get things done, which is why I will be working with the president-elect in the years ahead to move my district and our nation forward. In an effort to express my willingness to work in a bipartisan manner going forward, I do plan to join the President-elect at a bipartisan congressional lunch after his inauguration.

The Republican rules package passed last week contains several troubling provisions. One provision that went less noticed, but that is perhaps most alarming, is the Majority’s new rule that wildly expands staff deposition authority, meaning Republicans can force anyone in the country to sit in a room and be interrogated under oath by Republican staff from almost any House committee. Previously, a Member of Congress needed to be present for such an interview. Now, the Republicans have given themselves the authority to go on more political fishing expeditions like the Benghazi and Planned Parenthood panels, which uncovered absolutely no wrongdoing but cost the taxpayers millions of dollars. This is absolutely unconscionable. Republican staffers were not elected to Congress, and powerful investigative authority should stay in the hands of those who were.

Last week, I called on the Securities and Exchange Commission to conduct a complete investigation into the hundreds of questionable stock trades made by Congressman Tom  Price, nominee for Secretary of Health and Human Services. The evidence continues to build that Congressman Price made several trades on health care stocks, even as he worked on related legislation as a member of Congress. One example is Congressman Price’s purchase of thousands of dollars’ worth of shares of Zimmer Biomet, a medical device company that stood to benefit from legislation Price introduced—just one week later—that would’ve bolstered Zimmer’s profits by stalling new Medicare regulations. As the author of the STOCK Act, a law that bans insider trading, I have worked tirelessly to put an end to public officials using their positions for personal profit. Representative Price's investment activities at best show a pattern of questionable judgement in upholding the public trust. Yesterday, I spoke with Politico about this troubling situation. I was so proud to announce Emily Phelan, Lilly Wellman, and Michelle Russotti from Bishop Kearney High School as winners of the third annual Congressional App Challenge for the 25th district of New York. Emily, Michelle, and Lilly created “FutureUSports” an innovative organizational tool for high school athletes looking to play at the college level. The development of FutureUSports is proof that advancing knowledge in science, technology, engineering, and mathematical fields is not only educational, but can also be fun! I often say that Rochester is home to some of brightest minds in the country, and these young women are no exception. Congratulations on your tremendous achievement Emily, Michelle, and Lilly!

My office is located on the fourth floor of the Rayburn House Office Building, room 2469. Hope to see you there!

Don’t forget! My office will be open today, Friday, January 20th from 9 am to 5 pm for anyone traveling down from Rochester for the Women’s March on Washington or the inauguration. Please feel free to stop by, warm up, and enjoy a cup of coffee! My office is located on the fourth floor of the Rayburn House Office Building, room 2469. Hope to see you there!

Looking to escape the cold? Come by my office today, Saturday, January 21st between 9am and 5pm to check out the view and warm up! My office is located on the fourth floor of the Rayburn House Office Building, room 2469.

Thank you to the hundreds of constituents who stopped by my office over the last two days while in Washington, DC for the inauguration and national women's march. It was wonderful to speak with so many of you during this memorable weekend!

This morning, President Trump signed executive orders to advance the Keystone XL and Dakota Access Pipelines, harmful projects that have the potential to devastate the air we breathe and the water we drink. The Keystone XL pipeline would transmit some of the dirtiest oil on the planet and add carbon dioxide into the atmosphere that is the equivalent of putting up to 5.5 million cars on the road. It wouldn’t lower gas prices for consumers and would only create an estimated 35 permanent jobs. In addition, the Dakota Access Pipeline would endanger clean drinking water and the cultural and sacred sites of the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe. These dangerous projects were rejected for a reason, and I’m disappointed by the president’s decision today. I will keep fighting for a sustainable clean energy future that truly helps power the our economy!

This afternoon the House considered H.R 7, a deceptively-titled bill that would undermine women’s health care in this country and continue the Republican Majority’s unending assault on the Constitutionally-protected right to have an abortion. Last night at the Rules Committee meeting on this bill, I made clear why the Republicans’ endless efforts to infringe on our rights are so upsetting and how this extreme agenda would send us back to a deeply troubling period in our nation’s history. As I said last night, we will not give back the progress our mothers won for us!

It is unacceptable that the health insurance industry has a special exemption from anti-trust laws designed to promote fair competition benefiting consumers. This makes it easier for them to raise your premiums and make coverage less affordable. I’ve joined with my colleague, Peter DeFazio from Oregon, in introducing legislation that will end the exemption and prevent health insurance companies from colluding to raise prices. This legislation is especially important as Republicans in Congress repeal the Affordable Care Act, which will reverse years of progress in helping slow down costs. Given Washington Republicans’ extreme agenda, we need to do everything in our power to close the loopholes designed to benefit big insurance companies.

This afternoon, President Trump signed an executive order that directs federal resources toward the construction of a wall along the border between the U.S. and Mexico. Construction of a 2,000 mile-long wall is not only impractical, it is also an inefficient use of  federal dollars. Federal spending on border security over the last few years has been at the highest level our country has ever seen. In fiscal year 2016 alone, Congress appropriated nearly $4.5 billion toward these efforts, which helped support over 20,000 U.S. Border Patrol agents and other security measures like fencing, video surveillance systems, sensors, and manned and unmanned aircraft to constantly monitor and protect the border. There is still work to be done and I will keep working on comprehensive reforms, but this is not the way. This wall was preposterous when it was a political talking point, and it is even more offensive as actual policy.

This week I was proud to have voted for bipartisan legislation that gives the Federal Communications Commission new tools to crack down on spoofing scams and hold wrongdoers accountable. These scams aren’t just an inconvenience, they are used by criminals who seek to defraud and take advantage of unsuspecting victims. I’ve heard from many of you who have been harmed by this activity, which has been on the rise through text messaging and phone calls made over internet connections. Some people have even been forced to give away their life savings as a result of these scams, which have sent millions of dollars to con artists working abroad. This legislation is a commonsense way to help keep you safe and hold scammers more accountable. It's also a reminder that lawmakers can and should spend their time making government work rather than grinding progress to a halt.

I am so pleased to announce that the nonpartisan Government Accountability Office (GAO) has agreed to my request for an investigation that examines the effects of large, corporate restructurings on American workers’ pensions and health care benefits.Corporate restructurings, mergers, bankruptcies, and spinoffs have been on the rise for decades and while they allow for companies to grow and enter new markets, there is no denying that American workers are often harmed in the process, and in some cases, suffer from slashed pension and healthcare benefits they’ve earned after years of hard work. This investigation will look into the trends of corporate restructuring over the last twenty years and will provide members of Congress with the information needed to protect their constituents’ health care coverage and retirement security. I look forward to learning the results and you can count on me to continue to working to ensure employees and retirees receive the retirement benefits and peace of mind they have earned and deserve.

Yesterday it came to light that the Trump administration eliminated funding on all Affordable Care Act outreach efforts including commercials, advertisements, and emails that had already been paid for in an attempt to undermine this law and deny millions of people healthcare. Make no mistake, this move is a deliberate attempt to sabotage the ACA. It is shameful that Republicans, who are already trying to repeal this law, are now working to prevent people from getting the care they need while it is still in place. Not only is this a waste of taxpayer money—nearly $5 million dollars—it could also do serious harm to our insurance market by preventing millions of people from signing up during open enrollment, which ends on January 31st. We cannot let the administration get away with this. I encourage everyone to visit the link below and sign up now. Please share this so your friends and families do not miss their chance to get the coverage they need!

Today we celebrate the eighth anniversary of the Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act, a historic law that provides protections against pay discrimination in the workplace on the basis of sex. I was so proud to bring this bill to the floor as Chairwoman of the Rules Committee in 2009 and I stand by what I said on that day: a woman should not be paid less because she’s a woman. Even though this landmark law helped pave the way for equal pay, women still face discrimination in the workplace. On average, women who work full time earn only 77 cents for every dollar earned by a man. Even worse, African American women earn only 64 cents and Latinas earned only 56 cents for each dollar earned by a white man. I have always been a proud advocate for equal pay and you can count on me to continue fighting for this important cause!

Thank you Judge Ann Donnelly of the Federal District Court in Brooklyn for blocking part of the president's recently-issued executive order on immigration! And thanks to the many of you who have spoken out and made clear that this executive order is contrary to our values.

Over the past several weeks I’ve heard from many of you who are concerned about the crusade by the president and the Republican Congress against everything from women’s rights and environmental protections to the health care law and government accountability. There is a real desire out there to get involved in these legislative fights and ensure that your voice is being heard. I applaud you for this, and I want to give you all the tools you need.   1. Sign up for congressional alerts—these will allow you to get up-to-date information about specific legislation and the day’s activities in Congress: http://bit.ly/2jjlW76   2. Reach out to your elected leaders directly: http://bit.ly/1kyGkev or http://bit.ly/1F71fC2   3. Your involvement in the issues being debated in our nation's capital can help shape and sometimes even change the direction elected representatives take. We saw this recently when public outcry against the House Republicans’ plan to gut the Office of Congressional Ethics made them reverse course. So please, stay engaged and involved - don't agonize, organize! And, as always, please feel free to reach out to me at www.louise.house.gov. I am prepared to fight tooth and nail for the issues important to our community and nation and I truly value your input.

Today, I will join many of my House Democratic colleagues in filing the Statute of Liberty Values Act, a bill which states that the president’s executive order barring those from Muslim-majority countries will have no effect or force of law and states that no funds or fees will be used to implement the action.The president’s order is unconstitutional, immoral, and makes our country less safe. We must not allow our refugee admission program to be decimated and I refuse to sit quietly as the president implements a de facto Muslim ban that is contradictory to who we are as a nation. As I continue to fight this order, I’ve been heartened to see the tens of thousands of protesters who have come out against this order and the many lawyers that sprang into action to help the people detained in airports over the weekend. Our compassion for those who are suffering is a source of our nation’s great strength - we must continue to defend America’s values and ideals!

I have heard from hundreds of you over the last few days who are strongly opposed to the president’s executive order banning travel from Muslim countries and suspending the refugee program. We cannot let this de facto Muslim ban be implemented without a fight. That’s why I’ve joined more than 160 of my colleagues today in introducing the Statue of Liberty Values Act to block president Trump’s harmful executive order. This order runs counter to our nation’s fundamental values and I will work shoulder to shoulder with all of you to prevent it from being implemented!

This is very reminiscent of President Nixon’s Saturday Night Massacre. The president’s decision to fire Acting Attorney General Sally Yates is a blatant politicization of the agency charged with upholding our constitution. This is another troubling day for our country.

Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee have just boycotted today’s vote on the president’s nomination of Tom Price for Secretary of Health and Human Services, preventing his nomination from moving forward. Many members of the committee expressed concern about his questionable judgement, including recent reports that his testimony at his confirmation hearing was not truthful. I’m proud to have been the first member of Congress to call for an SEC investigation into Congressman Price’s troubling stock trades, which came to light because of the STOCK Act, the law I authored to ban insider trading by federal officials. In addition to evidence of insider trading, just yesterday we learned that House ethics rules prohibiting gifts and using an official office for personal gain may have been broken as well. How many revelations will it take before the president and Republican leadership admit that Congressman Price is too tainted by scandal to run the Department of Health and Human Services?

Today, Republicans on the Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions voted to move Betsy DeVos’ nomination for Secretary of Education to the Senate floor. Over the past few weeks, I’ve heard from hundreds of teachers, students, and parents who are troubled by Mrs. DeVos’ nomination and I share  those concerns. At a time when the prior administration has done so much to strengthen education in this country, Mrs. DeVos’ nomination would take us backward. She believes in voucherizing our public school system, which would cut standards, increase costs, and potentially give our kids a mediocre education. Mrs. DeVos’ performance during her confirmation hearing also raised serious questions about her depth of policy knowledge and ability to enforce federal laws. If Republicans in Washington get their way, she would be just another member of a cabinet full of billionaires and CEOs. I stand with my Democratic colleagues in the Senate who are rejecting this nomination!

This evening the House Republicans voted to order the previous question, a procedure that prevented debate on the Statue of Liberty Values Act. This legislation that I helped introduce yesterday would defund and rescind the president’s harmful executive order banning travel from Muslim countries and suspending the refugee program. The president’s xenophobic order is driven by fear. Apparently the Republicans are also afraid, refusing to stand up to President Trump and demand that he withdraw this dangerous plan. It is shameful that congressional Republicans are allowing an order to stand that demonstrates such a callous indifference to human suffering, likely ignores the Constitution, and harms our national security. The growing protests around the country are proof that the American people are closely watching what goes on in Congress. They will be holding their representatives accountable for turning a blind eye to this blatant attack on our values.

President Trump has already promised to nominate a justice to the Supreme Court that will overturn the landmark Roe v. Wade decision protecting a woman’s Constitutional right to have an abortion. No president before has ever bragged about such a litmus test. Regardless of what is said publicly in the coming months, I’m deeply concerned about what could have been said behind closed doors as the president made this decision. Judge Gorsuch is a proponent of the same radically conservative judicial philosophy as Justice Scalia and would go even further by eliminating Chevron deference, which would dangerously undermine the regulatory process. I’m also deeply concerned about Judge Gorsuch’s troubling record of condemning those who have often turned to the courts to live up to our nation’s ideals of equality, women’s rights, and civil rights.

Recently, I’ve heard from hundreds of constituents concerned by the Trump administration’s rollback of vital environmental protections. I share these concerns. Just last week, the president signed executive orders to kick-start construction of the Dakota Access and Keystone XL pipelines, which were rejected by the previous administration due to health and environmental concerns. President Trump also moved to expand efforts to drill on federal land. These priorities are dangerous and have the potential to destroy our precious ecosystems, displace wildlife, and contaminate our land and water. I’ve always been a proud advocate for our environment, from protecting our Great Lakes as co-chair of the bipartisan Great Lakes Task Force and securing grants for solar power development to introducing legislation that expands funding opportunities for businesses interested in developing clean energy. Preserving our air, water, and skies isn’t just good for our environment, it’s good for our economy too. I will oppose efforts by this administration and the Republican Congress to put the demands of Big Oil and the energy industry before doing what’s best for future generations.

Republican plans to repeal the Affordable Care Act would be devastating for millions of women across the country. Today’s front-page story in the Democrat and Chronicle highlights how destructive this repeal would be for women in Monroe County. Women are fearful about how repeal could affect their ability to afford contraceptive coverage, which is covered at no-cost right now under the Affordable Care Act. These locals and many women across the country are now stockpiling birth control and purchasing long-acting, alternative methods in case Congressional Republicans deliver on their promises to repeal this law. This would increase costs and in some cases make contraceptive care unaffordable. I’m proud to have brought the ACA to the floor of the House in 2009 as Chairwoman of the Rules Committee, and I will continue fighting against plans to strip away coverage from tens of millions of Americans.

It is unconscionable to me that instead of addressing our nation’s most urgent priorities, the president is now trying to roll back one the most effective Wall Street reforms in a generation. The Dodd-Frank financial reform law works to rein in the reckless behavior on Wall Street that nearly brought down our entire economy and led to millions of Americans losing their jobs, homes, and pensions. President Trump’s outrageous plans to target this important law for elimination would only benefit his friends on Wall Street and allies in the industry (aka his cabinet) at the expense of the American people. Working families suffered tremendously during the economic crash of 2008 and that’s why Dodd-Frank was necessary. I will fight any effort to roll back financial reforms so that we can hold the financial industry accountable and prevent them from bringing our economy to the brink of disaster again!

It is outrageous that yesterday Republicans in Washington used the Congressional Review Act (CRA) to repeal safeguards put in place by the prior administration that prevent people with severe mental illnesses from purchasing firearms. What’s worse, the Republicans repealed this important legislation on the same day as the gunman from the South Carolina Church Shooting was announced as suffering from several mental disorders. An estimated 91 people are killed every single day in America by a gun and we should be doing more to keep our communities safe, not less. Using the CRA to play politics with our safety in a way that would put peoples’ lives at risk is unacceptable. As a member of the Gun Violence Prevention Task Force, I will continue supporting commonsense legislation that keeps our families and communities safe and will continue to stand with so many of you who are disgusted by this harmful agenda.

I have said from the beginning that the president’s de facto Muslim ban is likely unconstitutional. I’m pleased that U.S. district Judge James Robart of Washington State ordered an immediate, nationwide stop to the enforcement of President Trump’s dangerous order halting visa-holders from seven majority-Muslim countries from entering the United States and shutting down the U.S. refugee program to Syrian refugees indefinitely. The president’s ensuing attack on Judge Robart is highly inappropriate and a disservice to the separation of powers that our nation was founded upon. The judge’s order, together with the denial of the Justice Department’s subsequent appeal, means that currently the president’s executive order is no longer being enforced as the legal process continues. This is a positive development, but we need to permanently protect our refugee admission program and make sure this order is never again enforced. That’s why I will continue pushing for a vote on the Statue of Liberty Values Act, a bill I introduced to block president Trump’s executive order. This order does not represent American values.

Early this week, the Senate will vote on the nomination of Betsy DeVos to be Secretary of Education. It is unacceptable that this nominee has never attended public school, never taught or worked in education, and believes in voucherizing our public school system. This would divert tax dollars to private schools, cut  academic standards, and potentially give our children a subpar education. After watching Ms. Devos’ confirmation hearings, I am even more concerned that she is out-of-touch with the realities that our students face every single day.  All forty-eight Democratic Senators and two Republican Senators have already said that they plan to vote against this nomination, which would require Vice President Pence to cast the tie-breaking confirmation vote. Senate Historians have confirmed that such an extraordinary circumstance has never happened in our nation’s history. This speaks volumes about Ms. DeVos’ complete lack of qualifications for this important position. I am deeply concerned by this nomination and have heard from hundreds of teachers, students, and parents in Rochester who are equally upset. As a member of the House of Representatives I do not vote on cabinet nominations, but I believe that Ms. DeVos would be a major step in the wrong direction. I will continue standing with my Democratic and Republican colleagues in the Senate who are rejecting Ms. DeVos’ nomination.

This image of President Trump reinstating the Global Gag Rule has stayed with me. It is incomprehensible to think that any president would sign a law restricting millions of women around the globe from accessing the reproductive care they need and deserve. It is troubling but not surprising to see that President Trump would sign this Executive Order in the company of only white men who fail to reflect our nation’s true diversity. In fact, President Trump has nominated sixteen white men and only four women to his cabinet. He is also the first president in decades to fail to include a Hispanic member in his cabinet. In contrast, President Obama’s administration had the highest percentage of women and minorities in history. It's 2017. Our government should look like the people it represents. When it doesn’t, we get bad policies like this Global Gag Rule.

Ahmed Haidar, a Yemeni post-doctoral fellow at the Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT), was barred from reentering the United States while returning home from a conference in Saudi Arabia over the weekend as the president’s de facto Muslim ban was taking effect. Despite the fact the he had a legal visa to be in the United States as part of his two-year program at RIT, Ahmed, his pregnant wife, and his two-year-old daughter were unnecessarily detained in Saudi Arabia. Thankfully, they are now back in Rochester after a district judge recently ordered the nationwide halt to enforcing the president’s likely unconstitutional ban. But this story is a reminder about the real-life impacts of this executive order, which is keeping out  of our country scholars like Ahmed, who are precisely the type of people that help our nation thrive. Yesterday, I also heard from worried parents in our local Muslim-American community  who are terrified of sending their children to school and stories of school bus drivers consoling worried Muslim-American students on their way to school. This is unconscionable. Stories like these are why I will continue to fight to rescind and defund President Trump’s harmful executive order.

This afternoon, the Senate confirmed Betsy DeVos as Secretary of Education in a historic vote that required Vice President Pence to break a 50-50 tie. I’m disappointed that all but two Senate Republicans rubber-stamped a nominee that was by any measure one of the weakest cabinet nominees to ever come before the Senate. The fact that the Vice President was needed to break this tie speaks volumes about Ms. DeVos’ lack of qualifications for this important job. Ms. DeVos never attended public school, never sent her children to public school, and believes in voucherizing the public school system, meaning that tax dollars would be taken from the pockets of public schools and placed into private schools. It would also cut academic standards and potentially give our children a mediocre education.  While I strongly believe that Ms. DeVos was the wrong choice, I take my job as a Member of Congress seriously and now have an obligation to ensure she is better informed about what our children are facing every day. Children in Monroe County and all across the country deserve policies that help them get the best possible education!

President Trump pledged to form an administration that would help American workers. Instead, he has chosen some of the most radical nominees we’ve seen in decades to lead departments in our government that will impact the lives of all Americans for years to come. A cabinet full of billionaires, bankers, and big business leaders will play a leading role in helping the president fulfill his vows to eviscerate the Affordable Care Act, reforms that protect against another financial crash, and critical environmental protections. My offices in Rochester and Washington have been flooded with calls against several of the president's cabinet nominees. Many of you are fearful that the president is going back on his word and protecting the wealthy instead of our workers. I will continue to oppose any efforts by this administration to put the interests of big business and Wall Street ahead of the interests of the American people!

Recently, hundreds of you have called my Washington and Rochester offices with concerns about H.R. 861, a dangerous bill introduced last Friday in the House that would eliminate the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). This threat is especially concerning since the president has nominated Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt to run this important agency, someone who denies the facts on climate change and is a close ally of the fossil fuel industry. In fact, as attorney general for the state of Oklahoma he sued the EPA several times in an attempt to stand in the way of its important work. For more than 40 years, the EPA has helped protect our air, land, and water and the health of millions of people. I strongly oppose this bill and am deeply concerned about Congressional Republicans’ war on science and our environment.

I’ve heard from so many of you who are troubled by the president’s signing of an executive order that gives Steve Bannon a permanent seat on the National Security Council (NSC). Mr. Bannon has a disturbing history of White Nationalist ties and repeatedly and aggressively pushing stories that promote anti-Semitism, xenophobia, and racism. He doesn’t belong anywhere near the White House, and certainly not on the NSC. I have co-sponsored H.R. 804, a bill that would prevent people like Mr. Bannon, whose role is primarily political in nature, from being assigned to the council or having the ability to attend its highly sensitive meetings. It would also give back the Director of National Intelligence and the Chairman of the Joints Chiefs of Staff the standing invitations they deserve. The NSC should be comprised of national security professionals, and we cannot let partisan politics interfere with its important work.

I am so proud to stand with three local families and other members of our community as they pushed for answers after a medical device called a laparoscopic power morcellator brought tragedy into their lives. These devices spread an undetectable fibroid cancer throughout the body like shrapnel – taking Stage 1 cancers immediately to Stage 4. As a result, what should have been routine procedures for three women in Rochester and many throughout the country ended with a death sentence. After learning of the impact on women in Rochester, I led the effort in securing a U.S. Government Accountability Office (GAO) investigation and yesterday this long-awaited report was released, revealing that we need to do more to protect patients. I will continue to push for reforms that ensure that no other families endure the pain of losing a wife, a sister, or a mother. Today, I’m reminded of what Frank Interlichia told me two years ago when we discussed the loss of his wife, that if we truly value patient safety we should be guided by one simple principle: first, do no harm. It’s time to make reasonable changes to help us live up to that principle.

As Ranking Member on the House Rules Committee, I have a front-row seat to Congressional Republicans’ far-reaching campaign against the safeguards you and your family depend on. They are using a seldom-used law, the Congressional Review Act (CRA), to eviscerate protections that millions of Americans need, rolling back rules that impact nearly every segment of society. Using the CRA is a sledgehammer-approach to eliminating government safeguards because it prevents the adoption of any similar rule, ever, unless Congress explicitly passes legislation to allow it.  House Republicans have already used the CRA to make it easier for coal companies to dump toxic waste in our waterways, allow big oil and gas companies to pollute our air with methane leaks, and help oil, gas, and mining companies hide their payments to foreign governments. They have even worked to roll back education standards and a rule long-despised by the gun lobby that helped prevent people with severe mental illnesses from purchasing firearms. The president and congressional Republicans said they were going to help workers. Instead, they are moving quickly to use the CRA to put the interests of their wealthy allies first.

Last night, a three-judge panel of the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals unanimously rejected the Justice Department’s request to lift the order that blocked the president’s de facto Muslim ban from taking effect. This means that the president’s ban, including his suspension of the refugee program, will continue to remain unenforced around the nation. This is an encouraging development and we must do more to ensure that this dangerous executive order never takes effect. I will continue pushing for the bill I've cosponsored to defund and block this harmful order.

Today marks the International Day of Women and Girls in Science. Although women have made great strides in the science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) fields that have positively impacted research across the country, they continue to face the limiting impacts of gender bias. According to a study conducted in 14 countries, the probability of female students graduating with a Bachelor’s degree, Master’s degree and Doctoral degree in science-related field are 18%, 8% and 2% respectively, while the percentages of male students are 37%, 18% and 6%. As a trained microbiologist, I know how important it is that we continue to provide women and girls with the education, resources, and support they need to succeed in STEM fields. You can count on me to continue leading the fight for women scientists around the country!

This month marks Black History Month, an opportunity for us to honor the legacies of so many trailblazers. Rochester is home to many pioneering African American men and women,  including Frederick Douglass, Fannie Barrier Williams, and other activists who helped change our community and country for the better. It has come to my attention that some may not know the history of advocates like Douglass, so let me highlight his efforts here: he escaped to New York at the age of 20 and established himself as an orator and writer, publishing his first abolitionist newspaper in Rochester, where he lived for over 20 years. Mr. Douglass used his influence to advocate for suffrage rights for African Americans and helped move freed slaves up from the south. He was also the only African American to attend the Seneca Falls Convention and was a proud supporter of women’s rights. Douglass spent his entire life pursuing equality for all Americans, and we live in a more just country because of his work.

General Flynn should never have been appointed National Security Advisor in the first place. At best, he lacks the judgement necessary to serve our nation and at worst, his relationship with Putin has compromised his ability to represent American interests. I have serious concerns that sanctions weren’t the only inappropriate thing General Flynn has discussed with the Russian ambassador. This development, together with the president’s refusal to release his tax returns, leaves the American people to wonder whether Russia has a financial and personal hold over the president of the United States. That’s why I’ve called for the president to release his tax returns and for the formation of an independent, bipartisan commission to investigate exactly what happened with the foreign interference in our election. General Flynn’s conduct – a clear violation of the law – is as outrageous as it is inexcusable, and he should be fired immediately

Over the past several days, I have heard from many of you who are concerned by senior presidential counselor Kellyanne Conway’s recent violation of federal ethics rules. Last week while speaking from the White House, Ms. Conway encouraged TV viewers to buy clothing from Ivanka Trump’s fashion brand, a clear violation of the Office of Government Ethics rule that prohibits federal employees from using their office to, “endorse products and services for the private gain of friends, relatives, or persons with whom the employee is affiliated.” Though Ms. Conway was reportedly “counseled” for her actions, her conduct warrants further disciplinary action. President Trump’s tangled web of international business interests have been on display for months and this is just another outrageous example of the current administration putting private profit before the public’s interest. The American public deserves to have confidence that President Trump and his taxpayer-funded employees are working on your behalf, not using the presidency as a publicity stunt to enrich himself and his family. It’s time to speak truth to power and hold the administration accountable when it fails to conduct itself ethically.

Today I led more than 160 of my colleagues in demanding that Speaker Ryan stop Republicans’ unparalleled assault on women’s health care. From working to repeal the Affordable Care Act to advancing legislation to place unprecedented limits on women’s access to reproductive health services, Republicans have made attacking women’s health their top priority. Consideration this week of a measure to roll back the Title X rule is the most serious threat to women’s health so far this Congress. Programs supported by Title X help provide life-saving and preventative health care services to uninsured and low-income men and women nationwide. It is outrageous that Congressional Republicans are now trying to allow conservative state legislatures to pick and choose who can provide this essential care. This marks an entirely new front on Congressional Republicans’ never-ending crusade against women’s access to reproductive health services.

Congressional Republicans have proven they’ll stop at nothing by using the Congressional Review Act to attack Title X, the national family planning program. Last night at the Rules Committee, I voiced my opposition to this government intrusion into our health care.

Today we celebrate Susan B. Anthony Day, which honors the life and legacy of Rochester’s pioneering woman who devoted her life to promoting equality for all Americans. Anthony fought for abolition after moving to Rochester and lobbied for constitutional amendments that outlawed slavery and guaranteed the right to vote, regardless of gender or race. She was a tireless advocate for women’s suffrage, and spoke before every session of Congress between 1869 and 1906 to promote equal voting rights for women. The 19th Amendment, which guaranteed women this right in 1920, is known as the “Susan B. Anthony” amendment—a tribute to our local heroine’s lifelong work. Today and every day, I am grateful for the trailblazing efforts of Susan B. Anthony!

Since President Trump took office, the White House Visitors Office has remained closed to all those wishing to take a tour of the White House. For more than 200 years, the White House has offered tours to the general public. Exploring the White House while visiting the nation’s capital is often times the most popular tour my office arranges and, unfortunately, 20 constituent tours were forced to be canceled during this lengthy closure. That’s why I recently joined over 40 of my colleagues in sending a letter to President Trump calling on him to reopen the White House doors to visitors. While I’m disappointed at the extended closure, I’m pleased to share that the White House has heeded our call and will once again open for public tours. If you’re interested, please visit louise.house.gov at least 21 days in advance to request a ticket.

This week, Congressional Republicans voted to roll back a rule long-despised by the gun lobby that helps prevent people with severe mental illnesses from purchasing firearms. The sad reality is that an estimated 91 people are killed every day by a gun in America and we should be doing more to keep our communities safe, not less. Republicans in Congress should put the American people first, and not their special interest allies. As a member of the Gun Violence Prevention Task Force, you can count on me to continue pushing for commonsense legislation that combats this epidemic and keeps all Americans safe!

Today I had the privilege of meeting with representatives from Monroe Community College, including president Dr. Anne Kress. Monroe Community College is a remarkable institution that has helped enrich the lives of thousands across our region for more than 50 years and I have always been a proud supporter of their work. A strong education is the key to unlocking our nation’s full economic potential, and Rochester is blessed to be home to renowned universities and colleges like MCC.

Holding Election Day one day during the work week is an antiquated system put in place over a century ago. That’s why I’m proud to introduce the Weekend Voting Act, which would move Election Day from the first Tuesday in November to the first Saturday and Sunday after the first Friday in November. This bill would make it easier for all Americans, especially seniors, students, and those who work night shifts, to cast their ballot. If we want to strengthen our democracy, we must make it easier for Americans to vote, not harder! I was proud to introduce this legislation with 22 of my colleagues and with the endorsement of Norman Ornstein, renowned political scientist and resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute. I’m especially pleased to have brought forth this bill yesterday on Susan B. Anthony Day, in honor of Rochester’s trailblazing activist who dedicated her life to ensuring everyone had equal access to the ballot box.

This week, I took to the House Floor to set the record straight on federal funding for Planned Parenthood. Let me be clear, not a dime of federal money is used for abortions. Most of Planned Parenthood’s federal funding is from Medicaid reimbursements for the preventative services they provide like cancer screenings and vaccinations for millions of men and women across the country. Congressional Republicans’ deceptive claim that federal money is used for abortions is totally false, and it is now past time that they stop their political spin.

I’ve already heard from David, an obstetrician and gynecologist from my district, who told me about the devastation he witnessed every day as a result of pregnant women not having access to the prenatal care that they need. Under the ACA, pregnancy is no longer considered a pre-existing condition and pregnancy, maternity, and newborn care must be covered. David told me that he has grave concerns about what a repeal of the ACA would do for pregnant women all across the country, and I agree. Pregnant women and newborns are among the most vulnerable populations, and you can count on me to continue fighting against any effort to rip away the care they need to thrive!

The Affordable Care Act (ACA) makes life-saving procedures affordable and accessible for millions of Americans in need. I recently heard from Joanne, whose husband was diagnosed with Leiomyosarcoma, a cancer of the soft tissue. Joanne told me about her husband’s eight-hour surgery and prolonged hospital stay and how, thanks to the ACA, her out-of-pocket expenses were greatly reduced. Joanne also told me that without the ACA, her and her husband would not be able to afford other preventative procedures like CAT scans, which he needs every three months. Like Joanne, I worry that if the Congressional Republicans follow through on their promise to repeal the ACA with nothing in its place, millions of families across the country will no longer be able to afford the life-saving care they need. This is unconscionable. Families like Joanne’s have enough to worry about, and should not be burdened by Washington Republicans’ desire to play politics. I will continue fighting to protect this landmark legislation!

Thanks to the Affordable Care Act (ACA), more young people have health insurance than ever before. Since this law was first enacted in 2009, the uninsured rate for adults under 26 has dropped by 46 percent nationwide and half of young, single adults who are eligible for insurance on the marketplace can get coverage for $50 or less due to cost assistance programs. Before the ACA, young adults were less likely to have quality health care because they were more likely to have employers that didn’t offer insurance or could not afford coverage on their own. Instead of taking away critical programs that work, Congress should be making them work even better for the American people. I will continue to fight against any effort to dismantle the health care options that so many—especially young Americans—have come to depend on!

All across the country, millions of Americans are suffering from addiction to opioids. Under the Affordable Care Act, treatment for addiction is covered like any other medical condition. That’s why the Congressional Republicans’ plans to repeal the ACA with nothing in its place would be so devastating, because it would result in many of our loved ones losing out on essential recovery services. I have always been an adamant supporter of preventative addiction services—from introducing legislation that demands safe drug disposal to demanding the CDC issue guidelines for the safe prescribing of opioids—and I will not stop advocating now. Those who are suffering from addiction deserve quality programs and the chance to turn their lives around!

Recently I asked my constituents to share their thoughts regarding the start of the Trump administration. I have been outspoken in my opposition to the president’s executive orders on women’s reproductive rights, a border wall estimated to cost $15 to $25 billion, and the immigration restrictions impacting refugees. Likewise, I’ve expressed support when justified – namely, the withdrawal from a 12-country trade deal I believe would hurt the people I represent. When asked, 70% of you indicated that you have serious concerns about the current administration and 20% said that you are positive and hopeful for the future given the president’s leadership. This is a troubling ratio, and one that I believe he must address. Thank you to all of those who participated in this survey and to the thousands who continue to share your comments and ideas with me at events, on social media, through website, and by calling my offices. If you want to get regular updates on my work in Congress and partake in my next survey, please visit: https://louise.house.gov/contact/louise-line-sign-up .

This weekend, I had the privilege of celebrating the Greater Harvest Church's third anniversary with Pastor Sebrone Johnson and First Lady Donna Johnson. I am so proud of the work Greater Harvest Church does in advocating for our great community and for their continued commitment to Rochester. Thank you for a wonderful service!

I’ve said it before, President Trump’s team of top advisers does not reflect the true diversity of this country. A new analysis by USA Today found that men outnumber women more than 2-to-1 among the president’s top aides. What’s worse, the president’s senior advisers for policy and homeland security, as well as the heads of the domestic policy, national economic, and national trade councils are all men. If the president continues this pattern, the percentage of women in the White House would be fewer today than at least five of the last six presidencies. Our government should look like the people it serves and the president has an obligation to do more to ensure that all voices are represented.

Recently I asked my constituents to tell me what their top priorities are as the new administration takes shape. The largest percentage of you said your top concern is ensuring American values and civil liberties are being protected under the Trump Administration. This response follows the President’s de facto Muslim ban and appointment Steve Bannon, a man with ties to the White Nationalist Movement, to the National Security Council. I have worked tooth and nail to protect our country’s ideals, including through the introduction of the Statue of Liberty Values Act, which would rescind and defund the president’s ban, and co-sponsoring H.R. 804 to prevent people like Mr. Bannon from being assigned to the Council or attending its meetings. I will continue doing so in the months and years ahead. Thank you to those who contributed to this survey and to the thousands who continue to share your thoughts with me. If you would like regular updates on my work in Congress or to partake in my next survey, please visit: https://louise.house.gov/contact/louise-line-sign-up

I’ve been sounding the alarm about antibiotic resistance for years, and am pleased to learn that Tyson Foods plans to rid their name-brand chicken of antibiotics by June 2017. It is dangerous and unacceptable that 80% of all antibiotics used in the United States are used not on humans, but on food-animals - most of which are perfectly healthy. The unnecessary overuse of antibiotics for non-therapeutic reasons is a major contributor to the evolvement of antibiotic-resistant diseases that are threatening our health, with at least 23,000 deaths each year in the United States. To protect public health and prevent a nightmarish post-antibiotic future, I will continue advocating for the legislation I’ve written, the Preservation of Antibiotics for Medical Treatment Act!

In all my time in Congress, I have never seen an outpouring of public concern like this. My offices have been flooded with thousands of calls, with a 400% increase of calls to my Rochester office and a more than 600% increase to my Washington office since the start of the Trump Administration. I appreciate everyone who has called, emailed, or attended one of my recent events to make their voices heard. Whether it’s defending the Affordable Care Act or leading the effort in Congress to repeal and defund the President’s de facto Muslim ban, I will continue speaking out for Monroe County families. I appreciate everyone who is getting involved in the issues being debated in our nation's capital!

It was wonderful to tour the ongoing construction at the new Rochester Intermodal Train Station yesterday with our local construction crews and partners at Amtrak and the New York State Department of Transportation. This station will improve our ability to move goods and people efficiently and reinvigorate local neighborhoods. I am proud to have secured a highly competitive Transportation Investment Generating Economic Recovery (TIGER) grant to make this new station a reality and look forward to cutting the ribbon on this new facility later this year!

Yesterday, while touring the ongoing construction at the Rochester Intermodal Train Station, I spoke about why President Trump’s reversal of the prior administration’s rule protecting transgender students is a dangerous step backward. All students should feel safe at school, and you can count on me to continue fighting for all of our kids!

Under the Affordable Care Act, most individual and small employer health insurance plans, including all plans offered through the Health Insurance Marketplace, cover mental health services. Across the country, we can see the very real effects this expansion of coverage is having. Recently I heard from Eric, an inpatient psychiatric care provider in Rochester. Eric said that before the ACA, he was often faced with patients who had no health insurance and who he knew would be bankrupted by the cost of their care once bills from the hospital finally arrived. With the ACA, Eric saw improvements like fewer uninsured patients, better quality plans, and progression toward integrated and accountable health care systems. I will continue to lead the charge in Congress to protect this landmark legislation, so that millions of Americans can keep the quality care that they need! For more information on mental health care services under the ACA, please visit: https://www.mentalhealth.gov/get-help/health-insurance/

Tomorrow night, Jonathan Siegel of Brighton will be my guest at the president’s joint address to Congress. Recently, Jonathan told me how the Affordable Care Act provided affordable health care for his family and made it possible for him to start his own business. I’m still struck by his words about his wife of 30 years, who he said is the bravest person he knows. Jonathan’s wife battles multiple sclerosis, and has religiously taken the necessary shots for two decades while dealing with the uncertainties of this disease. Their story highlights what’s at stake with President Trump and Congressional Republicans’ dangerous agenda. When the president looks up into the gallery during his speech, I want him to see Jonathan. He is a reminder of the millions of families all across the country whose lives and livelihoods will be devastated if Republicans repeal health reform.

The hypocrisy of Congressional Republicans is overwhelming. This week, the House is considering a bill to undermine the ability of agencies to protect public health and safety under the guise of slashing so-called “costly regulations.” In reality, this is nothing more than at attempt to gut safeguards without any examination of their benefits. This is the same group that wasted millions of taxpayer dollars on partisan witch hunts like Benghazi! This bill, the SCRUB Act, is nothing more than an attempt to scrub vital protections that Americans depend on off the books.

Don’t miss this story in today’s D&C about Jonathan Siegel, my guest for the president’s address to Congress tonight. Jonathan and his family are a reminder of the millions of families nationwide who would be devastated by the president and Congressional Republicans’ dangerous plan to repeal the Affordable Care Act.

As Dean of the New York Congressional delegation, I invited my bipartisan colleagues from our great state to join me ahead of the president’s address to Congress. This is a tradition that I am proud to have started and am happy to continue. I’m looking forward to seeing all of them tonight!

Today I had the chance to speak with Jonathan Siegel before we attend the president’s address to Congress this evening. Jonathan and his wife of 30 years are two of the many reasons why I will never stop fighting to protect and preserve the Affordable Care Act. Jonathan’s story is one of hundreds I’ve received as a result of my campaign to hear directly from my constituents about the ACA. I’ve also heard from doctors, teachers, young students, and parents who have remarkable stories about the life-changing benefits this law has provided them. Your testimonies strengthen my resolve to fight for this landmark legislation and I thank you, as always, for your continued input.

The president’s address tonight was heavy on vague platitudes but light on specific policy. President Trump and Congressional Republicans have been using a seldom-used law, the Congressional Review Act, to eviscerate protections enacted by the prior president. They have already used this law to make it easier for coal companies to dump toxic waste in our waterways, roll back anti-corruption measures, and allow people with severe mental illnesses to purchase firearms. The president and Congressional Republicans are now trying to rip away health care from tens of millions of people and enact sweeping budget cuts that slash billions from domestic programs at the expense of workers and the poorest among us. Instead of supporting small businesses, President Trump’s plans prioritize large corporations. Rather than help our workers, the president is pursuing an agenda that helps billionaires. I will keep fighting to protect health care reform, Medicaid, and all programs that actually help working people. At the same time and for the good of our national security, I will also continue working tirelessly to hold President Trump and his administration accountable for their unprecedented financial conflicts of interest.

The president’s address to Congress last night failed to lay out a clear plan on how he will tackle the real issues facing our country. In spite of the ambiguities in his proposals, I will continue to advocate for legislation and initiatives that actually benefit working people!

As many of you know, the Trump Administration and Congressional Republicans have plans to eliminate the National Endowment for the Arts (NEA) and the National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH). That’s why this week I testified before my colleagues about the profound influences the arts have on our nation’s veterans as they cope with unspeakable tragedies through the unique partnership between the NEA and Department of Defense. Even the Second Lady of the United States, Karen Pence, is an adamant supporter of art therapy and has dedicated much of her career to this important cause. As Co-Chair of the Congressional Arts Caucus, I have tirelessly advocated for the arts and I will continue to fight to ensure that the president and Republican Congress do not slash spending for essential programs in order to pay for an agenda that rewards big corporations and wealthy individuals.

This Week: House Republicans Find Budget Rules too Inconvenient to Follow:     This week, the Republican-controlled Rules Committee brought two pieces of partisan legislation to the floor at a cost of $50 million.  Despite a lot of talk, it seems fiscal discipline is not a priority for Congressional Republicans.     Additionally, in order to bring these measures to the floor, House Republicans completely ignored the Congressional Budget Act and their own budget rules.    Cost Ignored: $20 Million   According to the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO), H.R. 1009, which undermines the independence and authority of federal agencies, will cost taxpayers $20 million dollars.  Yet the Rules Committee put on a legislative blindfold and ignored the cost.     Cost Ignored: $30 Million   The second bill this week, H.R. 998, puts corporate profits before the health and safety of the American public and will cost taxpayers $30 million dollars according to the CBO. Again, the Republican-controlled Rules Committee waived a magic money wand to ignore the cost.
