Congressional Republicans are apparently so afraid of the public’s reaction to their health care bill that they have taken the extraordinary step of literally hiding it behind lock and key somewhere on Capitol Hill. Many lawmakers were left today to go on a scavenger hunt just to try to track it down, yet they were unable to see a copy. Even many Republicans haven’t been able to view this bill as their leadership works behind closed doors to pass it quickly over the next few weeks without public scrutiny or proper debate. Millions of people nationwide have finally been able to access health care and millions more have seen substantially improved coverage under the Affordable Care Act. If Congressional Republicans are going to rip away this care, then the public deserves to know what they want to replace it with. Speaker Ryan, where’s the bill?

My heart breaks reading about the vandalism at the Waad Hakolel Cemetery in Rochester, just as it does reading about other recent anti-Semitic attacks around the country. That’s why I’m  urging the Department of Homeland Security and the Department of Justice to address the threats of violence that we’re seeing at Jewish Community Centers across the nation. This is a country-wide problem that our community is not immune to and it requires a national solution.

This week marks the start of Women’s History Month, when we honor the courageous women in our history who have organized, marched, and advanced the promise of equality. Rochester is home to many pioneering trailblazers including Susan B. Anthony, who helped lead the fight for women’s suffrage. As we celebrate the many victories that women have won, we must remember to never stop fighting for full equality. From guaranteeing equal pay for equal work to expanding funding opportunities for women in science and protecting a woman’s right to choose, I have and will always be a tireless advocate for women.

It was a busy week in Washington! From Rules Committee meetings and attending the president’s address to Congress with Rochester resident Jonathan Siegel to bringing together the New York State congressional delegation and meeting with over 25 mayors from around the country to discuss the importance of arts funding, I’ve covered a lot of ground working for you. I also had the chance to meet with representatives from WXXI to discuss the importance of public broadcasting and with a group of individuals from the University of Rochester’s Laboratory for Laser Energetics. In just a few minutes, I’ll be off to a photonics meeting now that I’m back in Rochester. Here’s looking forward to next week, when I’ll continue to advocate for the issues that matter most to all of you!

Jonathan’s story is one example of the devastating impact a repeal of the Affordable Care Act would have on millions of families across our nation. I will keep fighting against Republican plans to eviscerate this landmark law, so that families like Jonathan’s can continue to receive the care they need.

As Co-Chair of the bipartisan Great Lakes Taskforce, I’ve tirelessly advocated for our lakes, which are the largest source of drinking water on the planet and which 26 million Americans in our region rely on for commerce, transportation, and recreation. That’s why the Trump Administration’s threats to defund programs like the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative are so troubling. The GLRI supports necessary protections like cleaning up contaminated sediments, reducing polluted runoff, and mitigating habitat degradation and loss. We are the stewards of our Great Lakes, and I will not sit idly by as the president slashes funding for this critical initiative that protects our environment and helps bolster our local economy.

Today marks the third anniversary of the reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act, a landmark law that I originally co-authored in 1994. In the 23 years since this law was first enacted, the rate of domestic violence has dropped by 67 percent and there has been as much as a 51 percent increase in reporting rates for women and 37 percent for men. In 2013, this law was expanded to include life-saving provisions for Native American women, the LGTBQ community, immigrants, and students on college campuses. Authoring this legislation is one of the most important things I’ve done as a member of Congress, and I will continue to advance laws that protect survivors and prevent domestic violence before it begins.

According to recent statistics, 75 percent of skilled optics technician job openings in Upstate New York go unfilled because of a shortage in qualified candidates. That’s why I’m proud to stand with Monroe Community College president Anne Kress in pushing the current administration to invest more resources into advanced manufacturing training to expand the next generation’s workforce in optics and photonics, which will help our region and country can stay ahead of increased global competition. Our city is an international hub for optics and photonics and I will keep working to make sure that MCC students play a major role in continuing Rochester’s proud leadership in this important field!

I recently had the privilege of meeting with the Girl Scouts of Western New York. For a century, the sale of Girl Scout cookies has empowered generations of young women to invest in their community and become great leaders and entrepreneurs. I am so proud of the scouts I met this week. The determination and passion they show while participating in these cookie sales will undoubtedly help give them the confidence and skills they need to succeed later on in life. I also had the chance to sample some thin mints—my favorite!

Today is International Women’s Day and millions of people from across the country are striking to demonstrate the enormous impact women have on our economy. It’s estimated that if every working woman in America strikes today, it would cost our economy $21 billion in lost gross domestic product, with New York State alone losing $1.7 billion. Women comprise nearly half of the American workforce, and today we should all reflect on how important their labor is to this country and think about what we need to do to properly value their work, including passing legislation ensuring women finally earn equal pay for equal work.

I fought for 14 years to pass the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act so Americans no longer had to fear that their genetic information would be used against them. None of us were born with perfect genes, it affects us all. This law has allowed people to take advantage of the tremendous potential of genetic research without worrying that this information would cost them their job or their health care. It is even playing a leading role in ground-breaking cancer research. It is outrageous that Congressional Republicans are now trying to turn back the clock by undermining this law to make it easier for employers to access the medical and genetic testing information of employees and their families.

As Dean of the New York congressional delegation, I recently gathered my bipartisan colleagues to hear from our friend and partner Lieutenant Governor Kathy Hochul. It was a great discussion regarding some of the top challenges and opportunities facing our great state, including the impact of ACA repeal and the importance of transportation infrastructure. There is much work to be done. Many thanks to my colleagues and to the Lt. Governor for participating.

Yesterday, the White House said that the Republican health care plan would be debated under an open rule. That, “every member of the House and the Senate will be able to have their opportunity to have amendments offered, well through the committee process and on the floor.” We have not yet had an open rule under Speaker Ryan and we’re now in the midst of a record-setting pace of closed rules, which block all amendments on the House floor. I hope that Congressional Republicans follow through on what the White House promised yesterday and give the American people the transparent process they deserve.

Today on the House Floor, I spoke about a key provision under the Affordable Care Act that many people might be unfamiliar with but that’s preventing individuals from falling into bankruptcy while trying to pay for surging health care costs. The health care law’s ban on lifetime and annual limits has helped protect millions of families from having to decide between life-saving care and unsurmountable debt by capping how much insurance companies can charge you for care each year and over the course of your life. Before annual and lifetime limits, over 60% of bankruptcies in the United States were medical bankruptcies. The new Republican health care plan threatens affordable health care coverage and coverage for medical care that many patients with chronic conditions in particular need. These changes could impose drastic new costs on families or make coverage unaffordable all together.  That’s why I will continue to defend the ACA and this critical provision so that families across the country won’t have to live in fear of going broke just to get the health care they need.

I recently had the chance to meet with representatives from the University of Rochester, including president Joel Seligman. For more than 150 years, U of R has provided hundreds of thousands of young people with the education they need to get ahead in life. A good education really is the key that unlocks our nation’s full economic potential and the U of R is helping to play a major role by conducting cutting-edge research and preparing the next generation of workers in emerging fields like photonics and optics. Rochester is blessed to be home to many remarkable institutions like the U of R!

Congressional Republicans spoke again and again about repeal and replace for nearly seven years. All the while, they didn’t have a thing in the world to replace the health care law with. It wasn’t until this week that the Republicans finally let Members of Congress and the American people see their latest bill, and it would be a catastrophe for families across the country. People would be forced to pay more for worse coverage, if they could afford any coverage at all.

The Republicans’ disastrous health care bill would be devastating for millions of women across the country. Not only would their bill institute radical new restrictions on women’s rights to comprehensive health services, it would also defund Planned Parenthood, which more than 2.5 million people—men and women—depend on for life-saving preventative care services like cancer screenings and STI testing.

Congressional Republicans promised a health care plan that would benefit all Americans and yet their bill does just the opposite, ripping coverage from hardworking people and eliminating Medicaid expansion. All while giving tax breaks to the wealthiest Americans.  Seventy million people across our nation, most notably seniors with long-term care needs, Americans with disabilities, and pregnant women, rely on Medicaid for the care they deserve. I am outraged by the Republicans’ decision to put the health of our country’s most vulnerable populations at risk, and I will continue doing my part to oppose this awful bill.

Many of you have recently called my offices looking for more information about how the Republicans’ health care plan could impact you and your family. Here’s more information about the plan, which shows just how devastating it could be for millions of Americans. That’s why I will continue fighting to preserve and improve the Affordable Care Act, instead of pushing this bill that would limit choice and increase costs.

This week marks National Sunshine Week, when we focus on government accountability and openness. From introducing the Political Intelligence Transparency Act and the Supreme Court Ethics Act to authoring the Stop Trading on Congressional Knowledge (STOCK) Act, I have tirelessly advocated to ensure that your government is held to the highest ethical standards. As far as I’m concerned, National Sunshine Week should be every week. Elected officials must uphold the trust of the people they represent, and I will continue to advance legislation that advances this ideal.

Republicans in Washington should be working to protect their constituents, not eviscerating the care that they depend on to stay healthy. For almost a century, employer-based health insurance has been a hallmark of the U.S. economy and a stabilizing force for the individual market. Under the Republican health care plan, employer-sponsored coverage would be eroded, causing more than 177 million Americans—more than half of the population— to lose critical protections like annual and lifetime caps, coverage of preexisting conditions, and required coverage of widely needed health care. In Rochester alone, 414,800 are at risk of losing protections under their employer-sponsored health insurance.  This is simply unconscionable. For too long, insurance companies would charge healthy people increasing premiums and then turn around and deny them care when they actually became sick. We can’t afford to go back to those days.

Under the Republican health care plan, millions of Americans across the country will be forced to pay more for less coverage, if they can afford that coverage at all. According to a recent report, the uninsured rate in Monroe County has dropped to 4.3 percent since the Affordable Care Act was enacted. Everyone who has gained coverage under this landmark law would risk losing that coverage If the ACA was repealed. This is shameful and, sadly, it only gets worse. I’m so proud to receive perfect ratings from the Defenders of Wildlife, a critical organization that protects imperiled habitats and wildlife around the country, and the League of Conservation Voters, which works to make environmental issues a national priority. I have always been an adamant supporter of the environment. In fact, saving the woods near my home in Fairport was my original inspiration for getting involved in the political process. From leading the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative to fighting new attempts by Congressional Republicans and corporations to roll back environmental safeguards, I won’t stop working to protect lands, wildlife, the air we breathe, and the water we drink.

As the only microbiologist in Congress, I am proud today to introduce the Preservation of Antibiotics for Medical Treatment Act (PAMTA), which would help prevent a nightmarish post-antibiotic future. This year marks the fortieth year since the U.S. Food and Drug Administration first acknowledged the dire threat of antibiotic-resistance and called for a reduction in the use of antibiotics in animals. Although I have been sounding the alarm for years, many leaders have failed to take this threat seriously. All the while, the consequences have continued to grow, with the discovery last year of an antibiotic-resistant superbug in the United States that couldn’t be killed by any known drug. It is beyond time for meaningful action to protect the public health and stop this in its tracks. We must break the stranglehold the pharmaceutical industry and corporate agriculture have on our public health policy and finally pass this bill.

I am pleased that U.S. District Court Judge Watson of Hawaii and others from around the country have blocked the president’s latest Muslim ban from taking effect. The president’s claim that these rulings make our country look “weak” is shameful and does a disservice to the separation of powers enshrined in our Constitution. On the contrary, this ban would have made us less safe by giving groups like ISIS fodder to recruit new members. No immigrants from any of the six countries listed in the president’s latest ban have ever killed an American in a U.S. terrorist attack. I will continue to fight tooth and nail against the president’s dangerous order.

This is the most draconian, ill-conceived, and harmful budget I have ever seen in all my time in Congress. President Trump is proposing cuts that would decimate programs the American people rely on in order to pay for the wall with Mexico and what he calls the biggest military buildup in history. This request would be devastating for Monroe County through its proposed elimination of the TIGER programs that are helping fund construction of our new train station, and the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program that is keeping the heat on for many families during a particularly tough winter. I’m also concerned about his deep cuts to Pell Grants, clean air and water, and the State Department. His elimination of federal arts programs would also be a major setback for servicemen and women as they use the arts to confront the wounds of war. Far from fighting for the American worker, this request would leave them behind by slashing the programs they need the most.

Despite their claims to the contrary, the Majority’s health care plan follows the typical Washington Republican playbook of favoring wealthy people and corporations, providing nearly $1 trillion in tax breaks to health insurers and pharmaceutical companies while skyrocketing the cost of health care for middle and working class families across the country. According to the nonpartisan CBO, a 64-year-old making roughly $26,500 annually would see premiums rise from $1,700 annually under the Affordable Care Act to $14,600 under the Republicans’ proposal. That’s half of their yearly income! What’s more, the AARP estimates that premiums could go up by as much as $8,400 for a 64-year-old who makes less than $20,000 under the Republican plan. We cannot let President Trump and Congressional Republicans punish the sick and elderly just so that they can fulfill their partisan agenda while giving special interests a nearly trillion dollar tax break.

Antibiotic-resistant infections are one of the greatest threats to our global health. A recent report estimates that by 2050, one person could die of an antibiotic-resistant infection every three seconds. This is unconscionable and that’s why I’ve sounded the alarm against this threat for years, including introducing the Preservation of Antibiotics for Medical Treatment Act (PAMTA). I’m proud to announce that an investigation I called for by the General Accounting Office (GAO) was recently released and that it identified several actions needed to prevent the continued misuse of antibiotics, including better collaboration between the U.S. Department of Agriculture and the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. I’ve already written to these agencies to make sure these crucial changes are being made and I will continue to make my voice heard on this important issue!

Today marks Arts Advocacy Day, a time when hundreds of activists from around the country gather in our nation’s capital to discuss the importance of federal arts programs. With the president’s proposed elimination of the National Endowment for the Arts (NEA) and the National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH), it is now more important than ever that we work to defend federal arts programs. As my editorial in The Hill makes clear, the arts are invaluable in supporting students, veterans, and our economy. For every federal dollar that is invested in the arts, nine non-federal dollars are leveraged, generating $600 million in matching support. As Co-Chair of the Congressional Arts Caucus, I have always and will always advocate for and protect arts programs that are essential to creating jobs and boosting our economy!

I strongly oppose the backroom deal announced late last night by Chris Collins that was added to the Republican health care repeal bill. It is a gimmick, and nothing more than pure political cover for wavering New York Republicans that know the Republican healthcare plan would devastate our state, especially upstate rural areas. The overall Medicaid plan would cost New Yorkers billions of dollars of lost federal funds and jeopardize hospital stability. Shifting the local cost share to the state is a political sleight of hand – if Republicans steal billions from New York to pay for tax cuts for the wealthy it doesn’t matter if taxpayers have to cover the cost at the county or the state level. Either way, Congressional Republicans are proposing New Yorkers pay for their terrible plan, and with this amendment, they would be sending our state a $4.7 billion bill. If Rep. Collins thinks that’s a good deal, he’s not a very good businessman or representative for our state.

As a member of the House of Representatives, I do not vote on Supreme Court nominees, but I have been closely monitoring Judge Gorsuch’s hearings. I’ve written to my colleagues on the Senate Judiciary Committee and asked them to question Judge Gorsuch on whether he supports requiring the Supreme Court to adopt a binding code of ethics. This is an issue I’ve been raising for years and have taken action on by introducing the Supreme Court Ethics Act, which would ensure impartiality and require justices to adopt the ethical rules imposed on all other federal judges across the nation. I will continue to advance this legislation so that the American people can be sure that the Supreme Court is held to the highest ethical standards.

Under the Republican health care bill, 24 million Americans are estimated to lose coverage in the next ten years. Disproportionally affected are Americans with disabilities, who would see devastating impacts to their coverage. The Republican proposal’s changes to the Medicaid program, including the elimination of Medicaid expansion efforts, would be disastrous for members of our community with intellectual and developmental disabilities. Medicaid is the primary source of health insurance and long-term support for 10 million non-elderly people with significant disabilities, helping thousands of individuals with disabilities live and work in their communities. Changes to the Medicaid program currently being proposed by Republicans risk the rights of individuals with disabilities to live freely and independently and receive quality health care services. This is shameful. Republicans should be working to fix our crumbling infrastructure and reinvigorate our schools, not eliminating care for people who need it the most.

Today marks the seventh anniversary of the signing of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), which has helped provide high-quality, affordable insurance to more than 20 million people who were previously uninsured. Just as important, the ACA ensured that all of us who purchase health insurance are entitled to the same essential care through our plans rather than having insurance companies point to the fine print when it comes to our basic healthcare needs. The impact on New Yorkers alone has been overwhelming: an estimated 147,000 young adults have been able to stay on their parents’ plan up to age 26; more than 6 million people are no longer limited by annual and lifetime caps, and more than 8 million Americans have gained access to preventative care like flu shots and cancer screenings at zero cost. What’s more, our nation’s uninsured rate is now at its lowest level in more than 50 years. Instead of working to strengthen and improve this landmark law, Congressional Republicans are trying to bring their repeal bill to the floor for a vote as early as this afternoon. Decimating the ACA and the protections it has delivered to all Americans is a huge mistake. Doing so to facilitate a nearly trillion dollar tax break for the wealthy, health insurance companies and medical device manufacturers is unconscionable. I will continue to voice my strong opposition.
In case you missed it, today The New York Times highlighted how the Republican health care bill would follow their typical practice of favoring the wealthy over our workers. Despicable.

Since December, I’ve asked families from around Monroe County to submit their story about how the Affordable Care Act (ACA) has expanded and improved their coverage. Yesterday afternoon, I delivered those stories to Speaker Ryan. Since then, I received several dozen more stories from physicians, nurses, mental health care providers, and seniors living off Medicaid worried about the fate of their health coverage under the Republican plan. Deborah, a family care physician from Rochester, told me that because of the ACA she has seen an increase in parents being able to afford essential services for their families. Ellen, a licensed clinical social worker, told me that the ACA has allowed dozens of her patients to receive quality mental health services for the first time. It is inconceivable to me that, despite millions of concerned Americans, Republicans in Congress are still pushing ahead to get their dangerous bill to the floor. Like many of you who wrote in, I am strongly opposed to Congressional Republicans’ plan and will continue to resist it.

It should say something about the quality of the Republican repeal bill that organizations like America's Essential Hospitals and Children's Hospital Association (CHA), who represent nearly 500 hospitals combined, are still opposed. Just yesterday, the CHA said that even with the latest changes to the Republican bill, it still “continues to fail over 30 million kids, including over a million disabled children, who receive their health coverage through Medicaid.” CHA even went on to say that this bill is a “national threat” to children’s health care. How many more public health organizations, hospitals, doctors, and nurses must come out against this before they abandon this awful bill?

One of the most important moments of my time in Congress was bringing the Affordable Care Act (ACA) to the floor of the House of Representatives as Chairwoman of the Rules Committee. The health care law was written in consultation with medical experts and healthcare advocates over months of public hearings and has insured 20 million Americans while improving coverage for all of us. Though the Republicans had seven years to offer an alternative, they only showed the American people their latest half-baked repeal bill a few hours ago and are now taking it to the floor. This dangerous plan was written to fulfill a political promise that will strip coverage from 24 million Americans. It is despicable and I continue to oppose it.

From the AARP and the American Medical Association (AMA) to the American Nurses Association and the National Physicians Alliance, the list of those opposed to the Republican repeal bill just keeps growing. The Majority is also failing to gather enough support within their own party because members of both parties know this bill will devastate millions of hard working Americans in order to give a nearly trillion dollar tax cut to the wealthy and corporations. The calls and emails into my office show just how opposed the majority of Americans are to this bill. To what length is Republican leadership willing to go to try and jam this bill through the House? I will be a strong vote against it!

It turns out that the president who wrote the book on deal making couldn’t close this deal. This decision is a win for the American people, who would have been devastated by this bill. Twenty-four million people would have been pushed off their health insurance, families would have had to pay higher premiums and deductibles, and those aged 50 to 64 would have faced a crushing age tax, paying five times more for premiums. This legislation would have also killed the requirement for insurance companies to offer Essential Health Benefits, including emergency services, maternity care, and prescription drugs. All the while, it would steal from Medicare, shorten the life of the Medicare Trust Fund and ransack the funds that seniors depend on for care.   House Republicans tried to jam this bill through the House without holding a single hearing, without waiting for a nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office analysis, and by bringing this bill to the floor just hours after releasing the final text late last night. A bad process begets a bad product – and both this process and this product could not have been worse. This bill deserves not only to be pulled from the floor today - it should be scrapped once and for all.

House Republicans’ decision to pull their disastrous repeal bill from the floor on Friday was a major victory for the American people. I am proud to have stood with the hundreds of you who called and emailed in opposition to this dangerous bill. It is my hope that Republicans will now turn their attention to improving and expanding the Affordable Care Act (ACA) and I will work with anybody who is serious about making this landmark law work even better for people in Monroe County and across the country.

For nearly a decade, Congressional Republicans have been focused on putting up roadblocks to progress rather than putting forward policies that help the American people. This startling admission from my Republican colleague after their failed repeal bill reveals what many of us already knew, that Republicans in Washington may be good at political campaigns, but they don’t know how to govern and get things done. I’m ready to work with any Republican or Democrat who is advancing policies that help my constituents and the American people. I’ve been vocal in both my support and opposition for the president’s policies on everything from trade to health care, but I will not give an inch if President Trump and House Republicans continue to propose dangerous legislation that takes our country backward.

While Congressional Republicans were trying to jam their dangerous ACA repeal bill through the House, the State Department was clearing the way for the president to approve construction of the Keystone XL tar sands pipeline, which would transmit some of the dirtiest oil on the planet and add carbon pollution into the atmosphere that is the equivalent of putting 5.5 million cars on the road. This is outrageous and what’s worse, nearly half of the steel used in construction will be manufactured outside of the United States. This is all for a project that will generate a grand total of 35 permanent jobs. It’s just not worth it. I will continue to fight for a sustainable clean energy future that protects the health of the American people and positions our country to lead the world in energy innovation.

Today President Trump will sign an executive order that dismantles landmark environmental safeguards put in place by the former administration to combat climate change. Although the president’s sweeping order is billed as a measure to promote “energy independence,”  the United States has already been moving in this direction for years. In fact, for the first time in over two decades, our country has produced more oil here at home than we have purchased from the rest of the world. The president’s order will reverse the progress we’ve been making to take on climate change while deepening our dependence on dirty fuels that contribute to pollution and illness. Like the hundreds of you who have written, called, and emailed, I’m deeply concerned by the president’s environmental agenda. I will continue speaking out and pushing for policies that are good for our environment and our economy. Clean energy jobs are being created and I want them to be created right here at home, not overseas in countries like China.

Today, many across our nation are standing with Planned Parenthood against efforts by Republicans in Congress and the Trump Administration to defund it. I was proud to stand against the Republican health care repeal bill last week, which would have defunded Planned Parenthood and prevented the 2.5 million men and women it services each year from receiving the care that they need. It is shameful that Republicans in Washington are continuously trying to defund this organization and put the cancer screenings, STI testing, and other health services it provides out-of-reach for so many. Today and every day, I will continue fighting to protect Planned Parenthood and the important care it provides for many across our country.

According to recent media reports, the House Intelligence Committee’s investigation into the Trump Administration’s ties to Russia have been put on an indefinite hold. Let me be clear: this is no time to stop investigations. What seems like every single day, news continues to break on this matter, from the scandals surrounding Attorney General Sessions or former National Security Advisor Michael Flynn or the fact that Trump still refuses to release his tax returns. Now more than ever, we need a thorough investigation into what exactly is going on behind closed doors in Trump’s White House. I’ve called for a bipartisan, 9/11 style investigation to examine this matter and it’s obvious that this is the right call, especially given the Chairman Nunes recent actions. The American people deserve openness and transparency, something this president has consistently failed to deliver.

I enjoyed reading today’s editorial in the Democrat and Chronicle, which highlights how invaluable the arts are to every sector of our society.  While the current administration plows ahead with its plans to eliminate the National Endowment for the Arts(NEA) and the National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH), I will continue fighting to protect these agencies, which enrich the lives of thousands right here in Monroe County and across the country.

This week, the Trump Administration announced that LGBTQ Americans would not be counted as a group in the 2020 Census. With this move, the president is literally saying that LGBTQ people do not count. By taking this step, the Trump Administration has proved it doesn’t even want the information necessary to govern in the best interest of thousands of American families. If the president doesn’t know how many LGBTQ people live in a community, how can he ensure that those individuals are getting access to the care, protections, and rights that they, as Americans, are entitled to? In response, I will be sending a letter to the Director of the Census Bureau John Thompson and Director of the Office of Management and Budget Mick Mulvaney to express my disapproval with this short-sighted decision. While this administration may cherry-pick which families count and which do not, I will continue to advocate on behalf of all my constituents.

My very best wishes to Todd Baxter, a dedicated public servant who has spent his career serving others.  From his service in the Army, through his time in the Rochester Police Department, to his distinguished tenure as Greece Chief of Police and his leadership as Director of the Veterans Outreach Center, Todd has devoted himself to making our country and our community a better place. In his current role, Todd has expanded the services at the VOC to include Priscilla's House, a home for female veterans and their children, ensured that countless homeless veterans have access to housing, and worked to ensure that those who fight for our country don’t have to fight for a job when they come home. I’ve been a proud friend of Todd’s for a long time, including standing with him in improving psychiatric and medical care for our veterans in Monroe County. Thank you, Todd!

CBS News has highlighted that it costs the taxpayers an estimated $24 million per week to run the House of Representatives. Here’s how Congressional Republicans chose to spend your tax dollars this week.

I was the first Member of Congress to call on the Securities and Exchange Commission to investigate now-Secretary Tom Price’s questionable history of stock trades. This recent report is the latest indication that Secretary Price likely violated the spirit, and quite possibly the letter, of the STOCK Act, a bill that I wrote and worked for six years to pass into law. We cannot let these questions go unanswered just because the Republican-led Senate rushed this nomination through on a party-line vote. I will continue fighting for answers to make sure that elected officials like Secretary Price uphold the public’s trust.

This week marks National Public Health Week. One issue I’ve spent decades fighting for is reducing lead paint exposure, which can impact any American living or working in older buildings across the country. For children, lead paint exposure is especially dangerous, contributing to behavioral and learning problems, hyperactivity, slowed growth, hearing problems, and anemia. I’ve been sounding the alarm for years and fighting for funding for lead poisoning prevention programs while introducing legislation that would require the CDC broaden the categories of those eligible to receive lead hazard abatement grants. Lead exposure is a national epidemic and I will continue to advocate for prevention and removal initiatives and the infrastructure upgrades necessary to keep our children and communities safe.

Today on the floor, the House will vote on H.R. 1343, the Encouraging Employee Ownership Act of 2017, bipartisan legislation that would finally update a 1988 rule and allow businesses like Wegmans  to offer their employees stock ownership in their companies. This is a commonsense bill, which is why I’m proud to stand with Wegmans to help them support their more than 24,000 workers in New York State. This company has been a part of our community for more than 100 years and that’s why I will continue to advocate for smart legislation like H.R. 1343, which help employees and businesses like Wegmans thrive!

Today marks Equal Pay Day, when more than three months into the year, women’s wages finally catch up to what men were paid in the previous year. Although New York State has the lowest gender wage gap in the country, women across our state are still being shortchanged in their paychecks. In New York, white women earn only 81 cents to every dollar earned by men. What’s worse, African American women and Latinas earn only 69 cents and 58 cents respectively for every male dollar earned. It has been nearly 54 years since President John F. Kennedy signed the Equal Pay Act into law but widespread pay inequity still runs rampant throughout our country. When a woman is paid less than a man for doing the same work, it cheats her entire family. It’s past time to ensure true equality for working women by finally passing the Paycheck Fairness Act, which would improve and expand the Equal Pay Act.

Today marks the fifth anniversary of the STOCK Act, a law I wrote that bans insider trading by federal officials, being signed into law. The American people should feel confident that leaders representing them are acting in the best interests of the public, and not in the best interests of their personal bank accounts. That’s why I spent six years fighting to get my bill signed into law. It is because of the STOCK Act’s disclosure requirements that questionable stock trades by the Secretary of Health and Human Services recently came to light. I believe this law will also be one of our best opportunities for holding President Trump accountable in the years ahead as well. I’m proud of the great importance this law has taken on today, and I will continue fighting for the transparency and accountability the American people deserve.

We are half way through National Public Health Week! As the only microbiologist in Congress, I have fought long and hard to improve the quality of our food including introducing the Preservation of Antibiotics for Medical Treatment Act (PAMTA) because American citizens should not have to worry that the food on their table is going to make them sick. This is one of the most pressing public health issues of our time. A recent report estimates that by 2050, one person could die of an antibiotic-resistant infection every three seconds. Antibiotic resistance already kills more people than HIV/AIDS. Following the lead of companies like Chipotle and Panera, McDonalds and Subway have recently made commitments to improving food safety. Although this is encouraging, more meaningful action must be taken to end the stranglehold corporate agriculture has on our public health.

Like so many of you, I was outraged when the president signed an executive order giving his chief political strategist, Steve Bannon, a seat on the National Security Council. Mr. Bannon has disturbing ties to the White Nationalist Movement and a history of repeatedly and aggressively pushing stories that promote anti-Semitism, xenophobia, and racism. Elevating him to a position that is usually reserved for military generals and experienced security professionals was outrageous. Today’s announcement regarding his removal from the NSC is a positive development, but it does not go far enough. He shouldn’t be anywhere near the White House.

An overwhelming number of House Republicans voted last week to allow internet service providers to sell your private browsing history without your consent. And now today, every Republican member of the House voted to hide President Trump’s tax returns from the American people. This double standard is breathtaking. Congressional Republicans are enabling this president’s unprecedented secrecy while selling your private data to the highest bidder. Questions are continuing to mount about this administration’s ties to Russia and the public deserves answers. House Republicans should stop standing in the way of our efforts to make the president fulfill his promise to the American people of finally releasing his tax returns. Mr. President, what are you trying to hide?

Today I am proud to stand with Chris Murphy in introducing our bill, the Supreme Court Ethics Act. As the final arbiter of justice in this country, the integrity of Supreme Court justices must be beyond reproach. This legislation will help restore the public’s trust by requiring the Supreme Court to adopt a binding Code of Conduct just like the law already demands of every other federal judge in America. Many Supreme Court nominees have been federal judges who already are subject to a code of conduct, and there’s no reason they should be held less accountable as a member of our nation’s highest court. I thank Senator Murphy for his continued leadership on this, and I hope we can finally make this common sense legislation the law of the land!

While today marks the last day of National Public Health Week, I will continue to fight to promote policies and advance legislation that reduces childhood exposure to lead paint, the spread of antibiotic resistance, and protects the health and wellness of all Americans. Over my time in Congress, I have fought hard for these causes and my resolve remains strong. I will continue to make my voice heard on these critical issues because fighting for improved public health ensures that every American citizen can live in a healthier and safer world!

CBS News has highlighted that it costs the taxpayers an estimated $24 million per week to run the House of Representatives. Here’s how Congressional Republicans chose to spend your tax dollars this week.

We’re almost through National Public Health Week! One issue that I’ve been passionate about throughout my time in Congress is protecting all Americans’ privacy rights, including health privacy. For 14 years, seven Congresses, and three administrations, I fought to the pass the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act (GINA) which allowed Americans to keep their genetic information and their family members’ genetic information private from employers and health insurance companies. Now, Congressional Republicans are promoting a bill that would coerce employees to reveal their genetic information, or face the loss of health care benefits. Undermining GINA is about as unethical as it gets, and I will continue to fight against dangerous policies that take advantage of employees and their families.

Bashar al-Assad’s ongoing atrocities against his own people are an affront to the civilized world. These crimes have often been abetted by Vladimir Putin and the Russian regime. The missile strikes ordered by President Trump appear to be a proportionate response to Assad’s barbaric use of chemical weapons against innocent civilians. Regardless of where you stand on these strikes, there is no question that President Trump must come before Congress and seek an Authorization for Use of Military Force before any escalation of this conflict. After more than a decade of occupying two countries, we must not enter into another open-ended conflict abroad. The American people and especially our brave men and women in uniform deserve to hear a concrete strategy from this administration.
Here’s the response from the Congressional Progressive Caucus to the U.S. missile strikes on Syria. I’m proud to be a member.
To everyone in Rochester and around the country celebrating Passover tonight, I wish you a Chag Sameach!

Today I am proud to stand with my colleagues in urging Secretary of State Rex Tillerson to reverse the Trump Administration’s decision to eliminate funding for the United Nations Population Fund. The UNFPA supports a range of critical programs in more than 150 countries that focus on safe birthing practices, anti-human trafficking initiatives, and ending child marriage. What’s more, the UNFPA also delivers life-saving services to women and girls in war zones and refugee camps. I’ve been a proud supporter of the UNFPA’s work for years, including advocating for its increased funding. Beyond the life-saving impact of this program for millions of people, the UNFPA also helps ensure that the United States remains a global leader in humanitarian assistance. Eliminating this funding would be a disaster and I will continue to do all I can to see this funding restored.

Our country’s more than 400 national parks, monuments, battlefields, and coastlines welcomed over 330 million visitors in 2016, an increase of 23 million from 2015 alone. Despite this influx, the president placed a hiring freeze on the Department of Interior and cut its budget by 12 percent, an $11.6 billion slash. The Trump Administration is trying to make political hay out of the president’s recent donation of $78,333 to the National Park Service, which is his first-quarter salary. With this donation, the president is suggesting how important our National Parks are while working silently to decimate their budget. The hypocrisy is unprecedented. We are the stewards of our parks, Great Lakes, monuments and coastlines and we should be working to protect these natural treasures, not eliminate the investments that make them thrive.

Calling all young artists! High school students from New York’s 25th district are encouraged to submit their artwork to the Memorial Art Gallery for the annual Congressional Arts Competition. I’m always so impressed by the skill and talent showcased every year by students across Western New York and I encourage all students to submit their art. Whether it’s a painting you are especially proud of or a picture you took and framed, the Congressional Arts Competition is for you. It is an incredible opportunity to have your work showcased in the halls of Congress! For more information on the competition, please visit my site.

Today marks the first 100 hundred days of the 115th Congress. It’s been a busy few months in Congress working for you! From introducing and co-sponsoring over 150 pieces of legislation, welcoming over 330 Rochesterians to Washington, and sending more than 940,000 email updates, I have worked hard to stay in touch and advocate for the issues that matter most to our district. I’ve said it often: the most important part of my job is hearing from the people that I serve. So, I want to hear from you—what ideas do you have to strengthen our community in the next 100 days?

Today’s front-page story in the Democrat and Chronicle really hit the nail on the head. It’s the height of hypocrisy that the president ran his campaign on improving infrastructure and now has decided to take an ax to it. Investing in rail has a ripple effect across our national and local economy, with every dollar spent generating roughly $4 in return. We cannot allow the rest of the world to continue speeding past the United States on infrastructure development and investment. That’s why I’ll continue to lead efforts in Congress to reverse the president’s devastating proposal and fully fund programs like Amtrak, TIGER grants, and new mass transit projects.

Happy Throwback Thursday! For fourteen years, seven congresses, and three administrations I fought hard to pass the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act (GINA), a law that I authored which prohibits health insurers and employers from using your genetic information to discriminate against you. Before GINA was enacted, an employer could refuse to hire or even fire someone with a family history of breast cancer or other hereditary illnesses. Thanks to this law, this is no longer the case. With these protections in place, we’ve seen genetic research blossom bringing us breakthroughs and the promise of much more. But despite the progress we’ve seen under GINA, Congressional Republicans are now promoting a bill that would force employees to reveal their genetic information or face the loss of their health care benefits. Undermining GINA and taking advantage of employees and their families is as unethical as it gets. Instead of stripping Americans of their personal privacy rights, Congressional Republicans should be working to fix our crumbling infrastructure and avert the looming government shutdown.

Over and over again throughout his campaign, the president declared that he alone could fix the trade deficit, even promising to renegotiate NAFTA his first day in office. It’s been nearly 100 days and this still has not happened. This would be comical if it were not for the millions of hard-working people the president convinced, people who are now left to wonder what he will do to improve the economy and secure American jobs. Real lives and real jobs on the line. In an attempt to console the public, the president recently signed two executive orders on trade. Both were ill-conceived, insufficient, and would not solve our trade woes. What’s more, his draft NAFTA renegotiation plan would make the trade deal worse for average Americans in a number of ways. The president has the obligation to act on his assurances and not follow his typical playbook of loud, empty promises and zero follow-through. President Trump, what’s the plan?

Congratulations to General Motors (GM) for being named a 2017 Environmental Protection Agency Energy Star Partner of the Year for the sixth consecutive year. For nearly 80 years, Rochester’s GM plant and their dedicated employees have been on the cutting edge of the latest automotive technologies while helping maintain over 1,000 jobs in our district alone. Rochester’s GM facility is leading the way in energy efficiency. The Rochester plant is certified landfill-free, which means it reuses, recycles, or converts to energy all waste products from daily operations. And just last year they invested $1 million in solar panels. I stand with American workers and businesses who are working to set a national example for environmentally safe and innovative practices. I’m proud that Rochester is home to this facility and congratulate them on their tremendous achievement!

For three Congresses I’ve been pushing the Supreme Court Ethics Act, my bill to finally require Supreme Court justices to adopt a binding code of conduct similar to what every other federal judge in the country already has to follow. Sadly, some justices in recent years have participated in political events and failed to disclose potential conflicts of interest, undermining public confidence in the institution. The Supreme Court Ethics Act would go a long way to restore confidence in the justices’ impartiality and restore the public’s trust. That’s why I will continue to advance and fight for this important legislation.

Good luck to Brighton’s Marie Boudreau-Ninkov and Fairport’s Onni Peck as they make Boston Marathon history today! Marie and Onni are the first female duo to physically qualify and participate in the Boston Marathon as a team. But today won’t be their first marathon, they’ve already run two together in the last eighteen months. They’re even calling today’s race their “victory lap.” Rochester is rooting for you, Onni and Marie. Way to go!

President Trump’s proposal to eliminate funding for long-distance Amtrak trains would only hurt our national and local economy. Last year alone, 43,000 people traveled on the Lake Shore Limited service out of Rochester. Not to mention, this proposed cut flies in the face of the president’s campaign promises to improve infrastructure. It is outrageous that the president continues to push for this slashed funding all the while using taxpayer dollars to fly back and forth to his own hotel practically every week. This kind of hypocrisy is why so many across the country are angry with Republicans in Washington. I will continue to lead the effort in Congress against these proposed cuts so we can properly fund our infrastructure development while helping grow our economy.

Millions of Americans across the country are filing their taxes today, which is a timely reminder that President Trump still refuses to fulfill his promise to release his tax returns. President Trump is no ordinary citizen and is now the first president in modern history to refuse to release his returns. This, along with Congressional Republicans voting six times against requiring the president to release his returns, has kept the American people deliberately in the dark. The public deserves an open and transparent government, not one that facilitates backroom deals and personal financial rewards. In the spirit of tax day, I once again call on President Trump to release his tax returns so the American people can finally get the answers that they were promised and deserve. Mr. President, what are you trying to hide?

This week marks National Park Week, a time when we celebrate the importance of the more than 400 parks, monuments, battlefields, and coastlines in our country. My family has always loved visiting our parks and I know countless others do, too. Sadly, not everyone recognizes this value. That’s why I oppose the administration’s proposal to slash the Department of the Interior’s budget in order to help pay for a $54 billion increase in defense spending. So much is at stake for our environment under the Trump Administration and that’s why it’s critical we strengthen our resolve to defend our natural treasures. Protecting our environment isn’t just good for our land and a part of our history, it’s also good for our health and our economy. Celebrate National Park Week by visiting a park with your family!

The president’s draconian budget calls for a $54 billion cut to domestic priorities, including critical scientific research, to afford what he calls the biggest military buildup in our nation’s history. These cuts would decimate funding for important research happening across the country and especially at the University of Rochester, where 72 percent of their research budget comes from federal funds. The University of Rochester is leading the way in groundbreaking work in fields like photonics and optics and eviscerating their financial support would be devastating to these efforts. Instead of slashing funding for research priorities and wreaking havoc on the scientific community, the president should be focused on fulfilling campaign promises like investing in infrastructure and improving our trade policies. I’ve been outspoken against the president’s proposed budget and will continue to ensure that this dangerous plan never becomes a reality.

The American people deserve an open and transparent government. That’s the bottom line. In refusing to release White House visitor logs, President Trump is deliberately keeping the public in the dark. We should know who has the power to influence the highest ranks of our government and in keeping the logs secret, the president is doing just the opposite. Backroom deals might’ve been the standard during Trump’s business career, but that approach doesn’t work anymore. Mr. President, it’s past time for you to practice transparency. The American public deserves nothing less.

The president has spent seven of the last 13 weekends at his Mar-a-Largo resort in Palm Beach. In one year, President Trump will spend more taxpayer money on travel than the prior administration did in eight. This is after spending years criticizing the Obama administration’s travel. We’re nearing the first 100 days of this presidency and President Trump is still failing to fulfill major promises like proposing a plan to fix our nation’s crumbling infrastructure and fixing bad trade deals that hurt our workers. There are real people, real jobs, and real issues at stake. Mr. President, it’s time to focus on governing.

Happy Earth Day! Today is an opportunity to remind ourselves and our neighbors that we have one precious planet that we must protect and preserve for future generations. People all across the country and across Rochester are gathering in solidarity today to stress the importance of science at such a critical time for our nation and our planet. Under the Trump Administration, science and facts are under siege. That’s why it’s so important that we stand up for science and act as good stewards of our lakes, mountains, rivers, and valleys. I’m a proud advocate for our environment. In fact, saving the woods near my home in Fairport was my inspiration for first getting involved in politics. My resolve hasn’t changed and I will continue to fight against every attempt to rip away the progress we’ve made in protecting our planet.

This week was Supreme Court Justice Neil Gorsuch’s first week hearing cases on the Court. Unlike two weeks ago when he was an appeals court judge, Justice Gorsuch is no longer bound by a code of ethics. Supreme Court justices should be more accountable, not less. That’s why I recently introduced the Supreme Court Ethics Act, because I believe our justices must be held to the same standards as every other federal judge in the country. Questionable actions by our justices in recent years have undermined the American people’s confidence in our Court and contributed to historically high disapproval ratings. Justices have participated in partisan political events, failed to disclose potential conflicts of interest, and attended events sponsored by high-profile political donors. Enough is enough. The final arbiters of justice in our country must uphold the public’s trust. My bill is the first step to ensuring that this happens.

Calling all high school artists! This is your last week to submit artwork for the 35th annual Congressional Arts Competition, which ends this Saturday, April 29. This competition is an opportunity for high school students across New York’s 25th district to test their artistic abilities and demonstrate their skills for a panel of local experts from the Memorial Art Gallery of the University of Rochester's Creative Workshop. I’m always so impressed by the talent showcased every year and I encourage all young artists from across Western New York to submit their work. Winning artists will even have their work hung in the halls of Congress! For more information on the competition, please visit my site.

We’re nearing the first 100 days of the Trump Administration and still the president and the Republican-led Congress have little to show for it. From introducing a dangerous and failed health care repeal bill and rolling back internet privacy protections, this has been a deeply troubling start. Under Speaker Ryan’s leadership, we’ve hit a record-setting pace of closed rules, with the Republican Majority already on their way to breaking the all-time record. This lack of transparency is preventing the American people from getting the debates they deserve. It’s no surprise that so many Republicans in Congress have been speaking out. During his opening address to the 115th Congress, Speaker Ryan said: “We hear you. We will do right by you. And we will deliver.” Unfortunately for the American people, the speaker’s actions haven’t matched his rhetoric. I will continue standing up to the president and Republicans in Congress so we can address the issues important to you and your family.

This week, President Trump is expected to sign a disastrous executive order that would undermine one of our country’s most important tools for protecting national parks and public lands. For over 100 years, the Antiquities Act has been used by presidents to designate areas of natural and cultural heritage as national monuments. This landmark law has brought us almost half of our nation’s national parks including the Grand Canyon, Acadia, and Grand Tetons. Now, President Trump is expected to direct the Department of the Interior to review these designations and “suggest legislative changes or modifications.” We know what this means. During his campaign, the president repeatedly called for more drilling and more digging for fossil fuels. His executive order—which is expected to be signed just days after the historic March for Science in Washington, D.C.— would help pave the way by putting at risk the designations from millions of acres of lands and waters that have already been protected. This is yet another step backward for the Trump Administration and science-free Republican Congress, who have made rolling back critical environmental protections their mission. And for what? So a few oil hungry energy company executives can profit off the destruction of our nation’s most cherished landscapes? The level of disregard to the environment and  public good by this administration is abhorrent. I will continue to resist any effort to eliminate our natural and cultural treasures.

Yesterday, Republican and Democratic leaders on the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee confirmed that former national security advisor Michael Flynn may have broken the law by failing to disclose payments from companies linked to Russia before taking a job with the Trump Administration. This reaffirms what I’ve said from beginning: we need a bipartisan, 9/11 style investigation to examine this matter and get to the bottom of this administration’s connections to Russia. We have heard and seen enough. The American people deserve the truth.

As co-chair of the House Pro-Choice Caucus, I am disgusted by Congressional Republican efforts to attach anti-choice riders on their bill to fund the U.S. government. Once again, we may be faced with a power play in Congress pitting the federal budget against women's control over their personal health care decisions. The Republican leadership recklessly forced a shutdown in 2013 over a fruitless scheme to defund Planned Parenthood. Now, they risk the same result over more restrictions on women's health. Poison pill riders should not be attached to a basic funding bill to keep the government open. Republicans in Washington must open their eyes to the fact that many of their fellow Members of Congress and the American public oppose these extremist efforts. The women of America have had enough.

Like everyone, I was appalled by the recent incident on United Airlines, in which a passenger was violently removed from a plane after refusing to give up his seat for off-duty crew members. This was something that should never happen, especially in America. I have been encouraged to see that public outcry has led United and other carriers to change their policies to avoid this type of situation. I am not convinced that a change in policy is enough, however, and will support efforts to require airlines to treat the flying public with respect.

I introduced the Stop Trading on Congressional Knowledge (STOCK) Act and worked for years to get it signed into law so the American people could trust that members of Congress weren’t using their position for personal profit. In the view of many, this important law has been broken, which is why I have called on prosecutors to investigate. In addition to potential violations of insider trading, members of Congress have taken advantage of a new legal loophole to enrich themselves. This is a major violation of the public trust. The legislation I’m introducing will make it clear as day that federal officials who take part in exclusive stock deals, get special stock discounts or participate in foreign IPOs are breaking both the spirit and the letter of the law.

Last call for high school artists from New York’s 25th district! Next Thursday, May 4, is the last chance for young artists across Western New York to submit their work to the 35th annual Congressional Arts Competition. As co-chair of the Congressional Arts Caucus and lifelong advocate of the arts, I always enjoy seeing the work submitted by talented young artists from Monroe County. Last year’s winning piece, “Hemispheres,” has proudly hung in the halls of Congress for a year and now it’s time for a new piece to take its place. Submissions are even judged by a panel of local experts from the Memorial Art Gallery of the University of Rochester's Creative Workshop! For more information on how to submit, please visit my site:
Tomorrow marks the 100th day of the Trump Administration. Here’s a look at just how troubling it’s been.

Today, thousands will gather in our nation’s capital to voice their concerns about this administration’s disregard for climate change. In his first 100 days, the president has undone countless policies from the prior administration, including easing pollution limits on power plants, coal mining, oil and gas wells. President Trump's dangerous roll back of the former administration's climate policies is already affecting the trajectory of the world's efforts on global warming. Some analysts are even warning that the president’s actions will result in billions more tons of pollution entering the atmosphere in the next 15 years alone. We cannot afford to move backward on this and we must protect our planet like it’s our last chance. It is.

Today marks the 100th day of the Trump Administration and a troubling start for our president. I’ve received thousands of calls, emails, and postcards the last 100 days from people who are worried by the White House’s inability to make progress on the most critical issues facing our nation like repairing our crumbling infrastructure and addressing the skyrocketing cost of education. You sent me to Congress to get things done, and that’s why I will keep pushing the president and the Republican Majority to get serious about the issues important to our region. Make no mistake, I will work with anyone willing to tackle the matters important to our state and nation. But I also won’t stop holding the Republicans in Washington, including the Trump Administration, accountable.

I do, in fact, know what I’m talking about because I wrote the Stop Trading on Congressional Knowledge (STOCK) Act and fought for years to get it signed into law so that the public could trust that their representatives weren’t using their positions of power to enrich themselves. I believe that this critical law may have been broken and that’s why I’ve called on prosecutors to get to the bottom of this situation. I’ve also introduced new legislation to ensure that other ethical transgressions don’t happen again. Upholding the people’s trust is the most sacred responsibility we have as members of Congress. Breaking the spirit and the letter of the STOCK Act and taking advantage of legal loopholes for personal profit are violations of that trust. I will not stop sounding this alarm. The people we serve deserve better.

Late last night, a bipartisan spending agreement was reached that would preserve funding for transportation programs the president targeted for cuts in his proposed budget. Despite his pledges to replace our crumbling infrastructure with “new roads, bridges, tunnels, airports and railways,” the president’s plan proposed slashing the U.S. Department of Transportation's (DOT) budget, including a  major cut for critical investments in mass transit, the end of long-distance Amtrak trains like the Lakeshore Limited, and the elimination of TIGER grants, which made the new Rochester intermodal train station and Inner Loop redevelopment projects possible. Thankfully, the newest spending agreement disregards President Trump’s misguided proposals and will provide DOT with more than $680 million above current levels. Investing in and improving our infrastructure not only helps put millions of Americans to work, it also allows our nation to remain competitive in the global economy. This increase in funding is a positive development, and I will keep fighting to ensure that transportation remains a top priority.

Last night, Jimmy Kimmel delivered a touching monologue about his son, Billy, who was born needing immediate open-heart surgery just last week. As Jimmy said, no parent should be forced to wonder whether they can afford to treat a sick child or whether their child will be able to get health insurance in the future. That’s why the provisions in the Affordable Care Act (ACA) have been life-changing for millions of people. While working to repeal the ACA, President Trump also proposed a $6 billion cut to the National Institutes of Health (NIH) last month. More than 40 percent of the people impacted by that cut would have been sick children in need of quality care. I was proud to fight for funding for the NIH in the spending agreement reached earlier this week, which actually increases the NIH’s budget by $2 billion, and I will continue to fight against the repeal of the ACA which protects the millions of children born with pre-existing conditions. Today and every day, I stand with Jimmy and with millions of parents like him.

No one should be fired, evicted, or kicked out of a restaurant or hotel simply for being who they are. That’s why today I am proud to be an original co-sponsor of the Equality Act, which would amend the 1964 Civil Rights Act to include nondiscrimination protections on the basis of sex, sexual orientation, and gender identity. This bill sends a clear message that LGBTQ Americans deserve nothing less than full, unmitigated legal equality from their government. As a member of the Congressional LGBT Equality Caucus, I believe that our LGBTQ community is long overdue for full protection under the law and that’s why I will fight every day to help pass the Equality Act.

Forty-four million people across the country owe over $1.3 trillion in student loans, with the average 2016 graduate owing more than $37,000. In today’s competitive global economy, we need more students graduating with a college degree and less graduating with unsurmountable debt. The spending agreement reached over the weekend is a step toward a solution because it expands Pell grant eligibility to include low-income students attending year-round classes and would provide one million students with an average award of $1,650. This is a smart, bipartisan approach to making college more affordable. Protecting the right for all students to get a college education is a top priority of mine and I recently co-sponsored the Affordability for Constant and Continual Education to Enhance Student Success (ACCESS) Act, which would reinstate the summer Pell Grant, allowing students to complete their degrees on time as well as participate in accelerated programs that require summer courses. If we want to inspire the next generation workforce in photonics, teaching, arts, STEM, or any other field, we have to make college degrees more, not less, accessible.

The president’s budget called for the elimination of the National Endowment for the Arts (NEA) and the National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH). Thankfully, the bipartisan spending agreement reached over the weekend actually increases funding for the NEA and NEH. The arts are an invaluable part of our nation and region’s culture and economy. From the Eastman School of Music and the Geva Theatre Center to the Memorial Art Gallery and the George Eastman Museum, Rochester is home to a thriving arts community that is made possible by vital departments like the NEA and NEH. Although this bipartisan agreement is a positive development, more must be done to permanently fund and sustain the NEA and NEH. As co-chair of the Congressional Arts Caucus and former blues singer, I take advocating for the arts most seriously. Rest assured that I will not give an inch on this important issue.

“Republicans face a test: Will they govern responsibly, or will they force a disastrous failure in health-care markets?”   In case you missed it, today’s editorial in the Washington Post highlights a critical question that remains unanswered in the never-ending crusade by Congressional Republicans to jam their health care repeal bill through the House. Amazingly, they have managed to make their health care repeal bill even worse by allowing states to waive essential health benefits and community rating rules, provisions included in the Affordable Care Act to prevent insurers from discriminating against people with preexisting conditions. This editorial asks the right question: will Republicans in Washington govern responsibly or will they use their faulty repeal bill to fulfill a political talking point, crash our health care markets, and rip coverage from those who need it most?

The bipartisan spending agreement is a win for the American public and especially the 2.5 million people who rely on Planned Parenthood each year for the care they need. Under this new agreement, there are no funding cuts to Planned Parenthood through the rest of the fiscal year. This is good news, especially in the wake of the seemingly never-ending efforts by Congressional Republicans and President Trump to defund this organization and put the cancer screenings, STI testing, and other preventative services it provides out-of-reach for so many. Although this is an encouraging development, there is still work to be done to ensure that Planned Parenthood is permanently protected. I will continue working to defend the life-saying services it provides so many across the country.

With their dangerous health care repeal bill, Republicans in Washington are putting the needs of corporations and the wealthy above the health of everyday Americans. This is shameful. So as tens of millions of Americans lose their health insurance, their ability to go to the doctor, and their coverage for pre-existing conditions, Congressional Republicans can sit back and rest easy knowing that this bill was used to line the pockets of their wealthy allies with a nearly trillion dollar tax break. The House of Representatives is the People’s House. Today, Congressional Republicans are not working for the people. I said it on the floor this morning: this is truly a sad day for our country.

Do any of these organizations look familiar to you and your loved ones? Guess what all of them have in common. They all put patients first and oppose the Republicans’ dangerous health care repeal bill.   American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network, American Diabetes Association, American Heart Association, American Lung Association, Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, JDRF, March of Dimes, National Multiple Sclerosis Society, National Organization for Rare Disorders, Women Heart: The National Coalition for Women with Heart Disease and hundreds of others.

More than 60 times over the course of the last seven years Congressional Republicans shouted “repeal and replace” without a single thing to replace the Affordable Care Act. Millions and millions of taxpayer dollars were wasted on this fruitless endeavor. It was one of the greatest hoaxes our government has ever seen. Today’s dangerous proposal is no better. My so-called fiscally responsible Republican colleagues don’t know how much this repeal bill costs but here’s what we do know: it eliminates guaranteed coverage for those with pre-existing conditions and will unleash chaos in our insurance markets. This bill lacks a moral compass. Let’s call it what it is: a trillion dollar tax break for the wealthiest among us. What a sad, sad day for the United States. Here I am standing up against this dangerous proposal on the House floor earlier today:

The Republican health care repeal bill would cause tens of millions of Americans living with pre-existing conditions to lose comprehensive, affordable coverage. What counts as a pre-existing condition under the Republicans’ sweeping proposal? People living with autism, women who have had children,  and domestic abuse and rape survivors. These are just some examples of the millions who would be forced to pay skyrocketing premiums and who would once again face discrimination from big insurance companies that exist to make profits, not deliver quality, affordable care. This is despicable. Those that vote for this harmful bill should be ashamed of themselves. We must do more, not less, to protect the most vulnerable among us.

Republicans in Congress are hurling our nation toward disaster. Despite the slapdash changes made recently to this bill, the facts haven’t changed. This repeal kicks 24 million people off their health insurance, guts essential health benefits like doctors’ visits, maternity care, and prescription drug coverage, and places a crushing age tax costing thousands on those aged 50 to 64, all while cutting more than $800 billion from Medicaid to pay for a nearly trillion dollar tax cut for the wealthy. This bill eliminates the safety net for those with pre-existing conditions. It shreds that safety net under the Affordable Care Act by letting states decide whether or not sick Americans can get the care they need. Millions of people would pay soaring premiums if they could afford any coverage at all.  I’ve always said that a bad process leads to a bad product. That has never been truer than it is today. Literal lives are a stake, but Republican leadership jammed this bill through the House without a single hearing or a score from the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office. We have no idea how much it costs but we know it would unleash chaos in our insurance markets. We do know that it would devastate the people every member of Congress represents. Republicans in Washington have rushed to fulfill a dangerous political talking point, but the American people don’t have a thing in the world to celebrate with this bill.

Yesterday while speaking on the House floor, I had a message for my Republican colleagues. Just in case they thought no one was paying attention, I wanted them to know that my office has received an unprecedented number of calls, postcards, and emails from constituents urging Congress to not strip away their healthcare protections under the Affordable Care Act. For the first time, my Washington office alone has received nearly 200 applications for the summer internship season. It just goes to show that people are listening, people are paying attention, they’re getting involved and making sure their voices are being heard. Those people deserve better than what Congressional Republicans delivered yesterday.

I’m proud to stand with Representative Rosa DeLauro in introducing a package of bipartisan bills that would reform the Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) review process for medical devices used by doctors and hospitals across the country.
