While most medical devices prove lifesaving, we know that some can cause harm and have devastating consequences for patients. Our bills are about solving this problem and saving lives. I’ve met with many families who have endured unspeakable tragedy as a result of unsafe medical devices. No one should have to wonder whether a device meant to save a life could instead cause devastating consequences. Our bills would make badly needed reforms to the FDA’s reporting requirements and offer patients the recourse they deserve when a device harms patients. It is time for Congress to finally fix this broken system.

Many thanks to Lt. Colonel Adam Czekanski, District Commander of the US Army Corps of Engineers, Buffalo District, for visiting Monroe County today. We had a good discussion in Irondequoit with Supervisor Dave Seeley and his Department of Public Works team regarding local flood mitigation efforts. NYS Department of Homeland Security and Emergency Services delivered 50,000 sandbags to Monroe County this week and 100,000 more are stockpiled locally. Please stay safe out there. For the latest information and assistance, call the Lake Ontario Flood Assistance Hotline at (866) 244-3839.

Over the weekend, France saw a 65 percent voter turnout rate in its presidential election. Although this isn’t an historic high for France, it is still significantly higher than the turnout rate from the United States’ election in November, which was at a twenty-year low of 57.5 percent. If we want to strengthen our democracy, we must make it easier for Americans to vote, not harder. That’s why I recently introduced the Weekend Voting Act, which would make it more convenient for all Americans to exercise their right to vote by extending voting hours to span two days and helping to reduce long lines at the polls. Currently, most polls are only open between 12 and 13 hours a day for one day during the work week. Extending voting hours would mean that students, seniors, and those who work the night shift would have ample opportunity to get to the polls. The Weekend Voting Act is commonsense legislation that will help ensure the path to the ballot box is clear for all Americans! I will continue to make my voice heard on this important issue.

I’m so proud of Rochester-based Wegmans for being recognized as an outstanding Safer Choice Retailer by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Safer Choice is a nationwide initiative that plays a vital role in developing products that contain safer chemical ingredients that are less harmful for families’ health and the environment. This year, the EPA granted just 33 of these prestigious awards to companies across the country. Wegmans was specifically chosen for its commitment to transition all Wegmans-brand household cleaning products, laundry and dish detergents to Safer Choice-certified formulas. Congratulations, Wegmans, on this outstanding achievement!

Don’t miss my editorial in the Harvard Law & Policy Review! For fourteen years, seven congresses, and three administrations I fought hard to pass the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act (GINA), a law I wrote which prohibits health insurers and employers from using your genetic information against you. When GINA passed, the American people no longer had to fear that their health insurance premiums would skyrocket or that their boss would fire them based on a genetic predisposition to a condition they may or may not ever develop. Despite the major progress that made under this law, Congressional Republicans are now pushing a bill which would pressure employees to reveal their genetic information, or face the loss of health care benefits. Undermining this law is as bad as it gets. We cannot afford to turn back the clock and reverse the progress we’ve made under GINA. Private genetic information should remain exactly that - private.

Today is National Teacher Appreciation Day! Today and every day we celebrate the critical role that educators play in shaping the lives of millions of children across our country. Teachers get in early and stay late, advocate for their students, give one-on-one attention and a little extra help whenever necessary. Thank you, sincerely, to all the teachers across the Rochester region and the nation for the important work that you do every day. Now, who’s your favorite teacher in Rochester?

As the only microbiologist in Congress, I know firsthand about the importance of science in our legislative process. It has been frustrating to watch the current administration and Republican Congress refuse to give science and facts their rightful place in policy debates. From drastically reducing funding for the Environmental Protection Agency and discrediting climate change to attempting to eliminate genetic safeguards, this administration and Republicans in Congress have worked ruthlessly to roll back the scientific advancements we’ve made. I’ve worked hard to advance science-smart policies like the Preservation of Antibiotics for Medical Treatment Act and the Genetic Information Non-Discrimination Act and my resolve is stronger than ever. I will continue to fight against this assault on science and advocate for policies that build on the progress we’ve made.

This is alarming and unprecedented.  Now more than ever, we need an independent, 9/11 style investigation to look into Russia's meddling in our elections and Putin's hold over this administration. The American people have heard and seen enough. It is beyond time for answers.

James Comey? Fired by President Trump. Sally Yates? Fired by President Trump. Preet Bharara? Fired by President Trump. That’s not all they have in common. Each was reportedly investigating this administration’s actions before being fired by the president in what I believe is a gross abuse of power meant to prevent them from doing their jobs and getting to the truth. The news surrounding the former FBI director is just the latest sign that we cannot trust President Trump. If we are ever going to get the truth we need an independent commission. Now.

Tomorrow marks the start of the annual Rochester Lilac Festival, a time for our community to gather and experience 10 incredible days of non-stop festivities including magnificent gardens, music, and beautiful exhibits. Rochester’s Lilac Festival is nearly 120 years old and is the largest of its kind in North America. What are you most looking forward to?

May is Military Appreciation Month, a time when we recognize and celebrate the service of our brave men and women in uniform. Defending our servicemembers—just as they do for us—is a tremendous responsibility and one that I take seriously. I’ve worked hard to ensure that our troops have the protective equipment they need to be safe on the battlefield and to eliminate the scourge of sexual assault in the military. I’ve also fought to protect our servicemembers from exposure to blast overpressure, the leading cause of Traumatic Brain Injury, which is the signature injury of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. These men and women are some of the bravest among us. Today and every day I celebrate and thank you and your families for your service.

Last month, President Trump’s Federal Communications Commission (FCC) proposed to roll back net neutrality protections, which are the foundation to our free and open market. Net neutrality safeguards the freedom of speech online. Without it, organic online movements like the historic Women’s March on Washington or Black Lives Matter could be stifled and stopped. The FCC’s roll back would cut the legal legs out from underneath our freedom of speech, allow big corporations to decide what you see and who you talk to, and would hand your power to choose over to those that can pay the most. This week, the FCC will vote on this outrageous proposal. I am strongly opposed and will continue to voice my opposition.

It’s the season of graduations! I’ve fought hard to increase opportunities for all of our students, including preserving and expanding the Pell Grant Program, supporting the growth of preschool and national school readiness programs, and fighting to ensure that homeless children are offered the same standard of care as their peers. I truly believe that education is the key that unlocks our nation’s full economic potential. Whether you’re a working adult finishing your degree, a soon-to-be college graduate, or a teen about to end your senior year of high school, I  will continue working to ensure that you have access to the tools you need for future success. Congratulations to everyone across Monroe County celebrating their graduations this month!

Happy Mother’s Day to everyone celebrating across Rochester and the nation! As a mother of three and grandmother of seven, I know how much these roles have helped shape how I view my responsibilities as a federal legislator. From advocating for affordable health care to fighting for paid family leave and equal pay for equal work, the choices Congress makes day in and day out affects the lives of women, children, and their families. This humbling fact strengthens my resolve to keep working toward a more just world where mothers and all women are valued and respected.

As scandals surrounding this administration continue to break, my resolve remains strong to fight back against President Trump and Republicans in Congress who are threatening everything from the environment and women’s health to trade and infrastructure development. We must refuse to be silent as the president and his team of billionaires, lobbyists, and CEOs rollback critical protections and institute dangerous new policies that will harm the American people. To learn more about what I’m doing to advance issues important to our nation and our region, sign up for legislative updates and receive the latest about what’s going on in Washington and Rochester right in your inbox.

Congratulations to Nasreen Jaff from School Without Walls for her extraordinary submission in this year’s Congressional Arts Competition! As the winner of this year’s competition in the 25th congressional district, Nasreen’s artwork will soon be hung in the Capitol for the next year. I’m so impressed by her beautiful piece and attention to detail. Thank you, Nasreen, for your submission! Thank you, too, to the three other finalists—Catherine Wu, Rebecca Flisnik, and Olaa Mohamed. I’m always impressed by the skills and talents of so many across our community.

“Progress is possible. But we cannot wait, we cannot stand by.”  I’m with Joe Biden. Today, all across our country and the world, the LGBTQ community and their allies are standing up and speaking out in support of International Day Against Homophobia, Transphobia and Biphobia. Discrimination of any form must be stopped in its tracks. Although we’ve made major progress here in the United States, that growth is at risk under the Trump Administration. From looming executive orders on “religious freedom” to the elimination of LGBTQ identification on the 2020 census and expressed support for North Carolina’s HB2, this has been a worrisome beginning for a president who promised to “protect LGBTQ citizens.” As a member of the Congressional LGBT Equality Caucus, I'm proud to stand firmly on the side of civil and human rights. Our former Vice President said it best: progress is possible. But we cannot wait. We must take action and continue to fight for this cause.

Yesterday, I was proud to co-sponsor four new bills, three of which are led by my Republican colleagues in the House. These bills tackle everything from rehabilitating historic buildings and protecting big cat wildlife to forcing corporations to disclose chemicals that could end up in our drinking water and ending discrimination against individuals with disabilities who need long-term care. When it comes to solving problems, I will work anyone, Democrat or Republican, to make our county and our community stronger. If you want to learn more about the bills I’ve introduced or cosponsored, check them out here:

When families have access to affordable and safe housing, they can use more of their hard-earned paychecks to afford things like groceries, medicine, and school supplies, improving their quality of life while benefiting our local and national economy. Investments in organizations like PathStone and NeighborWorks help break the cycle of poverty and economic inequality that too often limits families across our country and Monroe County. These federal awards will support efforts to develop and preserve affordable housing, revitalize and sustain our neighborhoods, and create jobs in New York. I’m proud to bring this funding to Rochester, so that we can continue to ensure all of our neighbors have access to the support they need.

This crocheted mural is a testament to the strong sense of community we have here in Rochester. Did you know it took nearly two months, 200 volunteers, and 351 crocheted panels to complete this quilt, which now hangs on the corner of Canal and Main? Even better, the mural features a picture of Susan B. Anthony, Rochester’s pioneering woman who devoted her life to promoting equality for all Americans. She was a tireless advocate for women’s suffrage, and spoke before every session of Congress between 1869 and 1906 to promote equal voting rights for women. Thanks to her efforts, millions of women across the country can now agree—independence is happiness.

I’m encouraged that Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein listened to the voices of the American people and took action last night in appointing a special counsel to investigate Russia’s ties to President Trump and its involvement in the 2016 election. Although this appointment is an important step forward, it is still not enough. Former FBI Director Robert Mueller’s appointment does not lessen the need for an independent, outside commission that’s truly free from any interference by the Trump Administration. An independent commission like the one created by President Bush following the 9/11 attacks would be made up of outside experts who would issue a report on their findings, which could include forward-looking ways of dealing with similar foreign interference in the future. Seventy-eight percent of the public agrees, it’s time to create this commission so that we can get to the bottom of Russia’s meddling in our elections and prevent this nightmarish situation from ever happening again.

I’ve always fought for affordable education and my new bill, the Perkins Loans Extension Act of 2017, is no different. Perkins loans help low-income students access the benefits of a higher education. This program provides low-interest loans that are paid back to the student’s college, creating a revolving system that supports the next class of deserving students. With absolutely no additional funding from the federal government, Perkins loans will continue to help students attain an education and allow them to break the cycle of poverty. It is inexcusable that some politicians are targeting this program for elimination since Perkins loans are a lifeline for 500,000 low-income students across the country and more than 6,000 from Monroe County alone. Thank you to the University of Rochester, Rochester Institute of Technology, Nazareth College, Monroe Community College, The College at Brockport State University of New York, St. John Fisher College, and so many others for your continued support on this important issue!

I voted against NAFTA because I couldn’t see it providing any benefits to American workers. Sadly, Rochester has lost half of its manufacturing jobs since this trade deal went into effect. It has been a bad deal for our manufacturers, small businesses nationwide have been forced to close their doors, and our trade deficit has grown out of control. All the while, a special provision in this trade deal has allowed multinational corporations to challenge U.S. laws they don’t like outside of the standard judicial system, endangering laws on everything from clean drinking water standards to raising a state’s minimum wage. President Trump now has an obligation to ensure his rhetoric on trade is more than just empty promises. His letter today is short on specifics, which is why I will continue fighting to make sure this administration is serious about crafting a free trade agreement that is finally fair to our workers. As I told Secretary Ross and Ambassador Lighthizer yesterday, it is time for an entirely new course in our nation’s trade policy. That includes not only rewriting NAFTA, but also enacting my bill, the Trade Enforcement and Trade Deficit Reduction Act, to change how we approach international trade.

This week during my Rules Committee meeting, I spoke about how important our law enforcement agencies are to every community. Police officers and first-responders risk their lives every day to keep us safe. They stand in the snow, the sleet, and the rain to protect us—I never forget that. From defending benefits for disabled officers and securing emergency preparedness funding for Rochester, I’ve always been a proud advocate for all of our law enforcement agencies. This week marks National Police Week. I want to thank all of the men and women who serve their communities, I am appreciative of your work every single day.

Retirees should not be forced to live in fear that the benefits promised to them in exchange for decades of work could be ripped away at a moment’s notice. That’s why I’m proud to stand with my Republican colleague, Congressman Walter Jones, in introducing the Employee Benefits Protection Act of 2017. Benefits that were once guaranteed have been increasingly eroded as more and more companies use corporate restructurings to avoid paying retirees what they’ve earned. Workers dedicate their careers to serving companies and my legislation will help ensure they get the pensions and health benefits they’ve earned and deserve.

It has been a busy week in Washington working for you! I’ve fought to help our workers by introducing a bill to protect retiree health benefits from corporate restructurings, so that those who spend their careers serving a company get the benefits they have earned. I’m also continuing my fight to save the Perkins Loan Program, which is once again on the chopping block in Washington. I led the charge to save this program from expiring back in 2015. The bill I’ve introduced this week would reauthorize this program for another two years so that more than 6,000 students in our region and many more nationwide can access the benefits of higher education. Thank you to the members of the Letter Carriers Union and the American Organization of Nurse Executives for meeting with me this week as well to discuss the issues happening on Capitol Hill. I especially enjoyed meeting one of my newest constituents, Rodney, a mail carrier in Rochester.

Here we go again. House Republicans are holding their health care repeal bill in a drawer somewhere until they can be sure that it follows rules that allow Senate Republicans to pass the bill without any Democratic support. Republicans jammed their repeal bill through without a Congressional Budget Office score; without input from experts, doctors, and people with illnesses; and without any sense of direction. They also included backroom, dead-of-night provisions at the last minute that now threaten the passage of a bill that, frankly, should’ve never been brought up in the first place. Their proposal, which only 17 percent of the country approves of, should be taken out of the drawer and shredded. The American people deserve better than what Congressional Republicans are delivering.

It’s another day in Washington and the Trump Administration is once again working to keep the public in the dark. Newest reports indicate that the administration has blocked all efforts to disclose the names of former lobbyists who’ve been granted ethics waivers to work in the White House or other federal agencies. This is a dramatic departure from the norm, since the prior administration automatically made all ethics waivers public and offered detailed explanations. Without access to these waivers, the American people have no idea which special interests are working behind closed doors to influence the president’s policies. I strongly support the Office of Government Ethics’ decision to demand copies of the waivers provided by the Trump Administration. I’ve said it so much I sound like a broken record—the public deserves an open and transparent government, not one that hides the truth at every possible turn.

Today the White House announced that it would ask for a further continuance in a court case that will decide the future of the health insurance markets created under the Affordable Care Act. This means another kick of the can regarding the fate of our health insurance marketplace and the comprehensive care upon which so many depend. What we need is certainty, not vague timelines and threats by a president who is willing to use the stability of our marketplace and millions of peoples’ health insurance as a bargaining chip to coerce Congressional Democrats into voting for his disastrous health care plan. Mr. President, every day that you postpone doing the right thing, the American public’s health insurance costs go up. That is disgraceful and unnecessary. It’s past time that you govern responsibly.

President Trump’s budget proposal is as heartless as it is harmful. This proposal includes a drastic $610 billion cut to Medicaid and a $190 billion cut to food stamps and school lunch programs over the next ten years. It ransacks education programs to the tune of $143 billion, making education costs soar even further for students. The administration’s budget even contradicts President Trump’s own promises to invest in infrastructure by decimating funding for the Highway Trust Fund and eliminating funding for the TIGER programs that are making Inner Loop upgrades and construction of our new train station possible. No sector of society is spared. Even the air we breathe and the water we drink would be put at risk by a proposed 30 percent cut to the Environmental Protection Agency. The president’s budget would also start the clock on the elimination of the National Endowment for the Arts and National Endowment for the Humanities regardless of the fact that they make up less than 0.008 of the federal budget and provide programming in every Congressional district. All this to increase defense spending while working to give a massive tax cut to the wealthy. Members of both parties are already expressing outrage over this request, and I will be fighting to make sure it never becomes a reality.

The president’s dangerous budget proposal released today would slash the National Institutes of Health's (NIH) budget by nearly $6 billion. That would include millions of dollars in cuts to critical organizations like the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI) and the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID), which help prevent the spread of diseases like AIDS and Zika. This cut would cripple the important research these institutes do in developing life-saving cures and treatments for diseases. Locally, we would see drastic cuts in research funding, threatening jobs and the important work happening right here in Rochester. One of my proudest early accomplishments in Congress was securing the first $500 million in federal funding for breast cancer research at the NIH and that’s why I’m particularly outraged by the president’s plan. It’s because of the NIH that our nation has been at the forefront of many landmark scientific breakthroughs and remains a global leader in some of the most important research being done today. I will continue to make sure we stay that way and fight so that the president’s plan never becomes a reality.

It was such a pleasure joining my friend and Chairman of the House Rules Committee, Congressman Pete Sessions, for a conversation with students from the University of Houston. Puja Javalagi, Katie Drews, Eden Absar, Melina Diaz, Livia Garza, Rogette Saba, and Manvitha Katta are bright young women working hard to make a difference in our country. We discussed the work of the committee, the priorities facing Congress, and how the next generation can get involved in public service. Thank you to these students for attending the Rules Committee meeting this week and for such a great discussion!

President Trump’s proposed budget steals billions of dollars from job-creating investments in infrastructure all the while giving a massive tax cut to the wealthy. It eviscerates funding for Amtrak and new transit projects and eliminates the TIGER grant program, which has made the new Rochester intermodal train station and Inner Loop upgrades a reality. It’s the height of hypocrisy. The president ran his campaign on improving infrastructure and now has decided to dismantle programs that enable this growth. Despite his promises to replace our crumbling infrastructure with “new roads, bridges, tunnels, airports and railways,” the president’s plan will stifle progress in infrastructure development all the while harming good-paying jobs. I am opposed to his disastrous plan and will continue to voice my strong opposition.

Nearly three weeks ago, House Republicans passed their disastrous health care repeal bill. Where’s the bill now? Stuffed in a drawer somewhere in the Capitol. House Republicans are waiting for the Congressional Budget Office (CBO) to release their score later this afternoon before sending their dangerous repeal to the Senate. A CBO score tells members of Congress how much a bill will cost, how many people it will help and how many people it will hurt. Congressional Republicans were apparently so scared about what this score would reveal that they jammed the bill through the House at lightning speed, without a score, without holding a single hearing, and without hearing from any experts. This is a complete breakdown of the legislative process. The facts of this bill remain the same: millions and millions of Americans will lose their health insurance and be forced to pay higher costs for worse coverage, if they could afford any coverage at all. That’s why I will continue fighting against this bill and fighting to improve the Affordable Care Act.

Republican leaders shattered the integrity of the legislative process when they jammed this bill through the House without a score from the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office outlining its costs and impacts. They moved so quickly to rip away health care from millions of people that they didn’t even hold a single hearing or listen to any experts. This plan was practically thrown together on the back of a napkin in a backroom somewhere despite the fact that it will impact one-sixth of our nation’s economy. The score released from the CBO today shows why Republicans moved so hastily while keeping Americans in the dark. The Republican repeal bill would leave 23 million uninsured, including 14 million in the first year alone. It would decimate Medicaid, disproportionately  impacting those in nursing homes, and ransack the funds that many seniors and people living with disabilities rely on for care. This repeal bill would erase the increased standard of care all Americans are seeing under the health reform law. The CBO has also confirmed that it would gut protections for people with preexisting conditions, causing their premiums to skyrocket and pricing many people of the market entirely. House Republicans have been waiting for this CBO score before advancing this bill. Instead of sending it to the Senate, they should put it in the shredder where it belongs. It is past time for Congressional Republicans to listen to the American people and come together to improve the Affordable Care Act.

I’ve always said that a good education is the key to unlocking the potential of our students and helping them succeed throughout their lives. I’m so proud to announce federal awards totaling more than a million dollars for RIT, the U of R, MCC, and SUNY Brockport to help students in our region further their education. These competitive awards are a testament to work being done by colleges and universities right here in our region to help our young people thrive.

President Trump’s budget would be a disaster for millions of students across our country and hit our community hard. Everything from after-school programs to aid for college students would be on the chopping block. Under the Trump proposal, student loans, financial aid, and repayment programs would be cut by $143 billion over the next 10 years. This would raise students’ costs to attend college and finish their degrees. Today, 44 million students in the United States owe more than $1.3 trillion in student loans, with the average 2016 graduate owing more than $37,000. Just last week, I introduced a bill to extend and protect the Perkins Loan, so that the more than 6,000 students across Monroe County who rely on this program could continue to receive the support they deserve. In today’s global and competitive economy, we must be working to make education more accessible, not less. I oppose the president’s dangerous and shortsighted budget and will continue standing up for students in Monroe County.

I’m deeply saddened by the passing of Dr. Amy Reed. She was an extraordinary doctor, wife, and mother who became one of the fiercest advocates for patients nationwide. Dr. Reed’s filing of the first report to the FDA following her surgery with a power morcellator gave a voice to so many people whose lives were devastated by these dangerous devices. Her drive and determination was vital to the work to prevent other families from having to endure such tragedy because of unsafe medical devices. My thoughts are with her husband, children, and entire family during this difficult time.

The president’s budget proposal once again puts the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency—and the important work it does in protecting our air, water, and lands—on the chopping block. President Trump has now called for slashing the EPA’s budget by 32 percent, a dangerous move that puts climate change research, environmental conservation efforts, and much, much more at risk.This proposed cut not only threatens environmental preservation efforts, but also thousands of jobs nationwide. We are the stewards of our environment and we have an obligation to protect our earth for the generations that will follow us. That’s why I will continue to fight against the president’s disastrous, science and fact-free proposal.

On this Memorial Day, we remember the selfless men and women of our Armed Forces who gave their life for this country. Today and every day, I am in awe of their sacrifice. Thank you to the brave men and women who have worn the uniform and fought for our great nation. If you are a veteran or know a veteran who may require assistance receiving benefits, please do not hesitate to call my Rochester office at 585-232-4850.

I’m so pleased to announce this federal funding for Pittsford-based Science Take-Out to continue their important work educating kids and community members about science. At a time when science and fact are under siege, it is critical that organizations like this promote the building blocks of environmental education for our students. I’ve often said that Rochester is home to some of the brightest minds in the country and this is largely because of businesses like Science Take-Out, who help inspire the next generation of researchers and environmental advocates with engaging, hands-on activities. Congratulations, Science-Take Out, on this tremendous award!

Drip, drip, drip. The most recent reports indicate that Jared Kushner, senior advisor to the president and his son-in-law, tried to initiate a secret communication channel with Russia to evade standard U.S. monitoring. He reportedly went so far as to suggest using Russian communications equipment at a Russian embassy or consulate. What is Mr. Kushner trying to hide? The American people have every right to be concerned. This is just another reason why we need an independent, bipartisan investigation to get to the bottom of this administration’s ties to Putin.

I’m so proud that the Rochester Institute of Technology will be sending a team to NASA's Johnson Space Center (JSC) to test their research in simulated microgravity. The students from RIT will test their project as a part of NASA’s Micro-g Neutral Buoyancy Experiment Design initiative, a prestigious program that challenges undergraduate students to build tools that help address current space exploration obstacles.This hands-on experience is a tremendous opportunity for young students across the country to test their scientific prowess. The impressive team from RIT spent months designing their device and will travel to Houston this week to put their prototypes to the test in the JSC’s Neutral Buoyancy Laboratory– a 6.2-million-gallon pool used to simulate microgravity for astronaut spacewalk training. I’m always the first to brag about the innovative research happening right here in Rochester and this team is a testament to that fact. Congratulations, RIT, on your achievement!

If we can’t get people where they need to go safely and efficiently, it will be more difficult to attract and keep businesses in our area. That is especially important with the Greater Rochester International Airport (ROC), which supports more than 10,000 jobs and adds more than $800 million to our local economy. I’m proud to bring more than $2.4 million dollars from the Federal Aviation Administration to make these important upgrades. This investment in our airport will help our region take advantage of Rochester’s resurgence as a hub for the flow of goods and people!

“Price’s lobbying abroad, which has not previously been reported, is another example of how his work in Congress could have benefited his investment portfolio. He traded hundreds of thousands of dollars’ worth of shares in health-related companies while taking action on legislation and regulations affecting the industry.”   I’m proud that my law – the Stop Trading on Congressional Knowledge or STOCK Act – brought these unethical trades into the light of day. This latest, troubling report indicates that while serving in Congress, Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price directly lobbied foreign officials about issues affecting stocks in which he had financial interest. I wrote the STOCK Act and fought for years to get it signed into law to prevent this kind of unethical behavior and ensure that backdoor transgressions like these were disclosed to the public. I’m encouraged by ProPublica’s deep dive reporting, which is the reason the president’s administration continues to be under fire for its litany of unethical behaviors. I have introduced new legislation to hold Members of Congress accountable for self-dealing, so the American people can have faith that their representatives aren’t using their positions of power for personal profit.

Today marks the beginning of Pride Month, a time when our LGBTQ community and their allies come together and celebrate equality for all. As a member of the Congressional LGBT Equality Caucus, I’m proud to stand resolutely on the side of civil and human rights. I’ve long supported our LGBTQ neighbors and I’m committed to continue fighting discrimination wherever it exists. This month and every month, I pledge to continue pushing for full equality for all.

Rochester is a national leader in innovative research and is helping to lead the world in some of the most important medical work being done today. That’s why I’m proud to announce this major award for the University of Rochester to continue its research into muscular dystrophy, which impacts so many families across Monroe County and the country. I will continue leading the effort against the president’s budget request, which would slash funding for the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services and put thousands of our local researchers and programs like this one at risk.

There is no earthly reason why the president should withdraw from the Paris Agreement. Everyone from members of his business advisory board to the Pope have voiced their strong concerns about this move. I stand with all of you outraged by the president’s dangerous decision. Climate change is real. Anyone who denies this and threatens to take our country backward is harming the major progress we’ve made in protecting our earth for future generations. By walking away from this critical agreement, President Trump is sending a message to the rest of the world that they should manufacture clean energy solutions and create jobs somewhere outside the United States. We shouldn't be withdrawing from our obligations or ceding our leadership to any other nation.

You cannot be a superpower if you don’t make anything, but America is sadly at a major disadvantage. Our nation has engaged in decades of misguided trade deals that have been anything but fair to workers and manufacturers across Monroe County and the country. Many communities have seen the impacts in shuttered warehouses, empty factories, and outsourced jobs. That’s why I’m proud to introduce new legislation that will transform how our nation approaches international trade so it finally benefits American workers, businesses, and manufacturers.

I am proud to have taken part in Quiltfest 2017, an important event hosted by the Genesee Valley Quilt Club and the Susan B. Anthony Museum & House that commemorated the 100th anniversary of equal voting rights for women in New York. I even presented my own quilt square to be joined in a larger quilt that celebrates women’s suffrage. The joining of these squares is a testament to the strong sense of community we have in Rochester and reminds us how far we’ve come and how far we still have to go to achieve equality. This tenacious spirit was modeled by our very own Susan B. Anthony. Thank you, Genesee Valley Quilt Club and the Susan B. Anthony Museum and House, for hosting such a tremendous event!

Over the weekend, I was proud to take part in the 4th annual 5k Walk at El Camino, a special event that helped commemorate the El Camino trail and the late Thomas Frey, former Monroe County Executive. Mr. Frey was a remarkable man and a terrific public servant. He was committed to linking all families and neighborhoods with the natural world and improving everyone’s quality of life through his role in local government. This event over the weekend, and the many of you who showed up in support, are a testament to his lasting legacy. Thank you, Genesee Land Trust, Conkey Cruisers, and Ibero-American Action League, for bringing our community together to celebrate Mr. Frey and his work on National Trails Day!

Yesterday I had the chance to meet with Sujatha Ramanujan and other representatives from the India Community Center of Rochester, NY (ICC) to talk about how our city can continue to raise awareness about Indian culture. The ICC is full of dedicated public servants whose work helps make a positive difference for so many across Monroe County. As a member of the Congressional Caucus on India and Indian-Americans, I have long been—and will always be—a strong advocate for issues important to our Indian-American neighbors and families. Thank you to the representatives from the ICC for taking the time to speak with me. I am proud to represent you and Rochester’s vibrant Indian-American community!

Today I had the chance to meet the new Xerox Chief Executive Officer, Jeff Jacobson. Jeff brings years of experience on how to revitalize and grow one of Rochester’s greatest sources of pride. His unwavering commitment to driving innovation and ensuring the highest-level quality that Xerox is known for was obvious and his vision for this respected company was even clearer. Thank you to Xerox and Jeff for stopping in and speaking with me about your plan for the future.

House Republicans have forgotten about the devastating impacts the 2008 financial crash had on millions of families across the United States. That’s what they’re suggesting anyway with their new bill, the CHOICE Act, a dangerous proposal  that completely guts some of the most important financial reforms  that helped stabilize our economy after the worst crash since the Great Depression. Since Washington Republicans can’t seem to  remember the specifics, let me make it more clear for them: more than 8 million jobs were lost, unemployment surged to 10 percent,  at least 11 million Americans lost their homes to foreclosures, and $13 trillion dollars in wealth was lost virtually overnight. All of this is now at risk again under the Republican proposal. It’s time for House Republicans to let go of their selective memory, stop doing the bidding of big banks, and start acting in the best interest of American families.

I was pleased to learn that my friend, Dr. Francis Collins, will stay on as Director of the National Institutes of Health (NIH). I had the chance to bring Dr. Collins to Rochester and tell him about the groundbreaking research happening right here in our community during his visit to the University of Rochester in October. Dr. Collins is a world-renowned physician and geneticist who helped lead the charge of the International Human Genome Project, which in 2003 sequenced the complete human genetic blueprint for the first time. As Director of NIH, he has been a visionary leader and I am certain that under his direction the NIH will continue to lead the way in scientific breakthroughs. Although there's much at stake for scientific research under the president’s proposed budget cuts to the NIH, I am confident in Dr. Collins’ ability to continue to keep our country on the cutting edge of science, research, and medical breakthroughs.

Today marks the 52nd anniversary of Griswold v. Connecticut, a landmark Supreme Court case which ruled that states had no right to ban contraception for married couples and established—for the first time—a family’s constitutional right to privacy regarding reproductive health decisions. This critical ruling paved the way for the legalization of birth control and ultimately the no-cost birth control protections included in the ACA. To commemorate this day, I sat down with the president  of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) and several of his colleagues, including Dr. Gandell, an OBGYN from the Rochester region, to talk about the progress we’ve made in improving women’s access to reproductive health services and the work we have left to do to ensure that all women have the right to make medical decisions about their own body. I am proud to stand with women, doctors, and families from all over our country in opposing the Trump Administration’s plans to eliminate no-cost birth control. We have made tremendous progress, but the fight is far from over. As co-chair of the Congressional Pro-Choice Caucus, I will keep working every day to continue advancing reproductive health policies for women and their families.

Do you remember the names of the Wall Street firms and executives that plunged our nation to the brink of economic collapse in 2008? Of course not. That’s because they faced virtually no major recourse for their unchecked corporate greed. Under the House Republicans’ CHOICE Act, these same firms would once again be free to take advantage of consumers and force middle-class families to pick up their tab. Disgraceful.

Former FBI Director James Comey has just begun his testimony in front of the Senate Intelligence Committee. Like so many of you, I am eager to hear what he will say and expect to learn more about his interactions with the president, including whether President Trump may have obstructed justice by interfering in what should be an independent FBI investigation into Russia’s meddling in our election. This is an issue impacting the foundation of our democratic system, and it deserves a complete review. Although the Justice Department took a good first step in appointing Robert Mueller as a Special Counsel, that is not enough. We also need an independent commission to investigate and prevent this type of interference from ever happening again. This is an important moment in our nation’s history and we must all remain determined to get to the truth.

I just left the House floor where I voted against House Republicans’ wrong CHOICE Act, a dangerous bill that guts Wall Street reform and the protections so many of you rely on. Many of you have called and written this week to raise your concerns and I’ve heard you loud and clear. We cannot afford to dismantle the financial reform law and force consumers to once again go it alone against Wall Street!

Director Comey’s testimony is a reminder of the old adage that where there’s smoke, there’s fire. His testimony made clear that President Trump likely obstructed justice when he suggested Director Comey back down from what should be an independent FBI investigation into former National Security Advisor Michael Flynn. It is deeply troubling that the head of the FBI had to make notes of meetings out of fear the president might later lie about what happened. I am deeply concerned about where we are headed. It was shameful yesterday when members of the intelligence community refused to answer unclassified questions before the Senate Intelligence Committee. When we’re sworn into Congress, we take an oath to protect the United States against all enemies, foreign and domestic. Congress has no more important task than getting to the truth to protect our democracy. We need to create an independent commission like the one created by President Bush following the 9/11 attacks to get to the bottom of Russia’s hold on this administration, wherever it leads.

I will never stop fighting to ensure that my colleagues are upholding the ethical standards required of a member of Congress, no matter who they are or where they’re from. That’s why yesterday I called on the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, the acting U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York, the House Committee on Ethics, and the Office of Congressional Ethics to investigate this possible violation of the public’s trust. Rest assured, I will continue to hold my colleagues accountable and stand for what is right.

Every day, political intelligence firms help hedge funds and Wall Street investors profit from insider information about what’s happening in Congress. Wall Street pays these firms $400 million per year and that doesn’t even include profits made or losses avoided with the information. These firms have no oversight and can freely pass along any information to try and turn a profit. It's well past time the political intelligence industry is brought out of the shadows and into the light of day. My bipartisan bill, the Political Intelligence Transparency Act, would do just that. Read more about my bill here: bit.ly/2r9A8Z8

From taking on the political intelligence industry to accountability for members of Congress and increasing the ethics requirements for Supreme Court justices, I have fought tooth and nail to make our government and courts more accountable to the people that they serve. The ethics bills that I have introduced this Congress—the Political Intelligence Transparency Act, End Congressional Stock Market Abuse Act, and Supreme Court Ethics Act—are important steps toward ensuring that the people chosen to represent the American public act in the best interest of that public. I will never give an inch on this issue and will continue to take on any institution of power that has rigged the system against the American people.

CBS News has highlighted that it costs the taxpayers an estimated $24 million per week to run the House of Representatives. Here’s how Congressional Republicans chose to spend your tax dollars this week.

This week, I had the opportunity to meet Tobby Cassuto, a women’s rights advocate from upstate New York who was visiting Washington, D.C. to raise awareness about access to contraception, which is threatened under the Trump Administration and Republican Congress. Women like Tobby have worked for so long to make the progress that women enjoy today, and I’m impressed by her persistence to ensure that no Washington Republican dials back the rights we’ve won without a fight. We need to move forward on women’s health care rights, not let this administration take us back in the wrong direction.

It’s been fifty-one years since the Equal Pay Act was passed into law and women still earn less than men in the workplace. Although we’ve made progress, on average, women who work full time earn only 77 cents for every dollar earned by a man. Digging into the numbers paints an even worse picture as African American women earn only 64 cents and Latinas earn only 56 cents for each dollar earned by a white male. I am a proud cosponsor of the Paycheck Fairness Act because it is past time we realize that when a woman is paid less, it cheats her entire family. On the anniversary of the Equal Pay Act, I pledge to continue my efforts to advance equal pay for equal work.

Fighting for an open and transparent government has always been a top priority of mine. That’s why five years ago, Congress came together to pass the STOCK Act, a law I wrote that continues to reveal unethical trades. After learning that some members of Congress were using loopholes to get around this legislation and enrich themselves and their families, I introduced the End Congressional Stock Market Abuse Act, which would prohibit members from taking part in foreign IPOs, purchasing stock at discounted prices, or from participating in private placement stock offerings. Oversight of the STOCK Act is especially important to me, and I will continue taking action if any member of Congress tries to find a new way around this law.

Today marks one year since the tragic shooting at Pulse Nightclub, the worst shooting in modern American history. Members of our LGBTQ community gathered that night to celebrate Pride Month and they were instead met with unspeakable violence. Today, we pause and remember those that we lost a year ago. As a member of the LGBT Equality Caucus and a long-time advocate for our LGBTQ neighbors, I will continue to fight to ensure that all Americans, no matter who they are or who they love, are treated with the dignity they deserve. In recognition of one year passing since this tragedy, I signed a resolution acknowledging the day, remembering the victims, their families, and the survivors. To members of the LGBTQ community in Rochester, I am proud to represent you in Congress and will never stop advocating on your behalf.
“The New York congressman’s stock pitch to colleagues ‘just reeks of insider trading,’ a watchdog says.”  I agree.

This weekend I was proud to help kick off Girls on the Run of Greater Rochester's biannual 5k at Monroe Community College. For 21 years, Girls on the Run has helped more than a million young women from across all 50 states learn life skills through dynamic, interactive lessons and running games. I was especially proud to join the fun this year, which marks the 45th anniversary of the passage of Title IX, a landmark law known for breaking down the barriers that prevented so many women from taking part in athletics. The young women who trained for this run are a testament to what we have achieved and an inspiration to continue this progress. I was honored to be a part of the 5k and look forward to watching all of the participants continue to succeed!

Congressional Republicans don’t want to talk about the reason they jammed their disastrous health care repeal bill through the House, but I will. They rushed a bill with a 17 percent approval rating through the House without holding a single hearing, listening to any experts, or getting a score from the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office so they could slash Medicaid to the tune of $800 billion, hurting the poorest among us to pay for tax cuts for the wealthy. We know that under this proposal 23 million people will lose their healthcare and protections for people with pre-existing conditions will be gutted, making health care out of reach for many. This bill will impact one-sixth of our economy yet it was written in the shadows somewhere in a backroom. While my House Republican colleagues may put the wealthy first, I will continue fighting for all Americans. That means protecting and strengthening the Affordable Care Act.

I’m pleased to announce that dredging will be completed at Rochester Harbor this week. The reason I fight so hard to secure the funding necessary to dredge our port is so that we can maximize its full potential at a time when it imports $10 million worth of goods annually. Infrastructure projects like these are felt across our entire region, driving job creation and construction projects throughout Monroe County. That’s why I’ve continued working for years to improve our region’s transportation infrastructure, including dredging our harbors, fixing our highways and bridges, improving our airport, building a new train station, and reconnecting neighborhoods in downtown Rochester by filling in the Inner Loop.

In just a few weeks, the president and his team will begin renegotiating the North American Fair Trade Agreement (NAFTA). Rochester is a textbook example of how NAFTA has failed the American worker. There were 114,000 manufacturing jobs in our region when the agreement went into effect and after two decades of failed trade agreements modeled on NAFTA, our manufacturing employment is now half of what it once was. That’s why today I pushed United States Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer to completely overhaul this agreement and craft a bipartisan deal that includes enforceable labor and environmental provisions, protects Buy American policies, strengthens rules of origin requirements, and rejects the misguided investor-state dispute settlement procedure (ISDS). NAFTA needs major overhaul, not a slapdash agreement in pursuit of a meaningless signing ceremony. I will continue to fight for an entirely new course for trade policy that is finally fair to our workers.
I’m thinking of my colleague Congressman Steve Scalise and of all others injured in this horrific shooting. I’m grateful for the work of Capitol Police and the first responders.

I’m proud to announce National Endowment for the Arts grants for Garth Fagan Dance and Pegasus Early Music, two important arts centers in our community. The funding for Garth Fagan, an acclaimed choreographer who has helped shape Rochester for more than 45 years, will support the touring of new jazz and classical dance works. Pegasus Early Music, a concert series that regularly brings in world-renown musicians, will use their grant to fund a production of “Dido and Aeneas.” The National Endowment for the Arts and National Endowment for the Humanities make up less than 0.008 of the federal budget but they provide programming in every Congressional district and generate a rate of return that’s virtually unparalleled. As Co-Chair of the Congressional Arts Caucus, I will always advocate for the arts and I’m proud to represent one of the most vibrant arts towns in the United States. Congratulations, Garth Fagan and Pegasus Early Music, on your achievement!

This week I had the chance to meet Gregg and William, representatives from the Buffalo Bills. I even had the opportunity to show them a football helmet signed by Jim Kelly that sits in my Capitol office. Kelly is the first Bills quarterback to go to the Super Bowl and the only National Football League quarterback to go to four straight Super Bowls. The Bills will soon start training camp at St. John Fisher College's high-tech facility in Pittsford, one of the very best in the NFL. Good luck and go Bills!

I just had the opportunity to meet Amber Krug and Eileen Hartmann, representatives from the American Association of University Women (AAUW). For more than 130 years, the AAUW  has been promoting equity and education for women and girls. Eileen and Amber spoke to me about AAUW’s most recent research, Deeper in Debt, which revealed that the average woman takes out more student loans than men and, because of the gender pay gap, have less disposable income to pay off those loans. Women in the United States hold nearly two-thirds of the outstanding student debt in our country, or more than $800 billion in total. This is outrageous. I will continue leading the efforts in Congress to lessen the burden of student debt and enact laws that finally create equal pay for equal work. It is past time we level the playing field!

The president’s draconian budget would eliminate funding for Rochester’s REMADE Institute and the four other U.S. Department of Energy-sponsored institutes like it around the country. Securing this Rochester Institute of Technology-led, $140 million manufacturing institute was one of my top priorities and I was so proud to announce it coming to our community earlier this year. The REMADE Institute is a public-private partnership that will revolutionize manufacturing across industries to reduce energy and material costs while making improved products that are more efficiently reused and recycled. Eliminating this manufacturing institute would badly hurt our region and stifle our country’s efforts in manufacturing innovation. I will be working closely with my Republican and Democratic colleagues in Congress to stop this terrible proposal in its tracks.

For more than 65 years, St. John Fisher College has helped shape the minds of so many young students across our region by providing them a world-class  education. This week I was pleased to meet with the person working to continue that legacy, President Dr. Gerard Rooney. Dr. Rooney and I spoke about the importance of affordable higher education and what we can do to ensure that more students are graduating with degrees and less with crippling debt. I’ve long championed this cause and recently introduced the bipartisan Perkins Loan Extension Act, which provides low-interest loans that are paid back to the student’s college and creates a revolving system that supports the next class of engineers, teachers, artists, and so many more. Read more about my efforts to save the Perkins loan and reduce the cost of college here: http://bit.ly/2rDVKb9

This morning I will tour the new intermodal train station in Rochester with local business leaders from AIM photonics, the Eastman Business Park, the Urban League of Rochester, the Rochester Red Wings and more. The new station is nearly complete and will be fully compliant under the Americans with Disabilities Act, meaning that all of our neighbors will finally be able to travel safely to and from our community. Today’s tour is just the beginning for the Rochester train station. I can’t wait to cut the ribbon in just a few months!

It’s been more than 150 days since the president took office and still his administration has failed to update the official White House website with the important information Americans need. This includes information about the Violence Against Women Act, a law that I co-authored. Since this law was enacted, the number of domestic violence cases each year has dropped by 67 percent. Millions of people—men and women—need to be able to access the information and services this law provides. The White House should get serious about providing the information Americans expect, from climate change to LGBTQ rights to background about this law.    If you or someone you know is experiencing intimate partner violence, call the National Domestic Violence Hotline at 1-800-799-7233. It’s free, anonymous, and available 24/7; no fees, no names, no judgement.

Long lines, wait times, and unnecessary delays caused by freight trains. Too often, that’s what people have been forced to deal with when traveling through the Rochester train station. For years, our rail station had only one operational track. Thanks to the major expansion work, our station will finally have two fully operational passenger tracks, meaning that freight trains can pass through on one track while travelers board passenger trains on another. This is a big improvement and one that will help cut down on delays, improve your travel experience, and help continue to bring more people, businesses, and goods into our great city!

Last year, the international community recorded 65.6 million displaced people, refugees, and asylum-seekers fleeing violence and persecution in every region of the world. Today, we stand with those families in celebration and commemoration of World Refugee Day. Our compassion for those who are suffering is a source of our nation’s great strength and we must continue to defend America’s values and ideals in spite of any efforts to close our shores and make our country less safe. Recent attempts to bar entry into our country run counter to who we are and threatens our collective security. I’m proud to stand with many of my colleagues in co-sponsoring a bipartisan bill to reaffirm the United States’ leadership in responding to displacement crises around the world. I will continue using all possible means to protect our refugees and support all communities under siege in our country.

Today I am joining nearly 200 of my colleagues in the House and Senate in an unprecedented effort to force the president to comply with the foreign emoluments clause of the Constitution. This is not an action I have taken lightly, but I have watched for months as President Trump violated the anti-corruption provisions of the Constitution by profiting from foreign governments without the consent of Congress. Foreign governments have granted preliminary approval of trademarks virtually overnight, paid to stay at Trump hotels, and have even leased space at the president’s properties, raising concerns that this president is putting his business interests before the interests of the American people. The public has been left to wonder whether the president is making vital decisions based on what’s best for his business empire. All the while, the administration has ignored attempts at oversight and the Republican Majority in Congress has refused to perform its responsibilities. This has left us with no other choice but to ask the court to step in to block these clear violations. Our Constitution is clear that Congress must approve any president’s foreign transactions. No president is above the law.

Congratulations to the first-ever all-female surgical class at the University of Rochester, who will walk the stage at graduation in just four days. These doctors are a testament to the growing number of women entering and shaping the medical field. I’m proud of these women from the U of R and wish them the best as they leave their residency program and continue making positive change in communities across the country!

For more than 75 years, the National Gallery of Art has been enriching the lives of millions across our country. So far this year, the National Gallery of Art has seen an increase of 29% in visitors walking through their doors over prior years. Today I met Rusty Powell, the Director of the Gallery, to discuss the importance of the arts in our lives and how to make the arts accessible to all. I’m especially proud to have led my colleagues this year in requesting full funding for the National Gallery at a time when the arts are under siege. Under the president’s proposed budget, arts funding is slashed to the bone and the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities are eliminated despite the fact that they make up less than 0.008 of the federal budget. The arts are our universal language and help bring all communities—from students to veterans—together. I am not known for remaining quiet on this issue and I refuse to sit silently now. The arts are invaluable and I will do everything in my power to continue to defend them.

#ThrowbackThursday to one year ago, when I held the floor with my colleagues in support of commonsense legislation to combat gun violence. After Sandy Hook we said “never again.” In the years since, we said the same after the violence at Pulse Nightclub, in Aurora, Dallas, South Carolina and other communities. Just last week we were all shocked by the senseless attack at the GOP baseball practice. On average, 93 people a day are killed by a gun in America. Acts of violence have become all too common in communities across our country. Whether it’s an elementary school, a college, a hospital, a place of worship, or any place in the world, gun violence is there among us. It must stop. I was proud to hold the floor one year ago today and I will continue trying to finally end the gun violence epidemic that is plaguing this country.

Today I stood with nurses, doctors, health care providers and several of my colleagues against the Senate’s TrumpCare bill, a meaner bill than the legislation that passed the House recently. This repeal is a billionaire’s tax cut disguised as a health care proposal. It will wreak havoc for Americans on Medicaid, particularly pregnant women, families living paycheck to paycheck, and middle class seniors with long-term care needs. There is so much at stake under the Republican’s health care agenda. That’s why I will continue to fight it every single day while working to strengthen the Affordable Care Act that so many of you rely on.

“This country made it possible for me when they took me as a refugee, and exposed me to a world that is big and better than where I used to live in many ways. That drove me to invest in my children."   Jamal Abdullahi and his daughters, Biiftu and Dursitu, are a testament to the idea that when we open our arms to refugees from across the world, our country becomes a stronger and better place. Jamal took a job as a custodian at his daughters’ high schools to invest in their dreams of going to medical school – a dream now within reach for Biiftu and Dursitu. Our country must continue to welcome families like his, who strengthen our democracy and make this nation a better place.

Today marks the start of the 16th annual Xerox Rochester International Jazz Festival! With more than 100,000 visitors, hundreds of musicians and shows, this festival is a treasure for our community. I’m looking forward to stopping by this weekend!

The passage of Title IX was a truly historic moment in the ongoing struggle for the equal rights of women. Today, we celebrate 45 years of this landmark law, which prohibits discrimination on the basis of sex in federally funded educational programs and activities. This law has helped change the face of success in the classroom, on the playing field, and in the halls of power in our country. We can credit it for helping to create the current generation of women doctors, athletes, engineers, and public leaders. I’m such a proponent of this law that I will soon reintroduce the Patsy Mink Gender Equity in Education Act, which would provide more resources for schools and universities to fully implement Title IX. Every day, millions of women’s lives are shaped by the impact of Title IX. That’s a legacy I am committed to helping continue.
Ronald is right. We must revamp the voting system in this country. I wrote the bill we need: bit.ly/2tDdA0s

Two years ago today, the Supreme Court confirmed the right to marry for all Americans, no matter who they are or who they love. I’m proud to represent a vibrant LGBTQ community in Rochester and I’m especially proud to stand with my LGBTQ neighbors in commemoration of this historic day. This is a troubling time in our nation’s history and there is still work we must do to expand rights for everyone and ensure full equality under law. I’ll fight with you every step of the way.

I had a great time at the Xerox Rochester International Jazz Festival yesterday! The Jazz Fest is such an important event for the City of Rochester and I enjoyed seeing all the excited festival-goers and Jazz fans. I also had the chance to catch up with Derrick Lucas at the Jazz90.1 WGMC-FM booth. We talked about the value of the arts and specifically the role they play in helping rehabilitate our men and women in uniform once they’ve come home from war. I also shared with Derrick that, back in the day, I was a jazz singer for a big band during graduate school. My favorite song to sing was “Blue Moon.” I will always fight for the arts, since I know the critical role they play in growing our local economy and shaping our community!

The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office has found that 22 million Americans would lose their health insurance under the latest Republican repeal bill, including 15 million people losing their coverage as soon as next year. The bill would gut Medicaid and disproportionately impact those in nursing homes. Premiums and deductibles would be so high that, in CBO’s words, ‘few low-income people would purchase any plan.' No wonder they’re trying to jam this bill through Congress as quickly as possible without holding a single hearing or giving the public time to react to this devastating CBO analysis. This is no way to draft legislation that will impact one-sixth of our entire economy and virtually every American. Congressional Republicans should listen to the nonpartisan experts at the CBO, and to the majority of the public who want to see the Affordable Care Act improved instead of eviscerated. They should work with members of both parties to strengthen this law instead of rushing to fulfill a dangerous political talking point.
Congresswoman Slaughter stands with the families of Flight 3407

This morning, I stood with the Flight 3407 families, Captain Tim Canoll, president of the Airline Pilots Association, Jeff Skiles, first officer of Miracle on the Hudson, and members of the Western New York delegation. Following the 2009 tragedy, the families who lost loved ones became steadfast advocates in the fight for flight safety reform and helped win the most important aviation safety legislation in a generation, including increased training hours and rest requirements for pilots. I was especially moved this morning by Summer’s speech. Summer lost her father at just two-years-old and has helped her mom champion airline safety reform ever since. As a result of these efforts, we’ve seen over seven years without a fatal regional airline crash. I’m proud to have been at the forefront of this fight, which has made the skies safer for all Americans.

Eight years ago, the families from Flight 3407 turned their grief into action. In the face of unspeakable tragedy, they refused to give up and pushed the Federal Aviation Administration and Congress to institute airline safety reforms that protect air-travelers and help ensure pilots are fully-trained for their job. I have been honored to work with these courageous families and will continue to stand by their side as we push to keep our skies as safe as they can be. We will work every day to make sure this kind of preventable tragedy never happens again.

Innate Immunotherapeutics – the Australian company that Congressman Chris Collins serves on as board member and largest shareholder – saw its stock value plummet by more than 90 percent literally overnight. This follows the company previously suggesting a great response to its drug and touting that it stood to generate as much as $3 billion in profits in the U.S. This raises very serious questions as to when Congressman Collins knew about the drug’s performance and who is responsible for the suspicious trading before the drug’s failure was publicly known. In these hearings and markups, House members heard from 181 witnesses from both sides of the aisle, considered 239 amendments, both Democratic and Republican, and accepted 121 amendments. In total, the Senate spent more than 160 hours considering the health reform legislation and the final Senate bill included 147 Republican amendments. So enough with the political spin. The Republican process has been nothing but dead-of-night deals and partisan theatrics. That terrible process has created an awful proposal that rewards the rich and hurts everyone else. The American people deserve better.

Today marks the ninth anniversary of the post 9/11 G.I. bill. Under this bill, servicemen and women who have served for three years on active duty since September 2001 are eligible to attend an in-state, public college or university and complete their education for free. I was proud to bring this bill to the floor of the House of Representatives for passage as Chairwoman of the Rules Committee in 2008. Since then, hundreds of thousands of servicemen and women have attended college, restoring the promise of a full, four-year education for veterans of Iraq and Afghanistan and their families. We owe nothing less than the best to the brave women and men who have risked their lives for our nation. That’s why I remain committed to ensuring that our veterans have the tools they need for success after returning home from war.

For 54 years, the Civil Rights Act has served as one of the most important achievements in our history. This landmark law is our pillar of equality and fairness and it's a testament to the tireless courage of thousands of Americans who demanded justice and worked, every day, to make that possible. We have made significant strides since this important day in 1964, but there is still more to do to ensure that equality in every sector of our society, from job opportunities, to housing, education, and health care, are practiced. As we observe this anniversary, we must recommit ourselves to making this country more just and fair for all. I will continue to work every single day in Congress toward this dream.

Ann, who has asthma and a thyroid problem, recently shared with me her fears that if the Republican repeal bill becomes law she will no longer be able to afford the doctor visits, tests, and medicine she relies on every single day. Ann has a right to worry. Under the Republican repeal plan, states could allow insurance companies to stop covering certain types of care that were protected under the ACA. Listening to and hearing from my constituents is the most important part of my job. That’s why I want you to keep sending me your stories, so I can amplify your voices and concerns in Congress. We must make sure Trumpcare is defeated so people like Ann can keep the insurance they need.   Submit your story about how the ACA has helped change your life here: http://bit.ly/2izRaur

Elizabeth from Upstate New York began suffering from a chronic health condition at the age of 19. Under the Affordable Care Act she was able to stay on her parents’ insurance and get the surgery that saved her life. She was also able to get her own Medicaid coverage as a result of Medicaid expansion, allowing her to continue to receive medications and care from specialists. If the Republican repeal bill ever sees the light of day, hundreds of billions of dollars will be stolen from Medicaid, disproportionately affecting people like Elizabeth, seniors in nursing homes, disabled Americans, and the poorest among us. All of this for a massive tax cut to the wealthy. Instead of jeopardizing the lives of tens of millions of Americans just to fulfill a political talking point, I will continue to work, every day, to strengthen the ACA and fight back against the Republican repeal bill.

I recently heard from Scott from Rochester whose brother was diagnosed with a mental illness several years ago. Scott’s brother was never able to get the health insurance he needed until the Affordable Care Act was passed. Thanks to the ACA’s required coverage for mental health services, he began seeing therapists and doctors and his condition has greatly improved. If the Republican repeal bill becomes law, states could opt of out of requiring insurers to cover mental health, which could drastically drive up the cost of mental health care coverage. We must make sure that people like Scott’s brother, whose lives have improved as a result of the ACA, are not stripped of the services they need.

Happy Throwback Thursday! In January, I was proud to stand with doctors, nurses, and hundreds of constituents from Rochester in support of the Affordable Care Act. Nationwide, the impact of the ACA has been astounding and New York is no exception. Did you know that, in New York alone, an estimated 47,000 young adults have been able to stay on their parents health care plan up to age 26; more than 6 million people no longer have to deal with annual lifetime caps that used to limit their coverage just when they needed it the most; and more than 8 million people have been able to access preventative care like flu shots and cancer screenings at no cost? I will continue to fight to strengthen this law for the hundreds of people who showed up in the bitter cold in January and for everyone else in our community. We cannot afford to give up the progress we’ve made in ensuring quality insurance to millions of Americans.
