Today I’m proud to stand with those fighting back against President Trump and the Federal Communications Commission’s efforts to undo net neutrality protections. Let’s be clear. Net neutrality safeguards free speech online and promotes an open and fair net. Rolling back these protections would limit economic opportunities for small businesses and organic online movements like the historic Women’s March on Washington and Black Lives Matter. Earlier this Congress, Washington Republicans took away internet privacy rights for all Americans and now they’ve gone one step further in trying to gut net neutrality. We cannot allow President Trump’s FCC to cut the legal legs out from underneath our freedom of speech, pave the way for big corporations to decide what you see and who you talk to, and hand your power to choose over to the highest bidder. I will continue to fight against this proposal every step of the way.

Holding Election Day on a Tuesday is an out-of-touch, arcane policy that was developed more than a century and a half ago. Although it made sense then, it doesn’t make sense now. Seniors, students, and people who work the night shift don’t have the time they need to get to the polls and cast their ballots. This outdated policy is a major contributor for our country’s shamefully low voter-turnout rates, which was just 57.5 percent this past November. This is a problem and that’s why I recently introduced the Weekend Voting Act, which would move Election Day from the first Tuesday in November to the first Saturday and Sunday after the first Friday in November, giving people the time and flexibility they need to cast their ballot. In order to strengthen our democracy, we must do everything we can to increase access to the ballot box. This starts with passing my bill, the Weekend Voting Act.

In an executive order earlier this year, President Trump dramatically cut the number of refugees allowed onto our shores. In fact, he set the lowest cap ever by the executive branch and less than half of that set by the previous administration.  As of this afternoon, that cap has been reached. This is devastating news for people across the globe seeking asylum from their home countries. In 2016, 65 million people were displaced from their homes. Nearly half of them were children. Without asylum, these individuals will be forced to undergo continued persecution. Today especially, the president’s decision to slam the door in the face of refugees sends a dangerous signal to the rest of the world that protecting the most vulnerable among us is no longer a top concern. We are a nation of immigrants and we must honor that history by continuing to responsibly welcome vulnerable people from all over the world.

It’s clear that when countries make it convenient for citizens to vote, their democracy is strengthened by higher voter turnout rates. The United States currently ranks 138th of 172 nations in voter turnout, mostly because our Election Day falls smack in the middle of the workweek. We decided to vote on Tuesday in 1845 when we were an agrarian society. Times have changed. The number one reason Americans give for not voting is that they are too busy or just can’t get time off work. France, Germany, Thailand, and Japan are just some of the countries that have moved to holding their elections on the weekend, contributing to significantly higher turnout rates. That’s why I wrote the Weekend Voting Act, which would move Election Day to the first Saturday and Sunday after the first Friday in November. I’ve been working on this issue for many years because voting is the foundation of our democracy. Let’s make it easier, not harder, for people to get to the polls.

Today also marks the standing up of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB)​, an agency created by this law that has already helped 29 million people in all 50 states receive nearly $12 billion in relief. Despite the major progress we’ve made, House Republicans have made it their mission to roll back these reforms, which have protected hardworking American families while helping grow our economy. We cannot afford to hand the power back over to the big banks and corporations. I led the charge in Congress and brought the financial reform law to the House floor as chairwoman of the Rules Committee. Instead of eviscerating important consumer protections, I will work every day to secure the safeguards that you and your family count on.

The Republican process has been nothing but backroom deals and partisan theatrics with zero Democratic input. This week, the Senate is set to vote on a repeal. If Republicans in Washington are serious about ensuring quality coverage for the American people, they shouldn’t be working in a partisan fashion to ram the health care repeal bill through the Senate without Democratic contributions. The University of Rochester recently shared news about their groundbreaking work to address antibiotic resistance. Led by Dr. Ann Falsey, the U of R team is developing a diagnostic tool to help doctors differentiate between a bacterial and a viral respiratory infection.  This will ensure that antibiotics are only prescribed to the patients they can help, which is key to controlling the spread of antibiotic resistance. Antibiotic-resistant infections cause at least 23,000 deaths a year in this country and by 2050, one person could die of such an infection every three seconds. That is why I have sounded the alarm on this threat for years, including writing the Preservation of Antibiotics for Medical Treatment Act (PAMTA) and sponsoring legislation that would help end the misuse of antibiotics.

Carole is right. The benefits and protections afforded by the ACA must be protected. Congratulations to Ed White on being named chair of the National Photonics Initiative (NPI) Steering Committee! NPI is an important alliance of scientists and industry members that raise awareness of photonics, a field that supports more than 17,000 jobs in our region and that plays a leading role in New York’s high-tech economy. Ed has worked side-by-side with me and so many others in the industry as we launch the photonics institute and position Rochester to lead the world in this revolutionary research. There’s no doubt in my mind that with his advocacy and leadership in this role, the photonics industry in Monroe County and throughout the country will continue to thrive in the years ahead.

Today is Startup Day Across America! In celebration, I toured one of our community’s most impressive companies, West Henrietta-based manufacturer SiMPore, who has grown from a start-up to a successful business. I also announced two major federal awards that will help them continue their important work. Don’t miss today’s editorial in the Democrat and Chronicle. Drug overdose is now the leading cause of death for Americans under 50 and more Americans die every day from overdoses than car crashes. Drug addiction is a complex, national issue and one that requires a comprehensive approach. We must tackle it from every angle, and my legislation is the right step toward a solution.

"Elected representatives have an obligation to ensure our voting system makes it as convenient as possible for our friends and neighbors to exercise their right to vote." I am proud to stand with Senator Chuck Schumer today in calling on the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs to take action and acknowledge the connection between Agent Orange exposure and a type of brain cancer called glioblastoma. For almost a decade, American soldiers serving in Vietnam were exposed to nearly 20,000,000 gallons of Agent Orange. Since that time, thousands of these veterans have been forced to deal with ensuing health complications like cancer. We owe a tremendous debt of gratitude to the men and women who’ve worn the United States uniform and that’s why I will not stop raising my concerns on this issue. It’s past time for the VA to acknowledge the link between Agent Orange and brain cancer and provide our veterans in need with the care that they deserve.

It is beyond time the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs recognize the link between Agent Orange and a type of brain cancer called glioblastoma. I have been sounding the alarm on this issue for many years because we have an obligation to protect veterans like Tom Cray who put their life on the line to protect our country.

I’m proud to lead this fight in Congress and will continue to take action on this critical issue!

Today in Washington, the Trump Administration began renegotiating the NAFTA trade agreement. I voted against NAFTA because I knew it would hurt Rochester. Unfortunately, that’s exactly what happened and it’s now clearer than ever that NAFTA needs a major overhaul.  The president has made many claims about how he will improve NAFTA, but his negotiations today will take place in secret and it’s unclear whether the agreement he seeks will actually be good for workers and places like Rochester or just another corporate giveaway. Most importantly, it must stop incentivizing the loss of more American jobs.

This tremendous program provides pathways for young people to gain the skills training they need to succeed in life. Yesterday McDonalds announced that it will phase out the use of human antibiotics from its foreign chicken supply, building  on their previous commitments to cut antibiotics from their domestic supply. This is an important step forward on the issue of antibiotic resistance, a critical topic I’ve been raising for years. I called on McDonald’s and other corporations to do their part when it comes to antibiotic resistance because by 2050, it’s expected that one person will die of an antibiotic resistant infection every three seconds. I wrote the bill that would stop this problem in its tracks. Companies like McDonalds, Subway, and Costco are finally taking meaningful action but more must be done by the food industry. That’s why I will continue to work to safeguard antibiotics on behalf of consumers across the country who demand safe food that has been responsibly raised.

Happy 101st birthday to the National Park Service! My family has always loved our national parks and I know so many others do, too. Protecting our environment isn’t just good for our land, waterways, and air, it’s good for our health. As we mark this milestone, we must call attention to recent efforts by the current administration to roll back environmental progress, from withdrawing from the Paris Climate Agreement and reversing a rule that bans drilling in the Arctic to eliminating studies on the health effects of mountaintop-removal mining. On this NPS anniversary, our resolve must be as strong as ever to continue fighting environmental health hazards and keep our precious natural resources safe, clean, and protected for generations to come. Like and share if you agree!

Happy Throwback Thursday to 2014 when I helped break ground on the new Rochester Intermodal Train Station. This station will be a major asset for Rochester by helping grow our local economy and creating an easier flow of people and goods to Rochester. It’s also fully ADA-compliant, meaning that for the first time in nearly 40 years, all of our neighbors will be able to travel safely by train. I’m so looking forward to cutting that ribbon!

This Monday marks Labor Day, a time when we remember the men and women who helped build our country and the tens of millions of Americans who continue to carry that legacy today. Happy Labor Day, Rochester!

Last night I spoke on the House floor about the tremendous benefits we’re seeing from National Endowment for the Arts-sponsored art therapy programs on tens of thousands of service members across our country. Today, the House came together in a bipartisan compromise on some of the most urgent matters facing our nation. We extended the debt ceiling to pay our nation’s bills, passed a continuing resolution to fund the government, and secured the first funding installment for Hurricane Harvey relief efforts. This is a testament to what Congress can accomplish when everyone—Democratic and Republican—works together for the good of the American people. I am proud to have helped contribute to this major win!

Today, on the 16th anniversary of 9/11, let’s pause and remember the innocent victims and their families, the first responders who risked their lives, and the men and women in uniform who show such selflessness in keeping us safe. We must never forget.

The Trump administration recently halted a critical study on the health effects of mountaintop-removal coal mining. This is deeply troubling to me, especially since my father was the blacksmith for a Kentucky coal mine. Reckless, profit-driven mining practices contaminate the air and waterways and have led to heightened rates of lung cancer, kidney disease, and other devastating illnesses for far too many people. I’ve long been a fighter on this and even introduced legislation that would require the first comprehensive federal study on the effects of mountaintop coal mining on public health. Despite moves by the Trump administration to abandon science-smart studies, the evidence is clear: we must place a moratorium on further mountaintop coal removal until we can ensure that families in these communities are safe!

Today Rochester will welcome Ambassador Tom Pickering, an accomplished diplomat who has served under countless presidents, from Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan to Bill Clinton and George H.W. Bush. He’s dedicated his life to serving our nation—acting as a U.S. ambassador to countries such as India, Israel, and Jordan—and I’m proud to welcome him to Rochester!

I'm so proud of all the New Yorkers who are assisting the victims of Hurricane Irma. This week, Rochester and our state will send 10 Black Hawk helicopters and 55 Army National Guard members into Florida to help those affected by this historic storm. Our compassion for those who are suffering is a source of our nation’s great strength – I’m proud of New York’s efforts to uphold this important ideal!

I’m proud to announce that IGNITE has been awarded a $325,000 grant from the The United States Department of Justice to combat violence in the deaf and hard-of-hearing community. Thanks to this major federal award from the DOJ, IGNITE will partner with the RESTORE program to provide confidential crisis counseling and 24-hour hotline services to more than 120 domestic violence survivors in the deaf and hard-of-hearing community across Monroe County as well as create new jobs in this important field.

Excited to be headed to Google’s Washington office this morning for an event that will feature Rochester’s two federally-sponsored manufacturing institutes - AIM Photonics and the REMADE Institute. I am proud to have fought tooth and nail to secure two public-private manufacturing institutes for Rochester, the only city in the nation to hold this honor. I’ve said it time and again, our community really is leading the way in manufacturing innovation and today I will have the chance to promote this progress to industry executives from around the country!

67%: the drop in domestic violence since the adoption of the Violence Against Women Act, which I'm proud to have co-authored.   Today marks the 23rd anniversary of this landmark law, which has benefitted countless lives and changed the culture surrounding domestic violence in this country. Authoring this law is one of the most important things I’ve done as a member of Congress and I’m so proud that it has substantially reduced the incidence of domestic violence and empowered survivors to speak out, turning domestic violence from private suffering into public outrage. We celebrate this anniversary in somber recognition of the fact that more than 12 million men and women are still physically assaulted, sexually assaulted or stalked by an intimate partner every year. On this anniversary of VAWA, I recommit myself to fighting until that number is zero.

I had a great meeting at Google’s Washington office this morning where I met with industry executives from companies like Northrup Grumman Corporation, The Boeing Company, and Microsoft to talk about Rochester’s growing global role in advanced manufacturing. According to the latest data from the U.S. Census Bureau, the number of uninsured Americans has plummeted in recent years thanks to the Affordable Care Act (ACA). In 2015 alone, 900,000 Americans gained quality health care under the ACA, a landmark law I’m proud to have brought to the floor as chairwoman of the Rules Committee in 2009. Despite this major progress, the president is still dangerously pushing ahead by gutting enrollment outreach efforts and threatening to cut funding for cost-sharing subsidies. Protecting the health of millions of Americans who rely on this law should be a bipartisan effort. I’m outraged by the president’s indifference and will never stop working to protect your care.

Thanks to the American Institute for Manufacturing Integrated Photonics and the REMADE Institute, Rochester is leading the way in innovative manufacturing. This week, I hosted dozens of executives from around the country and told them that our community is not just a good place to do business, it’s THE place they should be doing business.

I am honored to be the 2017 recipient of the Anthony L. Jordan Health Center Lifetime Achievement award! One of my top priorities in Congress has been protecting public health. This has included everything from bringing the Affordable Care Act (ACA) to the House floor as chairwoman of the Rules Committee and fighting for reproductive rights to securing the first batch of federal funding for breast cancer research and working for 14 years to pass the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act. As new attempts to repeal the ACA continue to surface, I am prepared to work harder than ever before to defend your health rights. Thank you, Jordan Health for this tremendous honor!

No surprise here! Fortune Magazine recently ranked Rochester-based Wegmans as one of the top 10 places in the country for women to work. We discussed the growing optics and photonics workforce in our region and, as Adele makes clear, Rochester really is leading the charge in innovative manufacturing. I’m proud to be at the forefront of our region’s advanced manufacturing sector and will never stop working to grow this groundbreaking industry!

The threat to Obamacare is back and it’s real. Washington Republicans’ Graham-Cassidy bill would punish states like New York that have increased access to health care and would end Medicaid expansion efforts. Senate Republicans are trying to push this bill through by the end of next week to use a special process called reconciliation to repeal Obamacare with just 51 votes. Worse still, they are planning to vote without an analysis from the nonpartisan experts at the Congressional Budget Office outlining this bill’s costs and impacts on coverage. We can’t let Congressional Republicans move quickly and quietly on a bill that would impact one-sixth of our economy and rip away the care you depend on.

I’m proud to be highlighting our community for consideration as Amazon.com's HQ2! Last week, at a meeting I hosted to educate industry executives about Rochester’s growing global leadership in advanced manufacturing, I made sure Amazon’s representative knew that Rochester was the best possible place for their new headquarters. This will arguably be the toughest corporate-siting competition the nation and the world have ever seen. That’s why I’m working hard with other community leaders to ensure we’re putting the best foot forward as we compete.

I’m so proud to announce this federal award for the Rochester Museum & Science Center that will be matched by the center, bringing the total investment to a million dollars! People travel from all over to visit RMSC, which we are blessed to have in our community. This museum is doing wonderful things under the leadership of its CEO, Kate Bennett. Centers and cultural institutions like this one are a major driver for tourism in our region, which contributes a billion dollars to our local economy every year. This grant from the Institute of Museum and Library Services will help ensure its collections inspire and inform for many years to come!  http://bit.ly/2wHeLfy

The setting of today’s sun marks the start of Rosh Hashanah, a season of reflection and renewal for Jewish people across our community and the world. From my family to yours, I wish you and your loved ones L'shanah Tovah - a happy, healthy, and sweet new year!

Today marks the 6th anniversary of President Obama’s elimination of Don’t Ask Don’t Tell, a policy that prohibited openly gay, lesbian, and bisexual individuals from serving in our military. This anniversary is an important milestone in the fight for full equality and it’s also a reminder of the barriers we still face. In July, the president took to Twitter to ban an estimated 15,000 transgender servicemembers who sacrifice for our country every single day. This is not only immoral, it also makes our nation less safe. On this anniversary of the disbanding of Don’t Ask Don’t Tell, we must recommit ourselves to defending and promoting equality for everyone, especially the brave patriots who wear the U.S. uniform and put their life at risk for our country.

I was so impressed by the progress I saw on my tour of AIM Photonics’ Test, Assembly and Packaging (TAP) facility with industry executives and community leaders this afternoon. This more than $100 million facility will mark a new chapter for our region as we work to bring the photonics institute online. The space we toured today will ultimately be home to some of the most innovative equipment in the world, with no other facility like it in the country. I’m especially proud that TAP is calling the Eastman Business Park home. The facility will get on-site expertise and Eastman Business Park will be able to attract more businesses and encourage existing ones to grow. That’s what I call a win-win! Today’s tour was a good sign of what’s to come for our region.

In the last 12 years, refugees have contributed an estimated $269 billion in revenues to all levels of our government. This is according to a recent U.S. Department of Health and Human Services study that the Trump administration tried to bury because it disproves the president’s outrageous claim that refugees are too costly. Since his start, President Trump has repeatedly pushed anti-refugee initiatives including his travel ban from seven majority-Muslim nations and deep cuts to the annual refugee admissions cap. Studies show refugees add innumerable value to our society. While the president may continue trying to turn back the clock on our nation’s ideals, I will continue to fight for an inclusive America!

Yesterday’s American Institute for Manufacturing Integrated Photonics tour was a great sign of the major progress happening at Rochester’s new Test, Assembly and Packaging (TAP) facility, which is set to open its doors later this year. The TAP facility will help our community continue to lead the way in innovative manufacturing, create more good-paying jobs and a next-generation workforce right here in Monroe County!

Senate Republicans have released a new version of the Graham Cassidy bill, a last-ditch and dangerous resurrection of TrumpCare. Its core cruelty remains unchanged: it will still defund Planned Parenthood, eliminate essential health protections like newborn care, mental health and preventative services, and punish states like New York that have worked hard to expand access to health care. This bill has been roundly rejected by health care experts, doctors, nurses, and more and yet, Senate Republicans are still steamrolling ahead. Like the many of you that have called in, I strongly oppose this proposal and will vote against it if it ever makes it to the House floor.
Rep. Slaughter stands with consumer protection activists and colleagues in fighting for medical device safety reform.

Yesterday at the Rules Committee, I recognized the devastation we’re witnessing in Puerto Rico because I want to make sure this catastrophe gets the attention it deserves. The mayor of San Juan said it best, “don’t forget us, and don’t let us feel alone.” We have an obligation to help our citizens, both in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. Watch me here:

Senate Republicans just pulled the plug on the Graham Cassidy bill, a rush job and a last-ditch resurrection of TrumpCare. This is good news for tens of millions of Americans that have come to count on the Affordable Care Act (ACA) for quality coverage. Make no mistake, your voices were essential to this fight and they will continue to be critical moving forward. Today we celebrate this victory and double down on our efforts to strengthen and improve the ACA!

Today is World Contraception Day, a time to reflect on the hard-won progress we’ve made in protecting reproductive rights and recommit ourselves to continue fighting for full access to contraception. The Centers for Disease Control CDC rightly named contraception as one of the 10 greatest public health achievements of the 20th Century because its benefits are truly innumerable and include everything from reduced global maternal mortality and improved economic stability for women and families to the lowest teen pregnancy rate in recorded history. As co-chair of the Pro Choice Caucus, I am proud today and every day to be leading this charge in Congress for women and families in the United States and around the world!

Today I got the chance to meet Dr. Tom Hall, Principal of Brighton High School and 2017 Principal of the Year in New York State! For more than 20 years, Tom has served Monroe County as both an exemplary teacher and principal. I can say with certainty after today’s meeting that he is a remarkable community leader and so deserving of this prestigious award. Way to go, Tom, Rochester is proud of you!

Today, I’m proud to stand with women and girls around the country in introducing the Patsy T. Mink Gender Equity in Education Act, which would bolster Title IX and help schools enforce this landmark law that bans sex discrimination in publicly-funded research and education. Now more than ever, this law is vitally important as Secretary DeVos moves forward with watering down federal policies that enforce Title IX guidance on sexual assault. The Trump administration shouldn’t be trying to take us back to another century. We need to strengthen Title IX, and that’s precisely what this bill would do while targeting resources where they are needed the most!

I’m proud to announce this Department of Justice grant that will help domestic violence resource centers across Monroe County. This major federal grant is a result of the Violence Against Women Act (VAWA), a law I co-authored and one of my proudest achievements in Congress. With this award, survivors will have the tools they need—like legal and counseling services—to step out of the shadows and get the help they deserve. I’m so pleased that 23 years later, VAWA is continuing to make meaningful change for so many across our community.

I am proud to have stood with consumer protection advocates in support of medical device safety reform! Many of the women I spoke with have been harmed by devices like Essure, which has led to far too many maternal deaths and miscarriages. No one—man or woman— should ever worry that a device meant to make their lives better could have unforeseen and dangerous consequences. In May, I introduced a package of bills that would reform the FDA review process for medical devices and increase access to legal recourse for victims. These bills are about saving lives and I’m committed to working every day in Congress with my colleagues to ensure their passage and put real reforms in place to protect patient safety!

Adele Ratcliff is responsible for industrial base policy at the Department of Defense and recently joined me to visit Rochester and meet with local high tech companies. We had great discussions about strengthening American manufacturing for national security and creating the workforce of the future.  Adele’s been a big supporter of our community, which is home to the AIM Photonics Institute and the REMADE Institute, two of only 14 USA Manufacturing institutes nationwide. This meeting was another strong sign of the good things to come for our region, as we continue to lead the way in innovative manufacturing!

I’m proud to lead the entire New York congressional delegation in a bipartisan push to save the Perkins Loan Program, which is set to expire at the end of this week. Students all across the country have begun their fall semesters and now, thanks to Republican leadership’s inaction, they’re being told there’s no guarantee a Perkins loan will be available to them as they work through their degree programs. I want to make sure this critical issue is getting the attention it deserves and that’s why I brought together my New York colleagues to send a letter to Speaker Ryan and other leaders urging them to work together to reauthorize the Perkins Loan program. There’s no time to wait, and I will continue fighting for this program every day for the 500,000 students nationwide that depend on it. Check out the letter here: http://bit.ly/2wZzDPh

Republican leaders are packing up their bags for the week but there is still much left to do before September 30, including reauthorizing the Perkins Loan Program. New York State is home to the largest number of students in the country—more than 50,000—who rely on this low-interest loan program for help getting their degrees and Monroe County alone is home to 6,000 recipients. It’s outrageous that instead of reauthorizing this important program, Republican leaders are leaving town and refusing to move the ball forward. Low-income students all across the country count on Perkins loans to get the education they deserve. The inaction on this issue is outrageous, and I will continue to lead the charge to reauthorize this program!

While boarding the plane back to Rochester, I got the chance to meet and give thanks to Vietnam and WWII veterans traveling to our nation’s capital on a Southwest Honor Flight. They’re visiting D.C. to tour the national memorials constructed in honor of veterans’ service and the sacrifice they and so many other vets made. I’m honored to have had the chance today to thank those who put their lives on the line for our country.

Like the many of you that have called in, I am appalled by the president’s decision to drastically reduce the number of refugees allowed into the United States for fiscal year 2018. Our compassion for those who are suffering is a source of our nation’s great strength, and with smart policies we can ensure our national security while remaining a beacon of light in a sometimes dark world. During my time in Congress, I have consistently worked to support refugee resettlement and promote human rights around the world while prioritizing our national security, and I won’t stop now. This just another example of the Trump administration taking our country in the wrong direction.

This week I took to the House floor to stand up and speak out in support of the Perkins Loan Program, which helps provide low-interest loans to 50,000 New York students and 6,000 students right here in Monroe County. The doors of opportunity should be wide open for all students, and that’s exactly what a Perkins loan helps do. Share this post if you’re ready to fight with me to #saveperkins!

Check out this new report by Consumers Union that rates top chain restaurants on their efforts to reduce the use of unnecessary antibiotics in their meat supply. Two million Americans become infected annually with bacteria that are resistant to antibiotics and at least 23,000 die each year as a direct result of these infections. The fact is we’re losing life-saving antibiotics faster than we can create new ones because we waste 70 percent of all antibiotics sold in the U.S. on factory farming practices that are both inhumane and pose significant public health risks. I’ve introduced legislation to reign in this abuse and will keep up the fight in Congress but we need consumers to speak up with their pocketbooks. How does your favorite chain rank? Any responsible restaurants or producers in your neighborhood? More here: http://bit.ly/2wYM1Ec

Proud to read this story today about Harris Corporation, who are sending portable radios, spare batteries, and desktop stations to assist the New York State troopers deployed to Puerto Rico to help victims of the recent hurricanes. The devastation we’re witnessing in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands must not go ignored, and I’m proud of our community’s efforts to help those in need!

Today marks the start of Domestic Violence Awareness Month, a time to come together to draw attention to this serious issue and help bring domestic violence out of the shadows. Twenty-three years ago, I co-authored the Violence Against Women Act to help protect millions of women and men around the country and I’m proud of the 67% drop in domestic violence we’ve seen since this law came into effect. But we’ve still got so much work to do. Today, one in three women and one in four men report experiencing sexual and physical violence or stalking by an intimate partner. On this first day of Domestic Violence Awareness Month, I pledge to keep working until that number is zero.

Thursday morning, the Supreme Court agreed to take a case challenging public-sector unions that is being financed by the conservative Bradley Foundation. Later that same day, Justice Gorsuch gave the headline speech at an event backed by the very same group. To top it off, the event was held at the Trump hotel in DC, which happens to be owned by the person who nominated Justice Gorsuch to the Court.  This exact type of conflict and threat to judicial independence is why I have authored a bill to bring the Supreme Court under a code of ethics. Just like all other federal judges, the nine Supreme Court justices need to be held to the highest ethical standard.

Last night in Las Vegas, our nation witnessed the worst mass shooting in modern United States history. My thoughts and prayers are with the victims, their families, and the first responders. But thoughts and prayers alone are not enough. Through our history, Congress has taken action in the face of other national crises and the scourge of senseless gun violence should be no different. We can and must take action to address the epidemic that is tearing communities and our nation apart. The United States stands alone as the only country on the face of the Earth to constantly see these large-scale shootings. There are common-sense measures we can enact to keep our communities safe and better understand the causes of mass shootings. But only if Congress has the backbone to stand up to the gun lobby. Enough is enough. We must act.

I just opened the Rules Committee by recognizing the horrific event that unfolded in Las Vegas late last night. Members of Congress are in a unique position. As legislators, we have the opportunity to do something about the gun violence epidemic that is tearing our country apart. Enough of this senseless violence. It is time for action.

I recently helped break ground on Rochester's new Veterans Clinic, which I’m proud to have worked long and hard to make a reality starting with securing the necessary federal funding. The 70,000 veterans living in the greater Rochester region deserve the best care we can give them, and a state-of-the-art clinic is an important step in the right direction toward accomplishing this critical goal. We owe nothing less than the best to these brave men and women and that includes the services and care provided by the soon-to-be VA Clinic!

The Democrat and Chronicle is right. It is time for some of my colleagues in Congress to take their heads out of the sand and move forward with enacting laws that will protect the American people from the gun violence epidemic. Thoughts and prayers are simply not enough. We need meaningful action. Now.

I just took to the House floor to call out House Republicans on HR 36, an offensive bill and another assault in the long line of attacks on women’s reproductive rights. Our nation just witnessed the most deadly mass shooting in modern history and our fellow citizens in Puerto Rico are experiencing a dire humanitarian crisis. Instead of developing much-needed solutions, House Republicans are instead using time and taxpayer money considering yet another bill that would chip away at women’s constitutionally-protected right to choose. To House Republicans: enough with the political posturing. The women of America are fed up and demand that you quit the partisan games and #StopTheBans!

Congressional Republicans don’t want the public to know they had plans to vote on a gun lobby giveaway around the same time our nation was witnessing the worst mass shooting in modern American history. The SHARE Act would make it easier for people to purchase silencers on firearms, even semiautomatic weapons and rifles. It would also legalize armor-piercing bullets, rendering most law enforcement officers’ body armor ineffective. If people can’t hear where the shots are coming from and our first responders don’t have protection they need to carry out their duties, no one stands a fighting chance. This is a dangerous bill that continues to be shuffled back and forth by House Republicans to escape public scrutiny. Yesterday, the Nobel Prize in physics was awarded to three scientists who discovered gravitational waves proving Einstein's Theory of Relativity. Did you know that researchers from the Rochester Institute of Technology helped lay the foundation for this discovery? Scientists confirmed the existence of gravitational waves using photonics-enabled technology at the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO). This marks the second year in the last three in which optics and photonics have facilitated a scientific discovery awarded with a Nobel Prize in physics. The world-class research happening right here in Rochester helped play a role in yesterday’s big announcement and I am proud of our community’s contribution to this pioneering research!

House Republicans have passed HR 36, a bill that attacks a woman’s Constitutional right to choose and bans abortions after an arbitrary cut-off point. The highest court in the land said that the decision she makes in consultation with those she trusts should be free from any interference from the government. It’s pure hypocrisy that Republican leaders in Congress are pushing this bill while not finding room in their agenda to extend the Children’s Health Insurance Program, which provides nine million kids across our country every year with quality health coverage, before it expired last week. All too often, this Congress does nothing to address the reality our children and families face every single day.

The time has come! This Friday, the new Rochester train station will open its doors. This day has been a long time coming for our community. I secured the first round of federal funding for the new train station seven years ago this month. After working with stakeholders and constituents and securing more than $18 million in federal funding for this project, this station is finally about to open a new era for our community. This project has untangled track and will strengthen our local economy by getting goods and people where they need to go more safely and reliably. I can’t wait to join members of our community this week to cut the ribbon on the world-class, Americans with Disabilities Act-compliant train station Monroe County deserves!

Two years ago, I had a little too much fun counting down the demolition of the old, dilapidated train station. Now, I’m preparing to cut the ribbon on the new, state-of-the-art station and open the doors to more than 130,000 annual travelers! On Friday, our community will welcome a high-tech, ADA-compliant and modern station that will help reduce regional delays and get goods and people where they need to go more efficiently!

I was so pleased to visit the National Gallery of Art this morning and get an up close look at a Monet! Next year, “Waterloo Bridge, London, at Dusk” will be on loan to the University of Rochester's Memorial Art Gallery (MAG). Right now, conservators at the National Gallery of Art are hard at work studying the painting in order to contribute even more research to the MAG’s upcoming exhibition. As co-chair of the Congressional Arts Caucus, I am always looking for new ways to bring the arts into education. I am delighted that U of R students and the general public will have the opportunity to enjoy and learn more about this masterpiece, and am thankful to the National Gallery for giving me a behind-the-scenes look!

Today’s the day! This afternoon, I will help cut the ribbon for the new Rochester train station. It’s been a long fight getting this station up and running, and one I’m proud to have led for everyone in Monroe County. From securing the necessary $18 million in federal funding and hosting countless development meetings with stakeholders and constituents to strategizing with community leaders, I am proud to have been leading this process every step of the way. This station will give the 130,000 travelers that come in and out of Rochester the grand welcome to our city that they deserve. Like and share if you’re ready for our state-of-the-art station!

Say goodbye to the stool! For 37 years, Rochester was served by an ill-equipped so-called temporary station that did not fully meet the needs of everyone in our community. I’ve heard stories of people in wheelchairs having to be carried onto the train because the passenger platform was not level with the door. That’s no longer the case with the new ADA-compliant station, which features a platform level with the doorway of the train so that no one ever has to use a stool to board again. The new station also features fully-functional escalators and elevators and digital public information display systems. No one should be forced to use inaccessible and outdated systems that fail to meet their needs. That’s why I’m truly proud to bring this ADA-compliant station to Rochester!

Today, I opened the new Rochester train station, a state-of-the-art transportation center and hub for the 130,000 annual travelers coming to our great city. With investments in infrastructure like this comes economic growth and a boosted tourism industry. Rebuilding our crumbling infrastructure and keeping transportation systems updated are some of my most important priorities in Congress, and this train station will be our biggest boost yet. All that’s left to say is: all aboard, Rochester!

The Trump administration today released an interim final rule that would allow any employer to be exempt from the requirement to provide health insurance that includes contraception. It is unconscionable that the Trump administration is trying to turn back the clock and let virtually anyone from bosses to insurance executives decide who gets access to contraception coverage. Women wouldn’t just have to pay higher costs; they could be forced to pay the entire cost of their birth control. Birth control is health care, plain and simple!

When Rochester comes together, Rochester wins! The grand opening of the train station was a welcome worthy of Rochester and marked the start of a new era of faster and more reliable transportation in our region. Securing the federal funds for this project is part of my larger infrastructure agenda that also includes redeveloping the Inner Loop, fixing our roads and bridges, updating our airport, and dredging our harbors. You can’t have a strong regional economy without modern transportation infrastructure. That’s why I’m proud to lead the charge in Congress to ensure Monroe County has the resources it needs to thrive in a 21st century economy!

In July, the president took to twitter to ban approximately 15,000 transgender service members, a move that appears to have been made without consulting Pentagon leaders or military officials. It’s outrageous that major national security decisions are being decided and announced in 140 characters or less with apparently no forethought. That’s why today I’m taking action with more than 100 of my colleagues in asking Secretary Mattis to release correspondence he had with the president prior to his announcement banning transgender service members from the Armed Forces. Matters of national defense should not be announced on a whim or in a series of tweets. I will continue to raise my concerns and demand answers so we can get to the bottom of this immoral move that makes our nation less safe!

Today, the Trump administration moved forward on repealing President Obama’s Clean Power Plan, which accelerated our nation’s shift toward renewable power and away from coal-burning power plants. Now more than ever smart energy policies are absolutely critical, as the effects of climate change—like more dangerous hurricanes, super storms, and wildfires —continue to create chaos for tens of millions of American families. We cannot afford to disregard science and abandon our efforts to combat climate change. I will continue to stand up, speak out, and advance legislation that solidifies our nation’s role as a clean energy leader of the future!

I am proud to have stood with my colleagues and the 400,000 Americans who signed petitions against the corporate giveaways in NAFTA as the Trump administration continues its rewrite of this misguided trade deal. I voted against NAFTA because I knew it was a bad deal for American workers. Sadly we’ve seen the disastrous effects right here at home, with Rochester losing half its manufacturing jobs since this deal took effect. As the president renegotiates NAFTA, the investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS) provision is one we should all agree must go. For too long, ISDS has put foreign corporations in charge of our trade policies. The president should fulfill one of his most critical campaign promises and deliver a better deal on NAFTA that actually helps American workers!

Happy International Day of the Girl! Today, we refresh our commitment to empowering young girls and bringing attention to the challenges they still face. I’m a mother of three daughters and grandmother of seven. One of my top priorities in Congress is to pass legislation that expands opportunity for all our children. Despite the progress we’ve made, we still see gender inequality in every sector of our society, from health care to the workplace. We must keep working until we have an equal playing for every child, and that’s exactly what I intend to do!

I’m so proud that the law I helped write, the Trafficking Victims Protection Act, is bringing $600,000 in federal funding for the Worker Justice Center of New York so that it can continue providing life-saving services to human trafficking survivors right here in our community.

They made clear that Iran was just weeks away from building a nuclear bomb before we entered into this agreement. It was carefully crafted with the international community, including the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Russia, and China. This deal remains the most responsible path forward to stop Iran’s nuclear development, giving us access to military sites and the ability to make necessary changes when key milestones are reached. Decertifying this agreement would hurt our standing abroad and have consequences across the globe. I hope the president thinks twice before breaking this deal. We must continue our relief efforts and help Puerto Rico rebuild.

Anyone who has the privilege to be a member of Congress has a responsibility to uphold the public trust and meet the highest ethical standard. I wrote the STOCK Act and fought for six years to get it signed into law for precisely that reason. I called for the Ethics Committee to investigate Congressman Collins given all the evidence that suggests he used his position in the public trust for his own personal gain. Don’t miss my editorial for the Hill today about President Trump’s latest attack on women’s reproductive rights. On Friday, the president issued a rule that would let anyone, from bosses to insurance executives, decide who gets access to contraception coverage. Under this rule, women could pay the full cost of birth control which can average $600 or more every year. The president has said over and over again that he respects women. Personal profit should never come before the interests of the people who elected you to serve.

The competition is heating up for Amazon.com's second North American headquarters! This is likely the biggest and toughest corporate-siting contest the world has ever seen and I’m so pleased to see Rochester and Buffalo join forces to ensure Western New York is putting its best foot forward as we compete. I’ve got my fingers crossed!

The president’s decision will isolate the United States. The Iran nuclear deal was carefully crafted through a broad, international effort that included the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Russia, and China. It will be difficult if not impossible to reassemble that kind of support again. The United Nations Security Council approved it unanimously and all of the experts tell us today it remains our best path forward to continuing to prevent Iran from building nuclear weapons. The world’s nuclear watchdog, the IAEA, confirmed this week that Iran is complying with the deal. That same view is shared by dozens of retired military leaders and security officials from Republican and Democratic administrations, as well as international observers. This week I met with some of the chief architects of this deal, including former Secretary of State John Kerry, former Secretary of Energy Ernest Moniz, former Treasury Secretary Jack Lew, and former Undersecretary of State for Political Affairs Wendy Sherman. Ambassadors from France, the European Union, Great Britain, and Germany also attended, representing their countries as part of the deal. They made clear that before this deal went into effect, Iran was just two months away from building a nuclear bomb. They also reiterated that it was in our national interest to remain a part of the agreement.    Former Prime Minister of Israel Ehud Barak has made clear that this agreement does not threaten Israel. Despite what the critics are claiming, the agreement also allows for the inspection of military sites and includes the ability to make necessary changes when key milestones are reached. The president’s decision to withhold certification of this deal will only hand Iran a victory and make China’s cooperation in dealing with the North Korea far less likely. It should be deeply concerning not only to Congress but to our international allies that the president has moved to decertify this deal even over objections from his own Secretary of Defense and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. This rash decision will have consequences around the globe. It flies in the face of the facts and the opinions of experts and could lead to yet another conflict abroad. Once again, the Trump administration is putting partisan campaign promises and the president’s worst impulses ahead of keeping American families safe.

In 2017, more than 300,000 women will be diagnosed with breast cancer. October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month, a time to remind ourselves of the tough battle that all-too-many women face and bring attention to the importance of screenings and early detection. One of my major accomplishments in Congress was securing the first batch of federal funding—$500 million—for breast cancer research at the National Institutes of Health (NIH). Before 1993, all NIH clinical trials were being conducted on white men only, meaning diseases killing thousands of women and minorities each year were being improperly researched. I am proud to have led the fight to fix this disparity and will continue with efforts to give our scientists and researchers the resources they need to finally find a cure.

I was honored to be a panelist at University of Rochester's session of Miller’s Court during Meliora Weekend on Saturday! I sat alongside journalists, professors, and experts in the field of law for a panel discussion on the Supreme Court and the most pressing legal issues shaping our country today. This is particularly exciting as the Court is set to face some of its most significant decisions in recent decades. Thank you, U of R, for having me!

I’m proud to help announce this major federal award for Refugees Helping Refugees (RHR)! It’s a testament to the inclusive, important work happening right here in our community. For 15 years, this volunteer-based not-for-profit has helped countless refugees in Rochester gain the resources and the skills they need to thrive in the United States. This funding will help expand that critical mission at a time when the president and his administration continue to use misguided travel bans and short-sighted policies to prevent refugees from seeking refuge in our country. Congratulations, RHR, on this award!

It was a pleasure to provide the leaders of the Episcopal Diocese of Rochester with an update from the front lines of Congress last night! Thank you, Ascension Episcopal Church, for hosting me and to all the leaders for such a productive and passionate conversation about national issues that impact our community.

Our region is home to 70,000 veterans, about one out of every 15 residents. These brave individuals put their lives on the line to protect our country and deserve nothing but the very best, including a stellar education. This U.S. Department of Education award will help local veterans earn their degrees while preparing for their future. Congratulations to Rochester Institute of Technology on becoming home to such an important program!

Sunday’s 60 Minutes investigation into the opioid epidemic is an example of what a strong press can do. This story proved once again that when something as bad as this bill, the misleadingly-titled Ensuring Patient Access and Effective Drug Enforcement Act, slips through the cracks, it doesn’t stay hidden for long. This legislation never went through the committee process or received a recorded vote on the House Floor. I did not even have an opportunity to vote on this bill. Instead, it passed as if it were a non-controversial bill, something it clearly was not. The public outcry should be a warning to any member thinking about doing the bidding of major corporations over the health and safety of their constituents. The president’s pick to lead the Office of National Drug Control Policy, Congressman Marino, wrote this disastrous bill and is now no longer in line to become our nation’s drug czar because of it.

Today we celebrate 45 years of the Clean Water Act, one of the most significant environmental laws in our country’s history. Despite its importance, the president recently moved to limit the scope and reach of this law. The Clean Water Act safeguards our drinking water, maintains fish and wildlife habitats, and promotes a healthy economy. In our own backyard, 26 million Americans rely on the Great Lakes for commerce, transportation, drinking water, and recreation. We are the stewards of our land and water and we have an obligation to protect them for future generations in Rochester and all across the country.

I’m looking forward to touring the progress today at the Inner Loop, a project that is creating new jobs, strengthening our regional infrastructure, and reconnecting neighborhoods in Rochester. The Inner Loop—just like our new train station— is funded by a federal Transportation Investment Generating Economic Recovery (TIGER) grant, a program the Trump administration has targeted for elimination in its Fiscal Year 2018 budget proposal. I’m proud to have brought in not one but two of these competitive awards in the last five years, since we all know how important updated infrastructure is to spurring economic growth. I’ll continue fighting tooth and nail to save programs like TIGER!

The president recently moved to roll back the Affordable Care Act provision that has allowed 62 million women to gain access birth control with no out-of-pocket costs. This act completely ignores the reality that birth control is health care. Today I’m introducing legislation that would prevent the president’s misguided, ill-informed interim final rules from having any force of law. We need to pass this bill to give the 62 million women able to access contraception under the ACA peace of mind that their birth control will not be put out of reach by this president.

I’m looking forward to addressing the Rochester Oratorio Society’s centennial celebration of women’s suffrage tonight! Our state was one of the first to guarantee women’s suffrage a full three years before the rest of the country. As this preview makes clear, tonight’s event also celebrates the 150th birthday of American composer Amy Beach, a pioneer in musical composition. The joining of tonight’s artists in celebration of Amy Beach is a testament to the strong sense of community we have and a reminder of how far we’ve come and how far we have to go to ensure equality for all.

Late last night, Senate Republicans voted for a harmful budget that would slash Medicare, Medicaid, and essential job-creating investments for hard-working families. This is their first step in trying to pass a multi-trillion dollar giveaway for special interests and the wealthy. The non-partisan Tax Policy Center estimates that a staggering 80% of the tax benefits in the Ryan-McConnell plan would go to the richest one percent in this country. I will stand firm against the fast-moving multi-trillion dollar giveaway and will continue to demand not one penny in cuts for the richest among us.

Things are looking good at the Inner Loop! This project—which helped create hundreds of new construction jobs—is set to finish up later this year and I’m proud to have secured the funding to make it happen. Right now the president is moving forward with a budget that slashes transportation funding by $2.4 billion, including the full elimination of the Transportation Investment Generating Economic Recovery (TIGER) grant program, which made the Inner Loop project a reality. We all know that modern infrastructure brings more businesses and workers into our city. That’s why I will keep fighting against the administration’s short-sighted budget proposal. We must keep our region and nation competitive in a 21st century economy!

Birth control gives women the opportunity to plan their families in a medically-safe way, provides treatment for conditions like endometriosis and polycystic ovary syndrome, and much more. Despite this clear and essential medical need, it is rarely treated like an important medication, made most clear by the president’s recent roll back of an ACA provision that provides birth control with no out-of-pocket costs to 62 million women nationwide. Like many of you, I am outraged by the president’s shortsighted decision to jeopardize birth control protection and am proud to introduce legislation that would ensure his latest move has no force of law.

I was honored to help break ground on the expansion of the Anthony L. Jordan Health Center! One of my main priorities as a member of Congress has been ensuring that our communities are healthy, from securing the first federal funds for breast cancer research on women and working to halt the effects of antibiotic resistance to introducing the Affordable Care Act on the House floor in 2009. We need strong health care resources, providers, and practitioners in our communities and I’m so proud that Jordan Health is helping take care of Rochester. This expansion is an exciting step forward and I am looking forward to seeing all the good Jordan Health does next!

Under the Affordable Care Act’s contraception mandate, more than 62 million women nationwide have gained access to birth control at no out-of-pocket cost. My bill, the Protect Access to Birth Control Act, would defend this progress from the Trump administration’s latest, anti-woman attack. More here from Bustle:

“The STOCK Act has indeed had a dramatic impact on stock-trading activity by senators, reducing both the overall volume of stock trades and the transaction value of those trades.”    I’m proud to have authored the STOCK Act to prohibit insider trading by federal officials, including members of Congress and their staff, and am pleased by the progress we’ve seen. In the Senate alone, the number of stock transactions three years before and after the passage of this law fell by 68 percent. Still, there’s much work to do. I’ve already introduced two bills this session of Congress to strengthen ethics laws and ensure full transparency in your government. Read more about my bills here: https://louise.house.gov/issues/ethics

1.1 million: the number of people who are expected to lose out on health care coverage because of the president’s move to sabotage the Affordable Care Act (ACA) advertising efforts. In August, the Trump administration announced it would gut the marketing budget for the ACA and slash the signup season in half. They even cut funding for the navigators who help people enroll and plan to close the healthcare.gov website almost every Sunday during open enrollment. The shorter enrollment period combined with reduced resources to help people who need health care will translate into fewer people signing up, creating chaos in our marketplaces and skyrocketing premiums for sicker and lower-income people. Open enrollment begins November 1 and ends December 15th and you can sign up for coverage on www.healthcare.gov. Like and share this message to spread the word!

Budgets are about priorities and it’s pretty clear from this proposal that Congressional Republicans’ priorities lie with the wealthiest Americans. To fund a massive tax cut for the wealthy, this plan calls for slashing $1.3 trillion from health programs like Medicaid, nearly $500 billion from Medicare, and more than $650 billion from programs like school lunch and nutrition initiatives. It also cuts financial aid programs at a time when education costs are soaring and college is becoming out of reach for far too many of our students. If it wasn’t before, it’s clear now that after years of carrying on about spending and the deficit, Congressional Republicans’ concern was all just a charade. They are now pushing this plan that would increase our deficit by $1.5 trillion while furthering the false notion that these cuts will pay for themselves in economic growth. As Bruce Bartlett, a domestic policy advisor for President Reagan, recently made clear, ‘tax cuts don’t equal growth.’ This is an irresponsible budget that is about one thing: setting the stage for tax cuts for the wealthy. The middle class and poorest among us will be left to pay the price.

I was so pleased to attend the Rochester Oratorio Society’s centennial celebration of women’s suffrage. For more than 70 years, the Oratorio Society has inspired countless people in our community with their beautiful choral and musical productions. The society is comprised of almost 145 men and women from the seven-county area, many of whom attended local universities to hone their craft. Many of the female performers approached me and told me about the barriers they worked hard to break as they were becoming seasoned musicians, proving wrong all of those who suggested this craft was better left solely to men. I was proud to hear these stories and am honored to represent the thriving and inclusive arts community in Rochester!

It’s been four weeks since Hurricane Maria made landfall and still, 80 percent of Puerto Rico is without electricity and local officials say it could be months, if not longer, before power is fully restored. Last night, a $300 million contract was awarded to a two-person Montana firm with ties to Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke. Was this the result of a comprehensive and competitive national search or is this a no-bid contract given to a company based in a state that Secretary Zinke used to represent? This is a disgrace to the people of Puerto Rico and to all taxpayers. Contracts of any size should be awarded to companies that have undergone a rigorous review process and that have proven themselves capable of such a monumental job. This is an all-hands-on-deck moment, not a two-person job.

Along party lines, they defeated a motion I offered that would have allowed for a debate and vote on the House floor on Representative Ted Lieu’s (D-CA) amendment. We cannot let this humanitarian crisis fall from the headlines and I am so pleased to know that members of our community are going to be playing a critical role in helping Puerto Rico rebuild.

Let’s cut right through the spin. The Republican budget is about one thing: clearing the way for a trillion-dollar tax break for the wealthiest in our nation. This would hurt countless families across Monroe County and the country. Yesterday at the Rules Committee, I spoke about how our community would be impacted by this disastrous plan. Watch me here:

I just finished leading colleagues, doctors, and activists in calling on the Trump administration to rescind their latest bad idea, which allows anyone—from insurance executives to bosses—to discriminate against women by refusing to offer health insurance plans that provide no-cost birth control. This rolls back the Affordable Care Act’s birth control mandate, which has helped provide contraception access to more than 62 million women nationwide. I’m fighting tooth and nail against the president’s devastating decision, including introducing legislation that would ensure it has no force of law. We cannot turn back the clock on reproductive rights.

I’m proud that Rochester’s own Lumetrics is receiving this federal award to improve bullet proof glass for our men and women serving in uniform around the globe. For years, I’ve worked to improve the safety of our body armor and am proud to have brought more than 16,000 pieces of unsafe armor back from the front lines. This award for our local manufacturer will ensure that Rochester continues to play a key role in protecting our service members by manufacturing the next-generation armor for our troops!

This afternoon, by a vote of 216-212, House Republicans passed their dangerous budget. This was their first step toward enacting a massive, multi-trillion dollar tax cut for the wealthy. There are many awful things in this budget, but one of them hits close to home: the repeal of the State and Local Tax deduction, which ensures families don’t have to pay federal taxes on the taxes they’ve already paid. Repealing the SALT deduction is a political assault on states like New York, where over 65 percent of households with incomes between $50,000 and $200,000 claimed this deduction. Moving forward with the Republican tax plan would raise taxes on hard-working families in our state while subsidizing tax cuts for the wealthy. It’s insulting.

This year marks the 100th anniversary of women winning the right to vote in New York State. In my Washington, D.C. office, a resolution demanding equal recognition of women's rights under the Constitution hangs right by my desk as a reminder of past generations who worked hard to create equal opportunity for women. On March 15, 1848, this resolution was signed by more than 40 brave suffragettes from New York who risked everything, spoke truth to power, and paved the way for the women who came after them. Thanks to them, our state secured the right to vote three years before the rest of the country. Even as we celebrate milestones, the work is never done. I am proud to honor and help carry on the legacy of women leaders from our home state.

On Monday, the Food and Drug Administration, Centers for Disease Control (CDC), and the National Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring System (NARMS) released a new report that highlights the latest on antibiotic resistance. According to NARMS, there are an estimated 100,000 infections and dozens of deaths each year in the United States from drug-resistant nontyphoidal salmonella and the rate of multidrug antibiotic resistance among salmonella in humans saw a significant increase in just one year. I’ve been fighting against antibiotic resistance for years—including writing the Preservation of Antibiotics for Medical Treatment Act (PAMTA)—and this report is just more evidence that Congress must come together to pass my bill. Antibiotic resistance is not some far-off threat. It is a present danger and we need meaningful action to stop it in its tracks!

This will ensure  that they will not pose a threat to public health. Find a collection site near you: http://bit.ly/2xv7Irl

I was proud to participate in National Prescription Drug Take Back Day this weekend at the Fairport Police Department! Every day, more Americans die from drug overdoses than car crashes and most of those deaths involve prescription drugs that were legally obtained. At a time when the opioid epidemic is continuing to devastate communities across the country, it is especially important that we get rid of our unused or expired drugs in a safe way. That’s why I’m introducing legislation to finally hold the producers of these drugs—the big pharmaceutical companies—accountable for the safe disposal of the products that make them billions in profits. Read more about my bill here: http://bit.ly/2xycSTF

Way to go, RIT! I am proud to read that universities in our region like the Rochester Institute of Technology are taking big strides toward creating more opportunity for students of all socioeconomic backgrounds. More than 30 percent of RIT’s 2015 freshman class qualified for Pell Grants, a program that provides need-based funding to hundreds of thousands of low-income undergraduates across the country. We must never stop working to ensure the doors of opportunity are wide open for all students and I am proud to know that our community is playing an important part in achieving this goal!

Tomorrow, House Republicans are set to take their tax reform bill out of a backroom and release it to the public. Here’s what we can expect: this proposal would raise taxes on the middle class, give 80 percent of the tax benefits to the wealthiest one percent, force drastic cuts to Medicare and Medicaid, and add $1.5 trillion to our national deficit. We need real, bipartisan tax reform that puts hard-working families first. I will fight against any proposal that hurts working families in order to give tax cuts to the rich. I’ll continue pushing for better jobs, better wages, and a better future for families across Monroe County and the country.

Thank you U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren for your editorial today about the Supreme Court Ethics Act and for cosponsoring the Senate version of my bill! As the final arbiter of justice in this country, the integrity of Supreme Court justices must be beyond reproach. And yet, recent unethical behaviors by our justices continue to erode the public’s trust. My legislation would help restore that trust by requiring the Supreme Court to adopt a binding Code of Conduct just like the law already demands of every other federal judge in the country. I will continue to advance this legislation so that the American people can be sure that members of the highest court in the land are held to the highest ethical standards.

The last-minute delay of Congressional Republicans’ long-promised tax plan is just more evidence that the GOP is pushing a half-baked bill that would have disastrous consequences for workers and middle class families across America. House Republicans are hoping to race massive changes into law before the American people see it’s just another multi-trillion dollar giveaway to the wealthiest one percent. While Republicans have been desperately hiding the details about their bill, we already know this much is true: it would hike taxes on the middle class and much, much more. This bill is nothing but bad news.

Another week, another attempt by the congressional Majority to block women’s health rights. The House Judiciary Committee  just finished a hearing on H.R. 490—an unconstitutional bill that would ban abortion as early as six weeks, before most women even know they’re pregnant. It is beyond shameful that the GOP-led Congress is spending its time and taxpayer money on an abortion ban that will put women at grave risk while simultaneously ignoring the major issues facing our nation today. This bill is not about science or facts. It is just another case of men who don't think women have the right to control their own bodies. This legislation is blatantly unconstitutional and it's time to stop the bans.

They claim to care about children while cutting funding from programs they rely on, including everything from school lunch and nutrition programs to head start and financial aid. I’m proud to announce a new contract expected to total approximately $40 million from the Department of Defense that will allow Harris to equip the Army’s new Security Force Assistance Brigade with their radio systems. This contract will sustain thousands of local jobs while equipping our brave men and women in uniform during their important missions abroad.

I was proud to announce this $40 million contract for Harris Corporation to provide radio systems to the Army’s Security Force Assistance Brigade. This award will allow Harris to bring dozens of new jobs to Rochester. I’ve worked hard to stand up the Security Force Assistance Brigade and am excited they have the opportunity to benefit from Harris Corp’s innovative technology. This is an important opportunity to support our troops and strengthen our local economy!

I’m always so proud to see Rochesterians visiting our nation’s capitol and getting an up-close look at the legislative debates happening right now. Today marks the 100th anniversary of women’s suffrage in New York State, which was enacted three years before the rest of the nation. On this centennial celebration, we honor the courageous women who fought tirelessly for equal rights and recommit ourselves to fighting and gaining full equality. Today and every day, I am proud to represent a district that was home to many brave New York suffragettes!
Louise leads voting rights advocates, civil rights leader Martin Luther King III, and the co-founders of Why Tuesday in calling for the passage of her bill, the Weekend Voting Act.

Last night I once again pled with the congressional Majority to at least consider commonsense reforms that could prevent mass shootings following the attack in Sutherland Springs, Texas. Members of Congress can do more than offer thoughts and prayers, we can take action. It is past time we do.

Voting on Tuesday is an outdated practice that was convenient in 1845, but not so convenient in 2017. Today I led several of my colleagues, voting rights advocate Martin Luther King III and co-founders of Why Tuesday? to call for the passage of my bill, the Weekend Voting Act, which would move elections to the first Saturday and Sunday after the first Friday in November. Voting one day a week makes it hard for seniors, students, working people, and parents to cast their ballots. We must make it more convenient for people to vote. That’s exactly what my bill would help do.

We must heed the call of the World Health Organization (WHO) and finally end the rampant misuse of antibiotics on healthy animals. I’ve been sounding this alarm for years, and it’s time for the U.S. government, the pharmaceutical companies, and corporate agriculture to face the consequences of making antibiotics ineffective. Tens of thousands of American deaths are attributed to antibiotic resistance each year and the threat keeps getting bigger with every passing day. Lawmakers and the Trump administration have a decision to make: keep the status quo that puts corporate financial interests above public health or take decisive action that can help us avoid a nightmarish future where standard operations like cesarean sections and appendectomies become life threatening because antibiotics no longer work.

Speaker Ryan pledged to usher in a new era of openness in Congress.  But this week, in contrast to that promise, he broke the all-time record for the use of Closed Rules, a procedure that blocks all amendments to legislation. House Republicans issued their 49th closed rule this week, and Speaker Ryan even has the dubious distinction of being the only Speaker in history to have never allowed a truly open rule on the House Floor.  In fact, on most major bills, no member – Democrat or Republican – is allowed to offer any ideas to improve the legislation. Members cannot even fix a typo under a closed rule.  But this is more than a process point.  If you care about any of the following issues, then you should care about this abuse of restrictive rules. The more than 1300 amendments blocked by restrictive rules this year include the following topics:   Prohibiting Sending U.S. Troops to Syria; Prohibiting Funds for the 2001 Authorization of Use of Military Force; Protecting DACA Recipients; Protecting Asylum Seekers and Human Trafficking Victims; Protecting Whistleblower Privacy Rights; Reducing Government Spending; Restricting Funding for President Trump’s Border Wall; Funding for Domestic Violence and Child Abuse Prevention; Preventing Trump Businesses from Receiving Federal Contracts and Grants; Funding for the Fetal, Infant, and Child Death Review Program; Funding for a WIC Breastfeeding Program; Condemning Boko Haram and Establishing a Missing Persons Database;   Net Neutrality; Equal Employment; Confederate Memorials; Troop Levels in Afghanistan; Maternity Leave; Climate Change; Military Spending; and Executive Branch Ethics among many more.

1845: the year our formerly-agrarian society decided to hold elections on Tuesday so they wouldn’t interfere with Market Day on Wednesday.    It is past time to bring our election system into the 21st century and make it more convenient for people to vote. Yesterday I stood with Martin Luther King III, voting rights advocates, and my colleagues to push for the passage of my bill, the Weekend Voting Act. This important legislation would move elections to Saturday and Sunday to ensure that everyone—from seniors to night-shift workers—has enough time to get to the polls. Read more about my bill here: http://bit.ly/2tDdA0s

Open enrollment under the Affordable Care Act (ACA) began last week and www.healthcare.gov has already seen a record-number of signups. More than 200,000 Americans chose a plan on November 1. Closed rules block democratic input, shortcut the legislative process, and silence the voices of members of Congress sent here to represent their communities.
