I was proud to stand with Martin Luther King III—a tireless voting rights advocate—earlier this week to push for the passage of my bill, the Weekend Voting Act. Martin Luther King III’s father, Martin Luther King Jr., said it best: “the time is always right to do what is right.” I couldn’t agree more and that’s why I wrote the Weekend Voting Act, which would move Election Day to Saturday and Sunday, increase voter turnout, and expand access to the ballot box for everyone. This is the right step forward and now is the time for Congress to come together and pass this commonsense legislation.

Veterans Day is a time to remember and give thanks to all those who wore the United States uniform and sacrificed for our nation. Here in the greater Rochester region, we have 70,000 veterans and they deserve the best possible care, which is why I fought hard to secure the funding necessary to build our brand new veterans clinic being constructed in Henrietta. Take a moment today to thank a veteran in your community for their service and heroism. If you are a local veteran and need help getting your benefits, call my office at (585) 232-4850.

I am deeply saddened by the loss of Tom Cray. I was honored to know Tom from my earliest days in office and I can think of no one who better exemplified what it means to serve a cause greater than oneself. From serving his nation in Vietnam and serving his community as my first District Director to founding the Veterans Outreach Center, Tom committed himself to the betterment of his country and his community.  In so doing, he made an indelible impression on all those who knew him and on generations of veterans who have passed through the doors of the Veterans Outreach Center, Inc. Tom and his family are in my thoughts at this difficult time.

Enrollment in the Home Energy Assistance Program (HEAP) opens today! This federal initiative makes it possible for so many families in Rochester to meet the high cost of heating their homes. This is especially important in our region as we begin preparing for another challenging winter. If you are interested in HEAP benefits and are not currently receiving Temporary Assistance or Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program Benefits (SNAP), go to https://www.mybenefits.ny.gov to apply online or call (585) 753-6477. It’s World Antibiotic Awareness Week! I’m proud to see the Centers for Disease Control (CDC​) and the World Health Organization (WHO)​ prioritize this growing global threat. Antibiotic resistance is one of the biggest dangers to public health, food security, and development today. Every year, two million Americans get sick from antibiotic resistant infections like MRSA, pneumonia, and salmonellosis—and tens of thousands of people die as a result. It is past time Congress pass my bill, the Preservation of Antibiotics for Medical Treatment Act, so we can ensure everyday infections don’t become deadly and prevent against a nightmarish post-antibiotic future.

Right now, House Republicans are rushing behind closed doors to finalize the details of their disastrous tax plan. This bill hands the wealthiest one percent and the biggest corporations nearly 50 percent of the tax benefits at the expense of 38 million middle-class households. It adds $1.5 trillion to our national deficit in just the next 10 years, dismantles the State and Local Tax Deduction (SALT), eliminates student loan interest deductions, lifetime learning credits and medical expense deductions while also imposing new limits on the mortgage interest deduction. House Republicans may continue to recite their “pro-middle class” talking point, but the rest of us know the truth: this bill is a rush job that will hurt tens of millions of hard-working Americans.

In a surprise move, House Republicans are moving this evening to jam their tax bill through the Rules Committee. This bill is terrible in a whole host of ways but it’s particularly bad for students and middle-class families. It would rip away the student loan interest deduction that 12 million graduates rely on, ending lifetime learning credits, eliminating tax-free tuition assistance from employers, and decimating the state and local tax deduction that helps fund our schools. Educating our young people is the most important investment our government can make. It is unconscionable that House Republicans are stealing from students and schools so they can write bigger checks for their wealthy donors and big corporations.

House Republicans are using emergency procedures tonight to speed up consideration of their bill to give tax cuts to the wealthy. Yes, providing tax cuts to make the rich richer is a literal emergency for Congressional Republicans. They're hoping no one is watching as they work to hand out giveaways to the wealthy and corporations at the expense of 36 million middle-class households.

Today, Republicans in Congress will move forward on their disastrous tax plan that would provide sweeping tax cuts to the biggest corporations and the super wealthy while exploding the deficit by $1.5 trillion. All this at the expense of 36 million middle-class families, young graduates, teachers, seniors, veterans, and more. You can rest assured I’m voting no.

We must not go backward!

Today, the House is set to vote on congressional Republicans’ disastrous tax plan. Republican leaders in Congress are calling this bill “H.R. 1.” We should call it “H.R. 1%” since 50 percent of the tax benefits in this bill would go to the richest one percent and the biggest corporations in this country. This proposal is bad news for students, teachers, our veterans, homeowners, and millions more. It dismantles key tax deductions that hard-working people count on, explodes our national deficit, and is just another dangerous reincarnation of trickle-down economics. I will vote no this afternoon, because I believe the American people deserve better than this half-baked tax plan for millionaires.

The House Republican tax bill will make the rich richer and leave our nation’s students and teachers to foot the bill. At a time when the cost of education is soaring nationwide, this bill will eliminate the student loan interest tax deduction that helps make getting a college degree more affordable. These cuts raise $65 billion off the backs of our students and young graduates just to give the wealthy a tax cut they don’t need. Even a deduction teachers rely on when using their own money to equip their classrooms would be eliminated. The repeal of the state and local tax deduction would also be devastating for our schools. An analysis by the National Education Association found that eliminating SALT would put nearly 24,628 education jobs at risk in New York alone and cut $250 billion in education funding nationwide over the next ten years. I stand with our local schools, teachers, and students who understand that this bill robs resources instead of investing in our future.

State laws should also be considered, with a priority given to states with robust rights and protections for LGBTQ individuals and women. It was an honor to be a part of the Inner Loop East grand opening today. This is an example of an infrastructure project that will pay dividends for years to come, improving economic development and strengthening our economy while finally uniting our community. That’s why I worked hard to secure the federal funding necessary to make this project a reality. This transformation will truly bring our community together!

Last week, I had the opportunity to reunite with some of my current and former fellow members of Congress, who I worked with to ensure that Anita Hill would be able to testify at the Supreme Court confirmation hearing for Clarence Thomas. Marching to the Senate and demanding that Professor Hill be allowed to testify is one of the most important moments of my career. After her courageous testimony, the scourge of sexual harassment became the focus of the nation, and the following year the number of women in Congress dramatically increased in what became known as “The Year of the Woman.” It was an honor to be reunited with such an inspiring group of women to discuss this important watershed moment in history.  Twenty-six years later, we are at another such moment and we must all take responsibility to ensure we make the progress our nation so richly needs and deserves.

We must save net neutrality. I’ve heard from hundreds of constituents in just the last 24 hours who share my opposition to the FCC’s proposal to abandon net neutrality protections. Net neutrality helps create competition and grow innovation. This proposed rollback would cut the legal legs out from under the principles of a free and open internet that are so vital to our economy and democracy. Repealing these safeguards will only stack the field in favor of large corporations who want to charge customers more money. The FCC’s proposal turns a deaf ear to millions of consumers and instead represents yet another corporate giveaway from the Trump administration. While I am dismayed at this plan, the fight is not over to save net neutrality and protect the free and open internet.

Yesterday, my friend and former colleague Maurice Hinchey passed away. Serving with Maurice in the state assembly and in Congress was a gift I, along with so many others, will always cherish. Over his long career, he was a constant champion of the environment and working people everywhere. He was fearless in speaking truth to power and he leaves a remarkable legacy that will stand for many generations to come. I’m so grateful he was with his loving wife and daughter in his final peaceful moments. Today as we gather to give thanks, let us remember with grateful hearts, the many contributions made by Maurice Hinchey to New York State and to our nation.

The phones have been ringing off the hook from people who share my opposition to the Federal Communications Commission's proposed plan to abandon net neutrality safeguards. This awful proposal would endanger the principles of a free and open internet. It would turn a deaf ear to tens of millions of consumers, allowing corporations to decide what you see and jeopardizing free speech and our thriving internet economy. All the while, consumers would be forced to pay more for the same services they have today. Simply put, it is just another massive giveaway from the Trump administration to large corporations that want to charge consumers more money. The fight is not over to save net neutrality, and your voices remain crucial to this debate.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) has helped more than 29 million people receive more than $12 billion owed by corporations who took advantage or flat out stole from them. The bureau's independence is essential to its unbiased functions, and it has a clear line of succession that puts Deputy Director Leandra English in charge. On Friday, the president ignored this, instead naming Office of Management and Budget Director Mick Mulvaney as the bureau’s temporary director. When serving in Congress, Mr. Mulvaney called the CFPB “a joke” and said he wished it didn’t exist. The president’s move is legally-questionable. By putting someone in charge of this agency who once tried to eliminate it, this move also puts the administration’s favoritism for the rich and powerful special interests ahead of American consumers, the very group the CFBP was created to protect.

Happy Giving Tuesday, Rochester! Today is dedicated to giving back. Businesses, charities, and people across Monroe County and the country will come together today to celebrate generosity. If you’re planning on giving, don’t miss this Democrat and Chronicle story with tips on how to donate safely to the causes that mean the most to you.

This week, Codex Alimentarius, the organization which sets international food standards, is holding its fifth meeting to address the growing global threat of antimicrobial resistance. Eighty percent of antibiotics nationwide are routinely fed to animals, not people. The costs are simply too high, with 700,000 dead and $1.2 trillion spent each year as a result of this misuse of antibiotics. We cannot ignore this urgent threat. In the words of Codex Secretary Tom Heilandt, “resistant bacteria can send us back to the 19th century and before where many infectious diseases were untreatable.” I urge the U.S. and other delegates to uphold Codex’s commitment to safe, good food and to end the routine, unnecessary use of antibiotics in healthy animals. It is past time for strong, transparent reporting of how antibiotics are being used on farms. Our public health depends on it.

The Food and Drug Administration should be the gold standard for public health, but that couldn’t be further from the truth. That’s why I am urging them to move forward with meaningful and transparent measures that would hold pharmaceutical and agricultural industries accountable for their irresponsible antibiotic practices. Eighty percent of antibiotics in this country are sold for use in animals with most being fed to healthy farm animals to compensate for crowded and unsanitary living conditions or to promote growth. The American people are paying the price, with an estimated 23,000 deaths each year from antibiotic-resistant infections. There is no reason our nation should be falling behind the curve while countries like Denmark and the Netherlands lead the way in preserving these life-saving drugs. It is past time for publicly available data on how antibiotics are being misused on farms. I will not stop sounding the alarm until it happens.

The House Judiciary Committee is on the verge of approving H.R. 38, the Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act, which would weaken state gun laws and make it easier for a dangerous person to travel across the country with a loaded, concealed firearm. This bill would leave states doing a good job of tracking criminal and mental health records at the mercy of states that are not and endanger local law enforcement officers. H.R. 38 is on the top of the NRA’s holiday wish list, and congressional Republicans—in their typical fashion—are ready to deliver. The United States’ gun homicide rate is more than 25 times the average of other developed counties. Washington Republicans and their NRA donors might consider this a legislative win, but the American people know better. It is past time for commonsense gun reform.

There are 10 days left until the government runs out funding and will be forced to shut its doors. If that wasn't bad enough, Republicans in Congress continue to ignore major legislative priorities. Funding for the Children’s Health Insurance Program, which nine million children rely on for their healthcare and well-being, has now been expired for 60 days. Right now, nearly a dozen states are preparing to notify families that this critical program is running out of money for the first time since its creation two decades ago. It is past time for congressional Republicans to stop the delays and reauthorize this important program.

Senate Republicans are rushing ahead this week with a tax plan that has been roundly criticized by several nonpartisan analyses. The Congressional Budget Office and Joint Committee on Taxation have said that, by 2027, people making $40,000 to $50,000 would pay a combined $5.3 billion more in taxes, while those earning $1 million or more would get a $5.8 billion cut. More than 35 renowned economists from the University of Chicago claim this tax scam would only add to the long-term federal debt burden. This bill is a reckless move that would hurt hard-working families, put our nation further in debt, and harm economic growth. Washington Republicans should start listening to the experts and stop pushing a bill that would only benefit their wealthy donors.

Funding for Community Health Centers, which provide more than 27 million people in 9,800 communities across our country with access to health care, has now been expired for two months. That’s two months too long. This isn’t about numbers on a page, real lives are being impacted. Anthony L. Jordan Health Center, Oak Orchard Health- Brockport, and the Regional Primary Care Network collectively care for 135,782 patients in Monroe County. Their loss of federal funding means efforts to expand primary, mental, and dental care will come to a halt and programs to reduce expensive hospital stays will stall.  These centers care for the most vulnerable among us. Hurting them can only harm the health of their patients and the overall health of our community. It’s time for Republican leaders in Congress to step up and reauthorize this critical program.

Right now, Republican leaders in Congress are frittering away precious legislative time while our government barrels closer and closer to a shutdown. I just took to the floor to call out their inaction and remind them of the devastating consequences we saw after the 2013 Republican shutdown. Congress should be working together to tackle the major issues facing our nation today.

Today I took to the floor to stand up and speak out against congressional Republicans’ dangerous tax scam.  How many times will hard-working Americans be forced to watch their wages drop and their taxes soar before Washington Republicans understand that trickle-down economics simply does not work? There’s a word for doing something over and over again and expecting a different result: insanity.

Yesterday I stood on the House Floor with members of the New York congressional delegation to honor the memory of our former colleague, Maurice Hinchey. Maurice was a champion of the environment and working people everywhere. He was a fearless leader and will be missed by all who knew him.

While businesses in states like New York helped power our country throughout the Industrial Revolution, some left behind contaminated lands where their operations once stood. Yesterday, I voted for bipartisan legislation that would reauthorize a remarkable initiative that has remediated more than 25,000 contaminated industrial sites nationwide, including several right here in Rochester. This legislation contains key provisions of a bill I’ve introduced that would jumpstart the revitalization of these sites. Clean and safe neighborhoods are essential for families across Monroe County and are critical to attracting new businesses, residents, and tourism to our community. This is exactly what this bipartisan bill will help ensure.

As we mark World AIDS Day today, I am proud to announce $270,800 in funding for Trillium Health in Rochester under the Ryan White program to continue their important health care efforts in our community. Thanks to the work of bipartisan initiatives like the Global Fund, PEPFAR, Ryan White, and the Minority AIDS Initiative, we are closer than ever to ending AIDS by 2030 both in the U.S. and abroad. However, much work lies ahead. Across the world, 36.7 million people are still living with the virus – and too many of them are locked out of the education, treatment & care that they need. Today, let’s recommit to ending AIDS & empowering the millions of people impacted by the epidemic around the world.

The calls keep coming from constituents who oppose the Federal Communications Commission’s plan to do away with net neutrality. This terrible proposal stands in stark contrast to the principles of free speech that this country was founded on. We all know that large corporations should not decide what you see and say online. This fight is far from over, and I will keep working to ensure your voices are being heard!

Senate Republicans passed their dangerous, deficit-exploding tax scam. At the very last minute, they included illegible, handwritten additions to the bill and lobbyists got the details before many Senate Democrats or the public. Here’s what we know: the Senate bill repeals the Affordable Care Act’s individual mandate, hurts scholarship opportunities for students hoping to attend college, and opens the floodgates for drilling in pristine natural wildlife refuges. At the end of the day, this is one of the largest transfers of wealth from working families to the wealthy that we have ever seen. This is anything but responsible governance.

Right now, President Trump is removing protections from more than two million acres of public lands and waters in the American west, the largest rollback of national monuments in history. This move would hurt local economies dependent on tourism, endanger important Native American landmarks, and put access to our public lands at risk. This is an unprecedented move and, according to most legal scholars, completely illegal. It is just another shameful giveaway to the oil and gas companies and special interests, who will make an even bigger profit off of the destruction of our nation’s most precious landscapes.

The president’s so-called ‘enhanced vetting’ is having major consequences for so many across the globe, including interpreters who put their life on the line and work hand-in-hand with our military. 344,000: that’s how many New York kids are at risk of losing their health insurance if congressional Republicans don’t reauthorize the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP), which has now been expired for more than two months.    Right now, nearly a dozen states are preparing to notify families that this critical program is running out of money for the first time since its creation two decades ago. There is an easy way for Representatives Katko, Reed, and Collins to ensure kids in their community have the insurance they need: join Democrats and support a full CHIP reauthorization that doesn’t cannibalize other health services. It’s past time to get the job done.

Right now, the Supreme Court is hearing oral arguments in Masterpiece Cakeshop V. Colorado Rights Commission, a landmark civil rights case that could make it easier for businesses to deny service to any person or family they disprove of. This is about more than just cake. It’s about public businesses treating all Americans with dignity and respect. No one should have to worry about which shops will serve them, businesses should be #OpenToAll.

Right now, I’m at the Rules Committee calling out House Republicans' latest NRA giveaway—the Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act. This bill would weaken gun laws and make it easier for dangerous people to carry hidden, loaded firearms across state lines. It’s time for common-sense gun reform, not legislation handcrafted by the NRA at the expense of Americans’ safety.

I am proud to be leading the fight in Congress against the Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act. This NRA-giveaway would force dozens of states to weaken their existing laws and allow people convicted of violent crimes and domestic abuse to carry concealed firearms. In the wake of some of the deadliest mass shootings our country has ever seen, it is unconscionable that House Republicans are advancing a bill that would make our communities even less safe from the gun violence epidemic. It’s no wonder everyone from the International Association of Chiefs of Police to the Law Enforcement Partnership to Prevent Gun Violence has opposed this awful bill.
New Yorkers should not have their economic futures turned upside down by a deficit-exploding, campaign donor-appeasing GOP tax scam. I will continue to lead the fight against this dangerous bill.

There are hundreds of thousands of mothers like Laquita across the country that depend on the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP), which helps provide nine million vulnerable kids with the health services they need. Thanks to the Republican leadership, this program has now been expired for more than two months. There is no more time to wait, we must reauthorize this critical program. Now.

#TBT to being on the House floor for the start of the last, self-inflicted government shutdown by Congressional Republicans in 2013. If the Majority continues to prioritize their tax plan for corporations and millionaires while ignoring domestic priorities working families care about, they might find themselves right back where they were less than five years ago. This is shameful. The American people deserve better.

Like Congressman Conyers before him, Senator Franken made the right decision in resigning. Republicans should now take a hard look at members of their own caucus. They have a president who admitted to sexual assault, which should have been disqualifying, a House member who has used taxpayer funds to settle harassment allegations, and a candidate running for Senate who has been accused of child molestation and harassment. If the national reckoning on sexual harassment is going to truly change Washington, we must adhere to the highest standards for all public officials. Women are tired of being treated as pawns subjected to such awful conduct.

Congressional Republicans are kicking the can down the road with a short term plan that only funds the government for another two weeks. Why should the American people believe that they will now turn their attention to national priorities when they’ve been missing in action for months? Vital programs like health insurance for children and college loans for low-income students have been allowed to lapse and expire under their leadership. I welcome this new report that highlights the encouraging drop we’ve seen in year-to-year sales of medically-important antibiotics for use in animals. This decline proves that consumer demand can lead to better practices in the food industry despite inaction by the FDA. There is still much work to be done to end the unnecessary non-therapeutic uses of antibiotics—including routine disease prevention—which some producers continue to use as a crutch to compensate for unsanitary and overcrowded conditions. Until the overuse and misuse of antibiotics ends I will continue fighting to preserve these life-saving drugs!

In a meeting yesterday with Food and Drug Administration Commissioner Dr. Scott Gottlieb, the FDA committed to meeting with some of the women of #EssureProblems. This is a step in the right direction and is good news for the countless women that have been harmed by Essure, a permanent birth control device that has had more than 24,000 adverse events reported to the FDA and is no longer sold anywhere outside of the United States. No one—man or woman— should ever worry that a device meant to make their lives better could have unforeseen and disastrous consequences. I will continue to stand with Essure Problems and the women who have been harmed.

I’m so pleased to have had the opportunity to talk with 1039 WDKX about what I’m grateful for this holiday season. Representing Rochester is one of the greatest highlights of my life and I am so honored to serve the community I love.

The Federal Aviation Administration’s recent release of its online pilot records database is a hard-won, important step forward in making our skies safer for travelers. This is all thanks to the tireless advocacy of the Flight 3407 families, who never stopped turning their tragedy into meaningful action, often traveling to and from Washington, D.C. at their own expense to fight for better air safety. It is because of their work that we passed into law new pilot safety standards and we haven't seen another fatal regional airline crash since. I'm proud to have worked alongside them to make air travel safer for passengers nationwide!

I’m proud to join my colleagues from New York in calling for a much-needed federal aid package for Puerto Rico. Puerto Rico is a part of our country and is home to more than three million American citizens. The mayor of San Juan had a simple request since the start of the devastation: 'Do not forget us and do not let us feel alone.' We cannot let this disaster fall from the headlines, and we have an obligation to help our fellow citizens during what will be a longer-than-anticipated period of rebuilding.

Right now, the Committee on Education and the Workforce is considering H.R. 4508, a 500-page, extremely partisan bill that would make college more expensive for students and give for-profit corporations—like Trump University—unprecedented access to federal student aid dollars. This bill continues Washington Republicans and Secretary DeVos’ attack on education and forces students and non-profit institutions to pay for corporate giveaways. It’s made worse by the fact that there have been no hearings on the legislation. That’s right. House Republicans are willing and ready to push a multi-hundred page bill through without expert insight or the due process it badly needs, just 11 days after the bill was made public. Our students deserve better.

I applaud Samantha, Jessica, and Rachel, who bravely came forward yesterday to re-tell their story of sexual misconduct by the president. Every woman who speaks out on sexual assault and harassment deserves to have their voice heard. Today, together with more than 50 of my colleagues, I’m asking the House Committee on Oversight and Congressional Reform to investigate the claims of sexual assault against President Trump made by these and other women. We must hold even the rich and powerful accountable.

Climate change has cost our economy an estimated $240 billion every year for the last decade. This is unconscionable, and it’s why we need global alliances like the #ParisAgreement. This fact is lost on the president, who recently pulled the U.S. from this accord in a science-free and fact-free move. Our country must remain a leader in climate change, clean energy, and environmental protection. That’s why I’m #stillin.

I am offended beyond belief that the president would say something like this about my state's senator. U.S. Senator Kirsten Gillibrand and the women of this country will not be silenced. I've served with a lot of presidents and I've never been afraid for the future of our democracy like I am right now. I will not be quiet as he slimes the senator from my state.

Republican-appointed members of the FCC should not get to restrict access to your content, slow down connection speeds, and have final say over what you see and say online.

Five years ago today, our nation was shaken by the unspeakable violence we saw at #SandyHook Elementary School. Since that day, we have sadly seen more than 1,500 mass shootings in the United States. This must stop. Today we remember the 26 lives lost at Sandy Hook and recommit ourselves to working in every way possible to end the gun violence epidemic that is tearing too many communities apart.

Republican-appointed members of the Federal Communications Commission just voted to abandon #netneutrality, our online safeguard that protects free speech. The fight is not over, and I will do everything I can in Congress to get this right. You can count on it.

I am so proud announce several National Endowment for the Humanities grants for the Rochester Institute of Technology, the University of Rochester, and Rochester General Hospital! These highly-competitive grants total more than $650,000 and will help fund new jobs, research, and educational training across our community. Congratulations, RIT, U of R, and Rochester General!

When you sit down to watch the latest installment in the Star Wars franchise, you’ll be experiencing the work of one of Rochester’s most iconic companies! Kodak played a leading role in making The #LastJedi a reality. The movie was shot on Kodak 65 mm and 35 mm film made at Eastman Business Park. This week, I got the chance to meet with Ken Morris who is the great-great-great grandson of Frederick Douglass! Ken is descended from not one but two of the most important names in American history: he is also the great-great grandson of Booker T. Washington. Amazing! The life and legacy of Frederick Douglass is so important to our nation. That’s why I’m so proud that he is one of Rochester’s own and was one the few men to attend the Seneca Falls Convention. Just like his ancestors, Ken is helping lead the way to educate young people about our nation’s history and the importance of equality for all. Next year is the 200th anniversary of Douglass’ birth and I am so pleased to partner with Ken and others to carry out the Frederick Douglass Bicentennial Commission Act.
